i did enjoy to game, but I wish I could give a neutral analisys, rather than a positive one. I do recommend the game if you want an easy game with a nice story and pretty graphics.

The graphics and soundtrack are really good, and it does a great job setting up the atmosphere of the game. The characters are likable and the story is really well made. You want to see what happens in the story and to it's characters and how it all connects.

But the game is just too easy. It doesn't really require any thinking, you just do what needs to be done. Only choice you have at some times is whether you want to kill every guard or just sneak around them.
Your choices don't affect the ending, killing or saving the guards doesn't do anything, and you can't even be really creative when fighting, cause there's barely anything you can even do.

I think the game could have some extra mechanics here and there to make it more interesting or tricky in some bosses fights, and have actual puzzles.

Only actual bad exprience I got was getting stuck in that freaking tent at the camp, that seems to be an old bug that unfortunately never got fixed. At least the way to get out of the bug is well covered by the community and you can unstuck yourself

150104105.review:
Immersed within the hauntingly beautiful landscape of 14th century France, "A Plague Tale: Innocence" intricately weaves a mesmerising narrative that ensnares the senses from its opening moments. This atmospheric masterpiece effortlessly captivates, leaving players spellbound and yearning for more.

The game's greatest triumph lies within its narrative prowess and captivating setting. The story's depth and immersive quality kept me irresistibly hooked, yearning to delve deeper into the haunting mysteries of Amicia and Hugo's journey. The plague-infested world breathes life into a dark yet enthralling backdrop, where every step unravels a piece of the puzzle, compelling me to explore further.

Crafting and combat mechanics, though vital, gracefully harmonise with the overarching narrative without overshadowing its essence. The simplicity and straightforwardness of these elements accentuate the storytelling, ensuring an uninterrupted flow. This delicate balance between gameplay and storytelling ensures that every moment spent engaging in combat or crafting feels seamlessly integrated, never detracting from the game's emotional resonance.

Moreover, the visual allure of "A Plague Tale: Innocence" stands as a testament to its sheer magnificence. The meticulous attention to detail paints a vivid and arresting canvas, evoking a hauntingly beautiful atmosphere that lingers long after the controller is set aside.

The characters, with their depth and genuine emotional resonance, etch themselves into memory. Amicia and Hugo's journey is not merely a quest for survival; it's a heartfelt narrative that explores the depths of sibling bonds amidst adversity. Each character encountered along the way adds layers to this rich tapestry, leaving an indelible mark on the player's heart.

However, if there's a minor setback, it's the game's length. While the adventure is immersive and engaging, the brevity of its duration might leave some craving for more.

In conclusion, despite this small constraint, "A Plague Tale: Innocence" remains an absolute gem. Its compelling storytelling, seamless gameplay integration, breathtaking visuals, and unforgettable characters make it an experience worth cherishing. I wholeheartedly recommend this game to anyone seeking a captivating journey through a beautifully grim world.

149986416.review:
A Plague Tale: Innocence is an underrated great linear stealth-based game. The gameplay could feel repetitive but the level design is brilliant and they don't feel like copy-paste even though you are repeating similar activities. The characters are lovely and the game makes you care for some of them. 

Pros : 
+ Unique concept. This is a stealth game with rats and set during the 100 years war. 
+ Decent gameplay and puzzle. Sometimes you are doing repetitive things but because the level design is great they don't feel like copy-paste. For example, you'll repeat using a lantern to block the rats but you need to be creative on how you are going to block the rats to proceed. In addition, different chapters also give you different challenges. 
+ Pretty good story. At first, it is a little bit slow but once you get to the interesting part it will hook you up.
+ Good characters with interesting dynamics. I love the dialogue and some banter between the characters. I like Amicia, Hugo, and their friends. 
+ Great voice acting. IMO the VAs did a great job and not many people talk about it.
+ Great visual. This game is visually immersive and you'll feel the horror of living during a plague and being hunted.
+ Good soundtrack. The theme song always gives me chills. 
+ Good aim assist. It's very snappy and accurate. 

Cons : 
- Sometimes you are forced to be stealthy. I don't mind this but some sections punish you for not. Your main character (Amicia) will die in one hit if she gets hit.  
- The main antagonist is not bad but not unique or well-written enough like the other characters.
- If you are afraid of rats then you should NOT play this game.

149964116.review:
For me A Plague Tale Innocence started out really strong and went off rails towards the end of the game. One playthrough took me about ten hours. The setting of the world and characters were really well introduced and executed in the beginning. Having the protagonist accompanied by her little brother for most of the game was really nicely handled compared to other games in this genre. You aren't really slowed down by him and he doesn't get in your way and adds more to the gameplay than just being a talking sack of potatos.

Towards the end of the game the game feels like it tries to wrap up its story too quickly. Some plot points seem to just happen without any input of yours or for the sake of the story (for example a captured character just reappearing saying he freed himself or another character acting completely moronic just to drive the plot). Some of the companions you gather around you also get some backstory and history while others doesn't even get mentioned. In general towards the end of the game many aspects and plot points seem to have fallen victim to cut gameplay and story. One of the later introduced gameplay mechanics also makes one of the biggest threats more or less harmless by which the atmosphere suffers quite a bit. The villains also fail to portray any meaningful reason for their actions besides being evil.

The cut content seems to have been a good idea though, because the game rarely overstays its welcome. The pacing in general is really nicely done and you don't end up doing either stealth, fighting or puzzle solving for too long. Some puzzles can be a bit janky though and are weirdly strict about how you should solve them. In most areas of the game you can play how you like without the game punishing you for being aggressive or not playing stealth. 

Overall a pretty fun game in my opinion which loses its spirit in the last third of the game. To be honest I find the game to be too expensive. If you can get it on sale for half off it's a good deal.

149828128.review:
A Plague Tale: Innocence nos sumerge en una oscura y cautivante narrativa ambientada en la Europa medieval. La historia se erige como el núcleo de esta experiencia, manteniéndote inmerso y emocionalmente conectado en todo momento.

La duración del juego es un punto fuerte, equilibrando hábilmente el tiempo de juego para proporcionar una experiencia satisfactoria sin sentirse apresurada o prolongada innecesariamente. El juego no se extiende más allá de su bien ejecutada narrativa, ofreciendo una experiencia envolvente que se siente completa.

La jugabilidad es otro punto destacado. La combinación de mecánicas de sigilo y rompecabezas aporta variedad y desafío a la experiencia, manteniendo el interés del jugador en todo momento. Los elementos de la plaga y las ratas crean un ambiente opresivo y tenso que agrega una capa adicional de desafío y emoción.

Sin embargo, donde A Plague Tale: Innocence puede tropezar ligeramente es en la profundidad de sus personajes. Aunque la protagonista, Amicia, y su hermano Hugo están bien desarrollados y evolucionan de manera convincente a lo largo de la trama, algunos personajes secundarios pueden sentirse menos memorables y, en algunos casos, caen en el olvido a medida que avanza la historia.

En última instancia, A Plague Tale: Innocence es una experiencia que deja una impresión duradera. Su cautivante narrativa, duración bien medida y jugabilidad envolvente se combinan para ofrecer una experiencia de juego memorable. A pesar de algunas limitaciones en el desarrollo de personajes secundarios, esta aventura medieval es una experiencia que cautivará a los jugadores y los sumergirá en un mundo oscuro y desgarrador.

149613017.review:
(I dropped the game a little past the halfway point.)

A very mechanically rudimentary game - distract, sneak, loot materials, craft consumables (think The Last of Us basically without the shooting (yeah, oof)) - whose enjoyment will likely hinge greatly on your immersion in the story, its characters, and their performances. Unfortunately, none of these things managed to bite for me; no matter how good your models look or how tragic your premise is on the page, it is extraordinarily hard to achieve authentic and gripping storytelling when none of your characters have a third dimension or unique voice to them, your dialogue has all the flavor and texture of a spoonful of plain dry cornmeal, and all of your actors were so obviously forced to cold-read said dialogue in an isolated booth instead of being able to feed off of each other (as should be yet somehow still isn't the standard in story-forward cinematic games).

All of the work done here to get the audience invested is purely conceptual, and its core premise and backdrop are certainly novel enough in the greater video game landscape to potentially jolt a player into paying more attention than they otherwise might have. From that point forward though, there is very little to keep you in your seat beyond the fact that you already bought the ticket.

Don't be roped in by the promise of a resonant and captivating story based on its aesthetic or surface-level production value, because that's all you're going to get (and certainly don't anticipate any remotely compelling gameplay). Watch a movie instead. By and large, they do the required work much better than this, in a fraction of the time, for less money.

Alternatively, if you think you might be able to bring enough of yourself to the experience to enjoy it despite its clearly sub-movie-level delivery, resist the temptation to risk your money going in blind and at least watch a little bit on YouTube first.

149597088.review:
What the hell? I thought everyone said this was a masterpiece. 

You might think; "Wow a highly rated game set in medieval France during the plague! lets try it out!" I should have known where it was going after the dog gets ground up in seconds from rats like they were mutant land piranhas. It wasn't entirely clear this game is pure science fiction rather then historical fiction. There is no historical here at all, no subtle blend like AC 2. The veneer of immersion/reality is a wet piece of toilet paper and you might not know until its too late.

I'm not even gonna get deep into the particulars. The unbelievably dumb deaf and blind enemies who can't hear you right behind them but hear a rock 5 feet away and go HUH??, why does a 25 year old game like Tenchu (1998) have more alert enemies then this? These bad guys need to be in assisted living for the handicapped, I felt sorry for them. It is truly the WORST stealth I have ever seen in a game. The atrocious character writing, none of these people make you care about what they say, especially the boy Hugo who talks like what ChatGPT would sound like mimicking a 5 year old boy, the nonsensical character motivations- child murdering peasants cause "reasons", what inquisition is this based on exactly? Vampiric magical rat tornadoes, what the hell is going on?!?

About halfway you realize the plot has gone full retard. Your little brother has the T virus from resident evil complete with pulsating Albert Wesker veins, Salazars father is the big baddie. Chapter 14 you control  your uncanny valley 5 year old brother aka Hasbullah from social media fame walking through the legs of 40 scribes who have the awareness of lobotomized scarecrows. The rats leave behind Ridley Scott ALIENS xenomorph scum hives, unbelievably dumb and cringe, this is not worth $39.99.

However the worst part of all is the hype behind this game, part of an increasing issue of artificially elevated reviews. Why is this happening recently? I am honestly curious. Is it because you guys play just trash nowadays and the first 4/10 game makes you cry in excitement? Zoomers have never played a good game in their lives and it shows. IDK what Step 2 is but Step #1 is unfollow whichever shill influencer that told you that this was a mustplay/ amazing artpiece, because it aint.

P.D. Si estas aburrido y el juego esta en buena oferta compralo si no, no vale la pena!!!

The game looks absolutely fantastic both graphically and in regards to its art direction. The gameplay itself is lacking however except for some fun boss fights and the crafting mechanics felt unnecessary (for example: there's 3 levels of upgrades to allow the character to sneak more quietly even though I wasn't heard sneaking in the entire playthrough). 

The setting of the game is good which combines wonderfully with the good music and art direction but the story is pretty weak and its delivery even weaker. For what it was it was mostly enjoyable for its short runtime.

[h3] Good [/h3]
[list]
    [*]Looks very good graphically.
    [*]Creative setting/gameplay.
    [*]Impressive art direction, especially the bleakness of the plague infected cities/villages.
    [*]Good music.
    [*]Creative boss fights.
[/list]

[h3] Bad [/h3]
[list]
    [*]Crafting seemed completely pointless.
    [*]Gameplay challenges to simplistic/no challenge in general.
    [*]The delivery of the story wasn't the most terrible thing ever but wasn't great either. Especially noticeable in cut-scenes containing action in them.
[/list]

Ran great on a 4070 with 4k Ultra settings (~100fps) but encountered some stuttering and a couple of bugs.

148890418.review:
Not gonna lie, I have no idea why this is so hyped. It looked interesting and beautiful and definitely did not live up to expectations. The story is good and character writing is also good, also the graphics are beautiful.

BUT to the problem...

The game literally has 3 types of mechanics that repeat throughout the game. And there near to none variance.
1. You either have to sneak around and time your movements, or more realistically put: You run, stop for 2 seconds and run again. Nothing else. All these timing are always unrealistically convenient. You can also crouch at a guards heels with a torch withouth them noticing.

2. You have to disable/knockout guards in an order without too many of them ambushing you too quick. Really no challenge here.

3. You have to solve tunnel-type "puzzles" where you direct rats away and create a safe path. These are really solved by doing the only thing you can do. If there's a lantern, light it. If something can be dropped, drop it. If there is a guard with a light, either break the lantern to kill the guard or follow the guard in his light bubble.

Summary:
- The game is very tunnel-like, do what you can, and you'll beat the game with ease. Mechanics are very rinse-and-repeat.
- The graphics are definitely more horroresque but the difficulty in the game overall is closer to a children's game.
- The game introduces us to a more complex fighting mechanic which is never used again after the tutorial "boss" fight.

148553257.review:
[h2]An Absolute Must-Play Game[/h2]
Even though I initially got this game for free on the Epic Games Store, I decided to purchase it on Steam. There's just something about owning games on Steam that feels more satisfying. 🗿

A Plague Tale: Innocence is a wonderful journey through medieval France, filled with rats, danger, and exciting moments. It follows the story of Amicia and her younger brother Hugo, and their friends, on a rescue and arrest mission.

The game’s story is top-notch, and the characters, especially Amicia and Hugo, are likable. The graphics are gorgeous, and the music adds to the fun. The game is a mix of stealth, puzzles, and combat, which keeps things interesting.

I've unlocked all the Steam achievements for this game as I wrote this review, which made it even more enjoyable!

The key to this game is the relationship between the characters. Amicia and Hugo’s relationship feels genuine, and your companions aren’t just helpful – they’re essential to the story. The use of lights to keep groups of rats at a distance adds an interesting element.

In short, if you want a game with a strong story, wonderful characters, and enjoyable gameplay, this game is a must-play. It offers a unique and unforgettable emotional experience. I also want to express my appreciation for each and every team member who contributed to creating this amazing game❤️.

Now I can't wait to play A Plague Tale: Requiem, but I'm waiting for it to go on a huge sale. Can't wait to play it. Please put it on a huge discount this winter sale :( 

Thank you for reading this review 🙏

148514792.review:
I typically don't care for stealth games, I find them slow and boring, but this game does a good job of mixing stealth with some light combat and tying it together with a steady trickle of story. The story, is quite good, and it's set in a world that is both beautiful and creepy, peaceful and violent. It's also very sad, tragedy after tragedy, no one can catch a break.

The game as a package looks great. The graphics and character models, while perhaps not the perfect up close, are amazing when not under close scrutiny. But the design, style, ambient effects, and environments are what really make the graphics shine.

The music does an excellent job of setting the tone of each scene, and accents specific actions quite nicely.

I got 71% achievements at about 18-19 hours. I had considered revisiting areas to get the rest of the achievements, but because of the heavy emphasis on story, I found it too cumbersome. For the amount of time and the price tag, I'd say wait for a sale. But definitely get the game, it's really good and definitely worth it. I look forward to playing the second one.

Some issues I had. 

1. I found the limitation on backtracking to be frustrating. Sometimes I would leave a material right behind me because I was full, use it shortly after, attempt to backtrack to get it, to find myself blocked by a door, or once even an invisible wall. 

2. Perhaps this is nitpicky, but after a three week progression, I feel like the main character would have wiped the blood off her nose, but surely by the end of the game.

3. Often time, during regular progression, dialogue overrides other dialogue. Sometimes it's main story dialogue triggers being too close, or side dialogue overriding story dialogue. This could be timed better.

4. Despite having a custom made PC that was pretty top of the line after this game was made, I experienced some performance issues and couldn't run on max settings. Seems like an optimization issue, but I can't be sure.

148468846.review:
A Plague Tale: Innocence certainly has a cool premise and/or setting for it's story. but there's a bit too much trial and error for my tastes. With the swarms of rats it's understandable why, although I think a QTE system like Metroid: Dread for escaping the EMMI robots (That are pretty hard, yet completing them is possible) could have made Innocence a touch more forgiving without undermining the harshness of the setting too much.

Amicia's sling is one of the worst videogame weapons I've ever used and I wish she could have daggers/knives against human enemies like defense items in Resident Evil Remake (2002) or RE2Make (2019). There is sort of a similar system in there already, but it really takes a lot of your already meager resources to make and can prevent you from upgrading your equipment. RE style daggers could be scarce and still complement the existing method.

The later boss fights against [spoiler] Nicholas [/spoiler] & [spoiler] Vitalis [/spoiler] are also frustrating, because they will kill you in one hit, but unlike normal enemies they require slightly more elaborate attacks to damage them. The problem with this kind of trial & error gameplay is that it can lead to repeating certain sections over and over again and potentially dulling any emotional impact. It can also lead the player to making more mistakes from sloppiness induced by frustration of having to redo a section many times. Although this can be sometimes be attributed to skill issue and not the game itself. I wish games would stop boss enemies from repeating the same lines non-stop if the player has understood what to do, just failing at executing the winning tactic.

Case in point, the boss fights I mentioned in earlier in spoiler tags are preceded by a [spoiler] supporting character death  [/spoiler], which at time of writing, I thought happened for stupid reasons. I don't think [spoiler] Arthur would just delay making sure Nicholas is dead[/spoiler] and [spoiler] Rodric's death just seemed too self-inflicted and should have been preventable, if not for gameplay limitations [/spoiler].

The visuals and performance are stellar though, I maxed out the settings at 1440p with an RTX 2080 and other components of that era and only ever noticed a few hitches that while I would have liked to see gone, didn't affect my playing much at all.

In summary: Bleak setting that's beautifully realized, solid performance through the entire game, yet frustrating gameplay and story gets weaker by the 2nd half.

6.5/10, wait until it's discounted if you still want to buy it

Edit: I really wanted to like this more.

148261800.review:
TL;DR:

Great linear storytelling adventure stealth game, top notch music, very immersive, very unique. Gameplay is short and not the most fun I've ever had, but I enjoyed it.

Longer Version:

A Plague Tale is a stealth adventure game, featuring some very unique characters and concepts. The musical score is very noticeably amazing and stands out very well. The stealth aspect works well too. The characters are lovable and quirky. The voice actors were amazing, though I could never tell what accent they were going for, it was very all over the place.

The atmosphere and graphics are cool, there's a lot of areas that you will find screenshot worthy, but will quickly find that you're taking way too many to share publicly.

The stuff I didn't like are very nitpicky, there's more in volume but it didn't bother me as much as enjoyed more than disliked the game.

They intended to put in puzzles but aren't difficult, which I would've liked to have something more.

The game is very linear, doesn't allow for much creativity. Eventually you'll also acquire too many craftable item receipes and the earlier ones become very trivial towards the end.

148118718.review:
A pretty decent stealth and exploration game with some unique ideas.

Pros: 

-The story is surprisingly good and has a lot of twists and turns that I didn't see coming
-The combat is pretty interesting, though kind of simple
-Great music
-Puzzles are interesting and not too difficult
-The stealth is some of the best in any recent games and likens back to old Splinter Cell, which was highly enjoyable.

Cons
-Hugo is one of the most annoying characters I've ever seen in a video game. Especially in the first half of the game. He gets a bit more tolerable towards the end, but I still call him top 5 most annoying characters I've seen in a game. Kids being dumb for no reason is such an unlikable trait in media.
-The facial animations, or lack thereof, make the characters seem stone-faced and emotionless, which does not match the voice acting, which was quite good. It was really jarring to see.
-Some of the supernatural stuff in the game was not explained and leaves me confused. 
-There was a random dream sequence in chapter 13 that made no sense and was very out of place and never explained. 


A cool experience that was better than I was expecting and looking forward to trying the sequel.

147937472.review:
¡HAGAS LO QUE HAGAS, SIEMPRE QUEDATE EN LA LUZ!

Primero veamos la historia basada en hechos reales del juego. Arranca en el año 1348 siglo XIV en Francia, época en dónde estaba la Guerra de los 100 años, conflicto que se enfrentaron los franceses e ingleses en una de las guerras más largas de la historia. Asimismo, la Inquisición que tuvo un papel importante al haber reunido un gran poder y conseguido muchos fanáticos. Además, la plaga de ratas, las cuales infectaron ciudades, campos enteros y expandieron la famosa "peste negra" por la que fallecieron millones de personas.
 Finalmente, esta historia se encuentra acompañada con el factor fantasía, en donde aparecen poderes sobrenaturales y cosas misteriosas para darle más interés a la trama.

A Plague Tale Innocence ha sido para mi uno de los mejores juegos que tengo en mi biblioteca. Es un juego conmovedor y brutal en partes iguales, ha conseguido mantenerme atrapado durante las 10 horas que dura aprox.
En A plague tale nos ponemos en la piel de una niña llamada Amicia y su hermano Hugo que lo pierden todo en medio de la plaga que se cierne sobre la humanidad, y juntos deberán sobrevivir y buscar respuestas al "don" del pequeño Hugo.
La historia es una joya, brutal y desgarradora por momentos, pero también nos deja momentos bellos, de cualquier forma que no te dejará indiferente y no podrás parar hasta llegar al final.
Los gráficos y el sonido son más que aceptables, creando una atmósfera muy absorbente que nos mete de lleno en la aventura; no es de lo más increíble que hemos visto últimamente, pero cumple a la perfección en este aspecto.
En cuanto a lo jugable, es bastante entretenido teniendo un sistema de sigilo bastante bien implementado y unas cuantas mecánicas que se van desbloqueando a lo largo del juego que le dan un toque fresco en todo momento.
A plague tale es una de esas joyas ocultas que para muchos pasará completamente desapercibida ya que es un juego pausado y que se aleja de lo estándar, pero para aquellos que se atrevan a embarcarse en este juego, les aseguro que se van a enamorar de este juegazo. 
No se me ocurre ningún adjetivo que coincida para describir a la perfección todo lo que me generó este juego.

RESUMEN
LO MEJOR:
Amicia y Hugo
La ambientación
La historia
Los personajes secundarios
Los enfrentamientos contra los bosses
El final.

LO PEOR:
No tiene las voces en Castellano
Puede llegar a ser algo monótono tener que estar escondiéndose todo el rato, pero lo compensa con otras cosas
El combate final puede hacerse algo complicado, al menos para mi jaja

Quien no lo haya jugado debería al menos darle una oportunidad a ver que tal, porque es un videojuego precioso, fantástico y emocionante.

From start to finish, this game delivers an unforgettable experience that left me completely enthralled. Here's why I believe it deserves all the [positive review:

Captivating Storytelling: The narrative in A Plague Tale: Innocence is a masterpiece. It's an emotional rollercoaster that keeps you invested in the fate of the protagonists, Amicia and Hugo. The character development is exceptional, and you genuinely care about their journey in this harsh, plague-infested world.

Stunning Visuals: The game's graphics are nothing short of breathtaking. The medieval landscapes and villages, the horrifying swarms of rats, and the beautifully rendered characters all contribute to the game's immersive atmosphere. It's evident that the developers paid meticulous attention to detail.

Innovative Gameplay: The game introduces unique gameplay mechanics involving light and shadow to combat the relentless rat hordes. The combination of stealth, puzzle-solving, and action elements keeps the gameplay fresh and engaging throughout.

Emotional Soundtrack: A Plague Tale's soundtrack perfectly complements the game's atmosphere. It adds depth to the emotional moments and intensifies the suspense during perilous situations. The haunting melodies will stay with you long after you've finished playing.

A World of Intrigue: The game's setting, based on historical events, is both fascinating and disturbing. It immerses you in a grim and mysterious world, with a narrative that continually unravels secrets and conspiracies.

Well-Crafted Puzzles: The puzzles in the game are cleverly designed and provide a satisfying challenge without feeling overwhelming. They contribute to the overall narrative and gameplay without becoming a hindrance.

Emotional Impact: A Plague Tale: Innocence is an emotionally charged journey. It doesn't shy away from tough themes and moments, making the player truly connect with the characters and their struggles. It's a testament to the game's storytelling prowess.

Lengthy and Fulfilling: The game offers a substantial playtime that's worth every second. It strikes a perfect balance between narrative-driven sequences and gameplay, ensuring you're never bored.

147697816.review:
TL;DR Don't believe the hype.

I don't get all the hype.
This game has a gazillion 9/10 and 10/10 scores from various reviewers.
But it's just not that good!

There's a stealth part of the game - which is good
There's a lights/rats puzzle solving - which is also good
The animation of the characters is great. At least the main character.
But there is absolutely nothing that we haven't seen in other games before.
It doesn't invent some completely new genre.
It doesn't set any new standard for existing game genre.

You might think the story of the game is exceptionally good - but it isn't.
The main premise of the game is quite original.
But it is not explained properly.
And the dialogs are really not well written.
Most of the dialogs feel like a benign banter. The characters simply don't say anything meaningful.

There is a bunch of supporting characters, but they are more stereotypes of common supporting characters than real people.
The annoying little sibling... (e.g. Princess Leia)
The quiet giant with a heart of gold... (e.g. Chewbacca)
The random stranger with same gender and similar age, that will inevitably become the best friend stereotype... (e.g. Han Solo)
The villian... (e.g. Darth Vader)
The villian's boss (e.g. Emperor Palatine)
Typical cast of any adventure story...

About the game mechanics:
There is some crafting.
But it's very very limited.
And doesn't have a profound effect on the game.
Same for collecting resources.
Very few resources, and very limited use.

Now I'm not saying it's a horrible game, it's not fun, or that you shouldn't play it.
But it's a 7.5/10 game. 
I can even believe it can get 8/10 if I'm being generous.
But it's in no way a 10/10 game.
Not even 9/10.

147374732.review:
Very atmospheric and rich story about two siblings living in a time of plague. The game is stable, and I never encountered any bugs during my ~16 hours of play time (enough to finish the game without rushing it, however I gathered maybe 30% of available optional collectibles).

Tha AI of characters (pathing and behaviour) is good enough to keep you fully engaged in the story. The puzzle elements are not really difficult to figure out, so you wouldn't be stuck in any particular place for longer, and still feel that you achieved something. 

The story is mostly linear - no story changing decisions you can really make (besides dying of course) - however that's fine, as the game is telling you a particular story which is really worth following. There are some optional places you can miss if you rush, which may add some elements to the plot, but nothing very important, so you can just immerse yourself into story and play however fast you like.

The game is always nicely providing required resources whenever they are needed to push the game forward, so you don't have to gather everything, but still it could make some challenges a little easier if you are able to upgrade your equipment earlier. 

The saving system is "console style" - so saving automatically on checkpoints, which are frequent enough to not make you frustrated if you die. And you might lose your life quite often - arcade parts although not super difficult, still pose some challenge. Additionally - if you want to collect everything, you can replay any particular chapter (each of them isn't very long, so you shouldn't get bored if you "really need" to collect all the achievements).

The graphics are good, sound effects and music are raising the immersion bar, and voice acting is great. I can highly recommend this game, especially if you like story-rich, immersive and dramatic games - it was definitely a valuable 16 hours of playtime for myself.

147331633.review:
Introduction:
Upon diving into the evocative world of "A Plague Tale: Innocence", players are transported to a dark, historical, and deeply emotional journey through 14th century France. Asobo Studio, with their meticulous craftsmanship, have weaved a tale rich in both narrative and gameplay, resulting in an experience that lingers long after the final credits roll.

Graphics and Atmosphere:
Right from the outset, one of the most striking features of the game is its breathtaking visuals. From dilapidated villages, eerie forests, and medieval castles to the daunting waves of rats that shroud the environments in horror, every scene is depicted with cinematic brilliance. The lighting plays a significant role in setting the mood, with shadows and glows masterfully used to emphasize both the beauty and terror of the plague-ridden world.

Narrative and Characters:
At its core, "A Plague Tale" is a story about family, resilience, and coming of age in a world gone awry. The bond between the siblings, Amicia and Hugo, serves as the emotional crux of the game. As they navigate a hostile world, their relationship is tested, strained, and ultimately strengthened. The game artfully delves into themes of loss, innocence, and the lengths to which one would go to protect loved ones.

The supporting characters, each with their unique backgrounds and quirks, enrich the narrative. Their interactions and story arcs add depth, ensuring the story remains multi-layered and compelling throughout.

Gameplay:
While the stealth mechanics may seem familiar to fans of the genre, they are executed with finesse and seamlessly integrated into the story. Puzzles and challenges often require strategic utilization of the environment, especially with the unpredictable rat hordes serving as both an obstacle and a potential weapon.

Amicia's sling, a primary tool and weapon, evolves over the course of the game. This evolution not only allows for a more varied combat approach but also reinforces the narrative of a young girl growing stronger and more resourceful in the face of adversity.

Sound Design and Music:
The auditory experience of "A Plague Tale" is equally commendable. The sound of chittering rats, the distant cries of anguish, and the subtle environmental sounds all coalesce to create an overwhelmingly immersive atmosphere. Olivier Derivière's haunting score punctuates the narrative beats, elevating moments of tension, sorrow, and hope.

Conclusion:
"A Plague Tale: Innocence" is an outstanding achievement in storytelling, game design, and emotional engagement. Asobo Studio has not just given us a game but a deeply moving piece of interactive art that resonates with universal themes. For those yearning for a narrative-driven experience rich in atmosphere, character development, and emotional depth, this title is not to be missed. It's a poignant reminder of the power of video games to tell evocative, human stories.

147203018.review:
The game's introduction puts you into a good perspective of what's going on with how Amicia's storyline would progress. Although the entire storyline is linear, the story progression was entertaining and didn't feel like a drag! 

Gameplay-wise, at rare chances, AI/NPCs following you may accidentally fall victim to the "piranha rats", resulting in a game restart from last save checkpoint

Stealth is very easy, to the point it is laughable! For instance, hiding behind a pile of barricades results in the enemies forgetting your existence after a while LOL!

Combat is also very easy, you do not need much preplanning before you get into a fight. For reference, think of a difficulty level of 1/10 compared to Soulsborne games

Visuals-wise, amazing game for a 2019 video game, it feels like the in-game engine is cranked up to 11/10. However, the visuals by default at maxed graphical preset are hampered, thanks to effects from blurry TAA, fuzzy film grain, annoying chromatic aberration and whatnot! 

As the game is rather well optimised, MAXED graphical presets, averaged at 140FPS in 1920x1080 with a 5600x + 32GB 3800CL18 + 1080TI. I highly recommend running the game at a higher render resolution to minimize dithering effects from TAA or outright disable TAA and inject SMAA with Reshade along with AMD CAS or LumaSharpen to dramatically punch up the clarity of this game!

Sound-wise, the game integrates its soundtrack to align with the given setting. Upon encountering a pool of "piranha rats", the game starts to play eerie music. Another good use of its soundtrack is when you discover a mythological structure for the first time, the soundtrack fills in the "ambience" of what is before you

In summary, consider buying this game if you enjoy a linear story-based video game! The game is well optimised with some visual kinks but has good sound design and great storytelling experience!

As a particular enthusiast of linear, story-driven single-player games, A Plague Tale: Innocence gave me everything I wanted; A beautifully decaying world, likeable, reluctant lead heroes, and at least a few more rats than other games tend to deliver.

This is a bleak, but highly engaging stealth-action game that effortlessly draws you in to its violent vision of Black Plague-era France, providing a supernatural spin that delivers a truly unique concept. The blend of puzzle-solving, cleverly dispatching foes and manipulating hordes of rats to progress all comes together to make something that feels just familiar enough to satisfy, but overall novel and interesting. Frankly, this is one of the most fantastic debuts for a new IP that the gaming industry has delivered in recent memory, and to think that it came from a formerly unknown developer is truly impressive!

Asobo Studio is one to watch, if this game is any indication. Definitely give it a try if you want something gruesome, but incredibly satisfying!

146828682.review:
A Plague Tale: Innocence is a game that will immerse you in a dark and brutal historical period, where you will experience the struggles and emotions of two brothers trying to survive in a world ravaged by war and disease. The game combines stealth, action and puzzle solving in a gripping story that will keep you on the edge of your seat.

The game follows Amicia and Hugo, a noblewoman and her sick brother, hunted by the Inquisition and must face hordes of rats spreading the Black Death. The game's graphics are stunning and create a realistic and atmospheric depiction of medieval France. The game's sound design is also impressive, with a haunting soundtrack and voice acting that convey the characters' personalities and emotions.

The game's gameplay is challenging and varied, requiring you to use your wits and resources to avoid or defeat enemies. You can use Amicia's slingshot to throw rocks or other objects to distract, distract, or kill guards, or to start a fire that can scare away mice. You can also create different types of projectiles with different effects, like attracting rats, putting out fires, or creating smoke screens. You will also have to work with Hugo and other allies, who will help you access certain areas or perform certain actions.

The game's story is gripping and moving and explores themes such as family, loyalty, faith and innocence. You will see how Amicia and Hugo grow and bond as they face difficulties and dangers together. You will also meet other characters who will accompany or fight you throughout your journey. The game's plot is full of twists and surprises that will keep you entertained until the end.

A Plague Tale: Innocence is a game that I highly recommend to anyone who enjoys stealth games, historical settings, or emotional stories. It's a game that will make you feel, think, and care about its characters and its world. This is a game that deserves your attention and praise.

Very good game overall. Managed to 100% it in 12h, not super long but long enough I would say. The game is a satisfying experience with a good story and conclusion, doesn't overstay its welcome, and I am really glad to finally have played it.

The game looks great overall, very atmospheric, also along with great music. But you can also tell it is a budget game on some level, especially in some stilted animations. 

The game is an adventure game overall, I guess. You have a story, linear levels, and essentially "puzzles" to solve with stealth, combat, or actual puzzles. It is fun with many options you have, manipulating light, the rats, etc.

The story was also good and overall satisfying and everything is concluded well. Good characters too, some twists and turns. I thoroughly enjoyed it.

I had some small bugs, like characters getting stuck, but it always fixed itself. Also some of the checkpoints (no manual saving here) can be very annoying, somehow games still have not learned that a checkpoint before a challenging section and long cutscenes is really annoying if you have to keep redoing it... oh well. It did not happen THAT much, but some sections can be really tough, compared to most of the game.

Anyway, overall, I can only recommend this game!

146693715.review:
A Plague Tale: Innocence is a stealth adventure game following Amicia, the eldest daughter of a noble knight as she travels through France while protecting her brother from the inquisition and the plague of highly feral and infections rats. The mystery of the rats and their connection to Hugo - her younger brother is the main mystery of the story and it's very well executed. Story wise it's excellent and I would recommend the game for the story alone.

Visually, the game is also excellent with moments of great beauty and gory horror as you traverse through lush forests, cities, and rat infested streets. The only issue is the facial models and animations which isn't as good as the more static objects. The facial animations can be stilted and unnatural but this is fine as for the most part it works.

The music of the game really brings out the tension of stealth based game play as the strings really puts you on edge at times. The overall ambiance of the music produces a creeping vibe throughout the game. It feels like a horror at times.

As for the game play itself, it's serviceable. the stealth is a tad too forgiving with the enemy losing you almost immediately when they lose visual contact. The action part is simple too since the game gives you auto-aim and plenty of ammo. The last boss what a bit of a pain though.

Overall, the game was quite fun and the story excellent. I recommend playing the game even just for the story. 

8 out of 10: too many rats.

146678144.review:
‘A Plague Tale: Innocence’ is a visually stunning game, both from a technical level, but also due to its superb art direction. Certain cinematic moments mimic the color palette of an old portrait painting, creating truly captivating and beautiful shots. The soundtrack only adds to this experience, with string instruments juggling intensity and serenity between scenes. This is a cinematic experience, but that doesn’t mean its gameplay pales by comparison.

The game is primarily a stealth game, with mechanics involving line of sight, sound, light, and this games signature: rats. You’ll either be lighting the area to get passed the rats, or putting out lights to use them to your advantage. The Inquisition is the main threat – soldiers that search for you among the puzzles and scenarios you find yourself in. These soldiers range in weapon types and armor types, which both have varying affects on how you’ll approach the situation. Bows and spears can kill you at long range, while melee weapons are usually accompanied by lights, allowing the guards to bypass the rats. Helmets will inhibit your ability to kill certain guards, but the game opens up with options for helmets, torches, lanterns… And then they’ll come at you with shields and heavy armor, negating your options once again. This gameplay loop slowly gets harder, but as you progress through the game, you’ll get more options in how you can deal with these gameplay elements. While at the start it comes across as rather simple and formulaic, the game expands its areas and your abilities, giving you many ways to approach each scenario. 

Because the games length is rather short, it doesn’t overstay its welcome, with each act feeling unique and dense… There was never a point where I lost interest, and in fact I only got progressively more invested in both story and gameplay with each new act. 

However it’s not all good, with story elements impacted by poor facial animations and the occasional stiff deliveries from the English voice actors. This made certain story beats not feel as impactful, taking away from an otherwise good story. Nonetheless, this is minor, and overall doesn’t hurt the game as much as I initially thought it might. 

Funnily enough, the biggest reason A Plague Tale: Innocence is worth trying is because of the “rat tech”. The technology to create thousands of rats on screen, and have them dynamically avoid light, as well as attack anyone in the dark, later on creating visual spectacles you wouldn’t see anywhere else, is ultimately what sets this game apart. Accompany this with great visuals and music, and a decent story, and it becomes easy to recommend.

146675510.review:
A Plague Tale Innocence is a game I picked up on sale and thought I would give a try after hearing many positive reviews. I personally wasn't expecting much from the game i was expecting another slow paced story driven Last Of Us clone and im personally kind of tired of these games even though they are still enjoyable if your in the right mood. What I got was a game that exceeded all my expectations and even surpassed a few of them. This game is not perfect far from it in fact frustratingly so at times but it had heart and clearly a lot of passion which one me over in the end.
The story follows a teenage girl called Amicia and her younger brother Hugo who has some kind of illness and its up to you to find a cure for his illness. While being chased by the inquisition who seem to be very interested in Hugo while the hundred years war between France and England rages on around you and a deadly plague is causing disruption to your every step. 
Visually the game is excellent with many contrasting areas and moods like lush forests and fields on sunny days to dark fire lit city streets and rat infested caves. The character models are decent even though they all suffer from same face syndrome with just a different hairstyle which I found very distracting at times.
This is a stealth heavy game where you throw rocks and pots at metal to distract guards and get away as life is very hard if you get caught. Its not especially deep but it gets the job done and keeps you engaged enough. Fire plays a huge part in the game as rats are afraid of fire so many situations involve you finding ways to get fire around the area to make a safe escape. 
The story is good for what it is I especially liked the dynamic between Amicia and Hugo as they slowly grow from being so distant to truly relying on one another and that's what holds the entire game together and I truly began to care for Hugo and his safety and that's something the Last Of Us never managed to do with Ellie. Unfortunately the side characters aren't so great as I found them to be very annoying which i suppose is OK since they're just kids and they add some diversity to the game but I just wish they had a little more development rather than just really angry all the time. The villain is so forgettable too that I cant even remember his name and his final boss battle is laughably bad which is a shame because the build up to him is actually paced pretty well. The other bosses fair much better and require more strategy and problem solving to overcome. 
I enjoyed this game a lot and im really glad I finally played if you haven't played I urge you to do so. Just be prepared for a few irritating moments and a really questionable checkpoint system.
If you got to this point Thank you for reading

146668440.review:
A Plague Tale: Innocence is a remarkable video game that takes players on an emotionally charged journey through a dark and devastating chapter in history. Developed by Asobo Studio and published by Focus Home Interactive, this gripping narrative-driven adventure stands out as a unique and unforgettable gaming experience.

Set in 14th-century France during the height of the Black Plague, the game follows the story of Amicia de Rune, a young noble girl, and her younger brother Hugo, who must navigate a world ravaged by disease, war, and supernatural horrors. The narrative is one of the game's strongest aspects, weaving a tale of sibling bonds, survival, and sacrifice amidst the backdrop of a horrifying plague.

Graphically, A Plague Tale: Innocence is a masterpiece. The attention to detail in recreating the bleak and grim atmosphere of plague-stricken France is impeccable. The environments are beautifully crafted, from the picturesque countryside to the haunting streets of disease-ridden towns. The use of lighting and shadows enhances the game's atmosphere, immersing players in its hauntingly atmospheric world.

The character design and animations are equally impressive. Amicia and Hugo are well-realized protagonists, and their relationship is at the heart of the story. As they struggle to survive, players become emotionally invested in their journey, feeling the weight of their burdens and the love between them.

Gameplay primarily revolves around stealth and puzzle-solving, as players must avoid both the relentless Inquisition soldiers and swarms of ravenous rats that are central to the game's plague motif. The game introduces new mechanics and challenges throughout its runtime, keeping the experience fresh and engaging. Amicia's sling, used for both combat and puzzle-solving, is an intuitive and versatile tool, allowing for a satisfying blend of action and strategy.

One of the game's standout features is the use of swarms of rats as a gameplay element. The swarms are both a threat and a resource, offering opportunities for creative solutions to obstacles and enemies. The way the game uses these swarms to create tension and atmosphere is nothing short of genius.

The sound design and music deserve special mention for their ability to enhance the game's immersion. The eerie sounds of rats scuttling, the whispers of the wind, and the unsettling ambient music all contribute to the game's haunting atmosphere.

While A Plague Tale: Innocence excels in many areas, it's not without its minor flaws. Some might find the pacing a tad slow in certain sections, and there are moments when the AI of enemies can be predictable. However, these minor issues are easily overshadowed by the game's overall strengths.

In conclusion, A Plague Tale: Innocence is a compelling narrative-driven experience that combines outstanding storytelling with stunning visuals and atmospheric design. It successfully transports players to a grim and emotionally charged world, where they must rely on their wits and courage to survive. This game is a testament to the power of storytelling in gaming and stands as a must-play title for those who appreciate deeply immersive and emotionally resonant gaming experiences.

The game has sort of a cool story. Your characters are fun, and develop some cool personalities in your time with them. I think on this side, the story is quite good. The voice acting was very good. I also thought It doesn't really flesh out the villains. I felt myself wondering what Vitalus wanted, and who he was.. The story just was left too empty on this side.

The gameplay was just ok IMO. The radial wheel doesn't stop or slow time, and radial wheels are never precise when trying to zero in on what you want. The combat sequences are just ok. There's always resources laying around to craft upgrades, and ammo.

The only bug I encountered is a broken achievement for crafting 100 ammo. The game ran very well for me. There's quality there, and that's very good. No frame drops. No dropped inputs, which is far too common these days. It's a good game for the the $8 I paid for it.

146607383.review:
Plague Tale: Innocence is an underrated gem, and I am writing this review retrospectively after having also played Plague Tale: Requiem, which I consider a masterpiece. In short, you have to play both games in succession to experience the full brilliance, but Plague Tale: Innocence does stand on its own merit in many aspects.

Great graphics, which hold up even at the time of writing this review. A great cast of characters who you can truly grow to care for throughout the game, each with their own considered purpose in both story and gameplay. Fantastic pacing, where the game will gradually introduce new mechanics to always ensure there's a new and interesting approach to tackle the next segment. Beautiful linear level design, with enough of a semi-open world feel to house interesting secrets without any fluff. Great old school puzzles, which I miss in games nowadays. Intricately woven story and gameplay, that really immerse you in the world. And in my opinion, one of the best female protagonists since Ripley.

Fantastic game.

Final score: 88/100

146577321.review:
TLDR: Its a story first game second, play it to appreciate the sequel. The story and artwork are impressive in both the 1st and second game.. so play the first if you want to appreciate that. Take it for what it is and its enjoyable.. but if you like to explore.. then don't play this.. as you cannot at all explore in this game.

Pros
- Looks amazing
- Is an excellent story that depending on execution will make a good film, I don't think it has enough content to make a good TV series (which I hear is in production right now).
- I kinda want to learn how to use a sling shot, feels like a life skill that anyone should learn.
- Sound design and music, are well executed, some great use of dissonance and atmosphere.
- Finished in less than 20 hrs, so its a short investment in terms of game time, with some interesting ideas, unique (to me) combat style.
- There is a sequel which I am play and some of the cons I mention below are addressed, so its worth playing this for the short investment, just to get the backdrop and see the progression of the game development and efforts.

Cons (for me, and has it been improved in the sequel)
- Is entirely linear, which I understand is its design, but the more I play games that are linear, the more i realise I just don't enjoy them. There are no decisions to be made.. you just follow the story.. which is a good story I agree.. but I feel like I am just pushing it along.. I addition you are walking through a canvas.. not a world, very little ability to explore or reason to do so.. (So far this look to be the same in the sequel but too early to tell)
- Its not that hard (I am 44, so maybe its my age).. but I didn't really get that stuck and all the puzzles all though they build in complexity. (Sequel is harder, you can have more choice on how you progress, all be it linear, and you gain skills based on your handling of certain tools and weapons)
-  I have two kids and managing Hugo became a little annoying, I game to escape parenting :) (Hugo is still Hugo)
- The combat style although unique I got immensely frustrated with selecting what I wanted to use, craft and so on. (Some tweaks to this in the sequel which catch you out actually if you have just played the 1st game.. but they do make some sense and make it easier to select, once i reprogram my muscle memory to use the new navigation of inventory and crafting.)
- The crafting is odd, because very early on you can craft anywhere, which makes the concept of tool benches redundant 95% of the time.. and the points in which you can upgrade, are in fact very well set in stone, so although you have some choice in what you upgrade when its actually pretty limited (this reminded me of early games in the new Tomb Raider Series). (Undecided in this, it still feels a little contrived, rather than a choice.. but this might be again just its design)
- I died a lot, and it didn't matter if I did, because you just try again..(I would say this goes back to the story nature of the game over the game play itself) - this means you get disconnected from it.. and over time it becomes more of just an exercise to complete the game and tasks other than anything else. (Dying less, because I am skilled sling shot, but on reflection the dying still happens a lot and again, it doesn't really matter if I do, just try again)

I enjoyed this game a lot - it had been on my wishlist for a while. It feels like a cinematic experience, but much more immersive than something from Supermassive or Quantic Dream. The story itself was excellent, I would have liked to see a bit more bonding and screen time with some of the side characters, but I appreciate the tight storytelling for what it is. The main focus is on the relationship between the siblings, which I thought felt fairly authentic. Still some mysteries to be solved, but I do know there is a sequel.

The camera and controls felt a bit clunky, but for the latter I also never bothered to memorize what number shortcut corresponded to which ability until the final fight, so I'm not fully qualified to give it a knock on that. Though I stand by the camera being frustrating to handle, particularly if you have to multitask. 

I'm happy with my purchase - It took around 11.5 hours to complete for me, with me being somewhat crap at the stealth sections - particularly as the game went on it became less of a hassle to just kill everything. I wouldn't call this game hard necessarily, but there are some sections that are a bit finnicky and take some retries. The guard AI stretches believability in their blindness at times, but it was still a fun gameplay loop. 

Anyways, this game has been out for a while - most people who are considering playing this are probably like me who have known about it for a while and never got around to hitting the purchase button. I'd say, if the price matches what you are comfortable spending for a game of this specific playtime (I think i saw some people complete it in 9 hours, so I'd say 9-12 is accurate), then go for it. It's a fun game with plenty of action, good story and worldbuilding, while not just making the player a passenger to a glorified movie.

146529111.review:
I would first like to compliment Asobo and their team on a wonderful gaming experience from start to finish. For me, story-driven games are my bread and butter, and that's exactly what this game delivers. Not only this but the excellent interwoven quality of European history, with just enough fiction attached was artfully carried out. 

The Good: 
1. Scenery: exceptional detail was put in to create the medieval world of the Plague Tale. Right from the jump we're introduced to the de Rune family with a luscious forest backdrop and the goodness only continues from there. 

2. Characters: The voice acting was engaging and real, which I deeply appreciate. I was especially drawn in by the fact that, for whatever your politics are, how good of a protagonist Amicia (Charlotte McBurney) was. The story didn't attempt to paint men as evil, inept, or stupid as pop-culture often depicts us now-a-days. The characters struggled with real human experiences in times of crisis with such themes as: death of a family member, fights between siblings, guilt, revenge, etc. *Spoiler Alert* I really did feel my heart strings being pulled with regards to whether Amicia, Hugo, and Beatrice (Katherine Pageon) would, after all of that struggle and strife, make it out of that ordeal alive. Excellently crafted characters. 

3. Plot: A highly engaging tale for the true story-mode player. I am almost certain even a casual gamer would find enjoyment out of this game. The plot centers around the black plague/bubonic plague, which struck down 1/3 of Europes population. The fear created by the plague was a palpable theme, and an appreciation of the confusion and the reliance on religion to save those lucky enough not to "catch it". Beyond that, the main characters fight to simply survive, avoid capture, and keep their small band together proved to be a Herculean feat! 

Overall: 5 out of 5 stars. I hope you will love and enjoy this game as much as I did.

This game caught my eyes ever since the trailer came out.  The game can be completed within 10 hours, depending on how you play.  What is truly praiseworthy about this game is the story and immersive environment bringing the days of the Black Plague to life.  The graphics are absolutely beautiful, with every single rat rendered individually, reminding me of the days where PhysX was prominent in games.

The game mechanics really causes you to think about how to approach different scenarios.  Further upgrades would actually allow you to take on multiple enemies, if your trigger finger is quick enough.  And utilizing the rats to your advantage in the late game provides a sense of catharsis as you watch those pesky rodents tear your enemies apart.

I don't know how people feel about stealth games, but I would highly recommend this one for both gameplay and story.

146345563.review:
[h1] When Hugo referred to an aqueduct as “the ackyduck” I was ready to die for that boy! [/h1] I think games like this (single playthrough story-rich titles with strong audio design and voice-work, and a somewhat heavy/emotional storyline; like Hellblade: Senua’s Sacrifice) are quickly becoming some of my favourites of recent years and I’m now eagerly awaiting the sequels. 

Half walking sim, half puzzle adventure, A Plague Tale trade’s Hellblade’s combat sections for stealth sequences involving stationary and patrolling enemies - and similar to Hellblade - the gameplay alone probably won’t be enough to keep you engaged unless you also like the setting or the story. But luckily, A Plague Tale delivers on both. 

The game is beautiful, and is possibly the best representation of medieval Europe I’ve seen in a game. And even as emotionless and callous I am, this game got me to care about a little 5-year-old French boy. The character interactions are all rather endearing and well written, and the story is mostly great until the last few chapters.

146225956.review:
Another game were I wish there was a mixed review.
This game is basically a 11 hours long visual novel. It's completely linear, there are like 3 "decisions" you can make and all are due to achievements (ie. save the english soldier or letting him die) with 0 difference choosing either in the story or even in the chapter.

The flow of the story through "chapters" is pretty jarring, throwing in your face a few secondary characters and timeskips that don't let you "know" the the group. Yeah, I can understand that the characters may suffer if one dies... but I as the player don't care enough about them, so my only reaction can only be "oh, they killed one for dramatic points, rip".
To the players the secondary characters are noting but "the kid who is an alchimist genius for reasons", "the girl who lockpicks", "the brother of the girl who lockpicks" and "the boy who smashes doors and punches guards". Giving us a few moments between chapters, to learn more about the gang, their reasoning, their past etcetc. would have make me feel for them much more.

The opponents you face are exactly the same. There guards that you can OHK, guards that you need 2 hits to kill and guards that you have to break a lantern / extinguish the torch. The encounters are basically the same over and over, with just different archetypes around.

The puzzles are fairly easy (and if I say so, since I usually suck at doing them...) and solving them is rewarded either with a few consumables or a collectible. There are quite a few collectibles laying around, so you are rewarded for exploring everywhere.

The bosses have unique mechanics but they aren't too challenging. Since every error is followed by your death and starting from 0 again... it gets a bit tedious. Just as the levels, the boss fights are linear too. There is one way to win and you need to follow the exact same actions every time. The first time is... ok... but you probably won't be playing the game a second time. Tedious.

The story is nice, nothing new but with a few enjoying aspects. Not historically accurate enough to scratch that itch but not fantasy enough either. It flows quite well, very gothic. The gameplay is not good enough to be played a second time, though.

This interesting and gorgeous CGI animated movie was completely ruined by the occasional requirement of pressing buttons to keep it playing.

Wait... it's a game?

Having turned off the UI for an immersive experience, I became obsessed with trying to find ways for my little brother to "accidentally" die; being told every few steps where everything is and how it might be useful...

Being teleported to a checkpoint I didn't reach after dying trying to get there, was a herd of bullocks.

Look at the pretty pictures, walk the line, do as you're told and do not engage brain.

146135566.review:
[b]To start:[/b] Protect a literal demon child.

[u]The Positives[/u]
+ A grim yet cinematic depiction of 1348 France with two siblings at the forefront.
+ There are no alternate paths or choices, instead it embraces being linear—backtracking just isn't possible.
+ The stealth, of which there is a lot of, is at times challenging, but satisfying once figured out.
+ The mechanics involving the swarms of rats is definitely the highlight—avoiding them or using them as a weapon, it feels unique.
+ Being heavy on narrative, there's a lot of voice acting and the performances are excellent.

[u]The Negatives[/u]
- Controls are finicky and not the best, sometimes seeming unresponsive.
- It’s odd to say, but the game is draining—might be all the trial and error due to sequences expecting precise timing, a sort of “do it perfect or else”.

[b]To end:[/b] That said, I don't think I'll ever want to play it again. Opinions are my own and reflect my experience.

146089298.review:
If you make a movie game then just commit to it and don't add crafting and collecting things. This makes the player think "I think the game wants me to go left... so let's go right first to see what's there". If you guess wrong then you trigger a cutscene or door closes permanently so you can't go back and see what you've missed. It's not even about FOMO, it's just playing the game for the first time you don't know how hard the upcoming levels will be so you might need all those materials for upgrades. It ruins the immersion, sometimes instead of going forward as fast as possible (e.g. through a battlefield full of bodies) you will walk around checking if there's something to pick up. Anyway, in the end you can beat the game without all upgrades and if some encounter requires specific projectiles then materials for them will always VERY CONVENIENTLY lie somewhere close.
Other than crafting it has another thing that's in almost every game nowadays - the idiotic hiding in tall grass. Yeah I'm sure walking in it and trampling it wouldn't make it obvious that someone is there and make way more noise.

It has some very odd design decisions:
You can't run with a torch whenever you want, only when the game lets you, this is to make you solve puzzles in the exact way devs intended when in reality you could just sprint and solve it in an easier way

Main character can't go over a wall or a fence without dropping the torch/stick

If you put it in a torch holder and get on some elevation, you can't retrieve it. Why? Just crouch and reach for it.

You're supposed to get rats to focus on meat/animals/humans so they ignore you but it works only on scripted meat that you can drop with your sling and living npcs. There are moments where you're surrounded by dead bodies of animals or humans and rats ignore these but if you kill an enemy then they will start eating him. Why not just eat all the other bodies? It makes no sense.

Also it's funny how they made it so Amicia can't even pick up a knife, a sword or a bow and only has her sling to defend herself to make the character seem defenseless and more grounded in reality, not some killing machine like Lara Croft but... she can easily kill enemies with headshots from that sling. That makes her a scarier enemy than most video game protagonists, I think it's the opposite of what they wanted to achieve.


The story is supposed to be the highlight of the game but it's nothing special. I was hoping it will be grounded in reality but it turns into supernatural stuff.

It looks good and has a good soundtrack but that's not enough for me.

146082378.review: Buena historia, pero demasiado corta. Me pase el juego en menos de 12 horas y eso que repetí varias veces algunas misiones. Vale la pena SOLO si lo compras en descuento, por su precio original hay juegos mas largos.

146074338.review: A short but beautifully atmospheric game that really draws you in.  Its stealth, horror, a bit of exploration and crafting... The only negatives I have is that a few of the checkpoints in the later game are poorly placed.  I died more than a few times in one spot and each time I reloaded, I do the same 5 min of gameplay before the event set-piece that should have been the checkpoint.  That, and the first real boss at the beginning of the third act is a pain in the ass, mostly because ammo switching/crafting is done without pause, and while this is not a big issue in the rest of the game, doing so while constantly moving in a prolonged action scene was a headache along with trying to figure out the exact thing I was supposed to do while juggling all the controls.  Its just a bit of "in the deep end" moment.  The other 90% of the game was brilliant.

146070109.review:
It is painfully obvious this is yet another game designed for consoles, and the inferior controllers so common among them.

I have no idea how this game was rated so highly. It is a nice story, decently told, but it is barely a game, in that it is barely playable.

The little brother in this story is more annoying, and far less useful, than the whiny son in God of War.

The mechanics are slipshod and frustratingly unresponsive at the best of times. The RPG elements and combat are a sad afterthought, like this was intended to just be an interactive story, but the Devs were told to make it a game so marketing could earn their paychecks.

The forced nonsense (Oh no, drama!) and the constant "Wait, you are not allowed to move, or look, or check your inventory, while we force feed you this bit of information we couldn't be bothered to work into the story...) moments are maddeningly game-breaking.

The lack of a mini-map wouldn't be an issue, if the half-baked mandatory actions had hints or tips...  Note for Devs: That doesn't make the game better, or the puzzles more intricate, it just makes the game more annoying.

The only saving grace was the sale price.

Story: 6/10
Visuals: 7/10
Atmosphere: 7/10
Mechanics: 2/10
Combat: 1/10
RPG elements: 1/10
Puzzles: 3/10

Overall 4/10, and not something I would recommend to anyone who actually likes to play games. 

On the other hand, I wouldn't hesitate to recommend it to those poor souls who actually like TellTale games.

145879433.review:
The story is not as great as it's being praised for. Lots of nonsensical decisions, emotional plot points are undermined negating all potential growth for the characters, characters have little to no investment of motivation for their actions, very ambiguous on why characters do what they want. I would go into it more, but I don't want to spoil it too much. I think my biggest issue is Hugo gets a pass on growth. There's a lot of opportunity for him to lose his innocence like the title implies, but it's undermined horribly. Amicia has a better arc, but it's also undercut largely by Hugo's actions and his growth being undermined.

The first arc and atmosphere are great, but about a third or half way through the game crashes hard. Fine enough, get it on sale, but it was about as "meh" or "mid" as it gets. That's at best, at worst it's a solid disappointment.

Also you can't through rat beyblades in and expect me to take your story seriously. I was laughing through the final hour.

145835710.review:
The writers, who are clearly a team of talented torturers who studied at the feet of great masters of piquant suffering, have managed to turn the Black Death into a superhero origin story. This delightful trauma conga comes complete with not one, but TWO 'evil opposite' starter villains, for both protagonist and deuteragonist: the clanky idjit who lights himself on fire for Amicia, and the bad touch creeper in the fancy miter for Hugo. 

Around the cart-pushing bit in chapter 16, the phrase 'shmup puzzle' came to mind, and I needed a break. I feel that whole concept, in keeping with the legacy of French misery, really lived up to esprit De Sade. Those parts--the cart, the final boss fight, you know the bits I'm talking about, the ones everyone had to restart three or more times because what in the absolute F**K--made me really feel like a little french girl. One stuck in a pub with a lot of Millwall hooligans, after their lads had just had a right kicking on the pitch and their tab has been cut off.

Besides those bits, though? Full marks.

145803039.review:
A Plague Tale: Innocence is a game about how to deal with rats. Meaning both the rodents AND French people! The avalanche of rats is amazing technology, the story is interesting, soundtrack is stellar, French voice actors and actresses did a helluva job etc. Everything is amazing, except for one thing.

The gameplay is ass. Now, while they give plenty of tools and the stealth sections are mercifully short, it is often hard to figure out what the designers want the player to do. Much of the game is redoing same sections over and over again until you get it right. Or maybe you are not a dumb person, unlike me, and you will have a great time. Who knows.

Overall, despite the frustrating gameplay, I would say Plague Tale is worth experiencing. It is different than most modern games and a breath of fresh air. Hopefully the sequel has some changes in the gameplay, or it too will have a side odor of a wet fart. 4/5

Rats are terrifying at first but you will actually get used to them, really. 

Pros: Surprisingly good graphics, better than most game at a similar price, definitely a visually appealing game. Refreshing plot line and setting with good depth, the voice acting was quite unique. Stealth game play was well made, however combat is ridiculous if you don't play stealth, you would see man twice your height covered in full armor with weapon chasing you around a table like two kids playing.

145478720.review:
Looks like i am the minority here but i found this game quite unbearable to get through by the end. 

A number of reasons:

1. Characters are boring and 1 dimensional, the characters you meet along the way just got annoying to me and honestly I didn't care for them a single bit, if one of them died it sparked no emotion in me because of how one dimensional they are. The same goes for the main villain, very cartoonish.

2. Voice acting, i came to this game after playing the last of us so i guess my expectations should have been readjusted, but i really didn't find any emotion behind there voices at some points. especially the mother.

3. Slow and boring gameplay, there really isn't any room to experiment, one small mistake can kill you instantly with a potential checkpoint that will set you back another minute or so. The stealth was your run of the mill throw a rock and move past. This game also had a habit of intentionally slowing the character down so that you cant run around and explore, just slowly walking for no real reason.

4. following on from walking slowly everywhere, the home base sections are just sooooo tedious, having to slowly trudge through this massive castle. Every time i was there i felt like i was being taken away from the story and had to talk to other characters that i really didn't care about.

The main issue i have with the game is a big one though, considering this is a story focused game. The story just never hooked me, it didn't hook me at the beginning and i was waiting till the very end for it to surprise me, but it never did. 

However this game isn't ALL bad the good points are:

1:Gorgeous environments, basically every level is packing with detail. all towns look dark and grim with hanging corpses and rats eating bodies. Then you might go into a luscious forest with flowers and lots of foliage. I wish i was allowed to explore these areas more.

2:The rat system, the rats are a very cool feature, watching hundreds of rats swarming to get you or going through them with a torch is something i really enjoyed.

Other than that i cant think of many good things about the game.

Although i really didn't enjoy this game, i'd recommend people to play the first 2 hours or so and see if you are hooked with the story. If you aren't hooked, just drop it. It really isn't worth how boring and frustrating the game is.

145424083.review: This game is amazing. If you enjoy survival stealth with a vibrant and well put together story, this game is a must.
