Decent game with decent graphics and a cool concept. I honestly did not disklike the game, just didn't love it and I think it is a bit overhyped. Feels like a triple A take on a browser puzzle game, both in a good and a bad way.
The good: It actually feels like a triple A game in terms of graphics and progression, and the cheesy puzzles are adapted in a way that makes them feel kind of not too boring.
The bad: Extremely linear and ckblocking storyline where you have to follow exactly the path the game laid forward before you. If you do anything outside the precisely planned path, you will die or be blocked by invisible walls or be unable to jump up a height you usually can jump if the game decides you are allowed to. I have loved somewhat linear games like dragon age origins before where they still made you somewhat feel like the world was open even though it wasn't. This is the opposite. You really feel stuck in a cage at times in this game. 

Also, sometimes there are like two paths, one going towards loot, and one going to the next checkpoint, and it's not obvious which is which. If you choose the checkpoint, you are forced into the next step of the game, no way to go back get the loot. Even if it's just a door you go though: can't go back. That is stupid and infuriating.

145235979.review:
SUMMARY: A fantastic story-driven game that has enough action to keep you engaged.

PROS
+ Simple, yet engaging story progressively unfolding as you play.
+ Fun game mechanics that aren't difficult to master, but leave enough of a challenge to keep you on your toes at times.
+ Characters that you can really connect with over time. Many touching moments that make you smile.
+ Not punishing, but definitely a few moments that will surprise you by the challenge.
+ Short and sweet. I was able to beat this game and do 74% of achievements in ~13 hours of gameplay. Honestly, if it went on longer,  I probably would have started to lose interest. I think this was the perfect duration to tell this story.
+ The acting was top notch. I felt the emotions invoked in each of the characters and it really immersed me further into the story. Bravo to the writers and the actors.

NEUTRAL
- The game is a story-driven game, which means that it's quite linear in its path. You're not left guessing where to go or what to do; rather, there are clear indications that you have a single path you can proceed on. Note that this is somewhat remedied by including challenges by finding "gifts", flowers, and relics that represent the history of the time this story is told. To find these items, you do need to deviate a bit from the path in front of you (where it allows).

CONS
- The ending was sweet, but I wouldn't have minded a bit more to it. However, I have yet to play the sequel, so perhaps that's what I need to go to.

145102052.review:
This is a hard one to review. I wish there was a "neutral" rating because the game isn't bad by any means, but it falls short of being a great one. The superb graphics in combination with a great narrative make for a very tight, cinematic experience. The gameplay itself is nothing to write home about since it is very much on-rails and with minimal freedom as to how you can approach problems. There is usually only one way of getting past an obstacle. That alone would be entirely forgivable if the game fully focused on the one thing it's doing well and that's stealth.

Sadly, the pacing changes entirely toward the end of the game, and what was a narrative heavy stealth survival experience becomes a fantasy action game where lightning reflexes are required to progress. The final boss fight was particularly egregious and I felt that the game broke character with the previous 95% of the experience. I won't spoil anything but the mechanics are very reminiscent of the way boss fights were being done 20-30 years ago: punishing timings, no mistakes allowed and having to redo difficult sequences if you slip up at any point. It makes no sense that the developers would want to punish the player in this way after sticking with their creation for 12+ hours. It felt like a slap in the face for no good reason. Someone who stuck with the game until the end certainly didn't do so to be abused for their trouble.

In a nutshell, the last 1-2 hours are pretty weak and the final encounter is executed so badly that it ruins the game for me. It is unfortunate because the game is amazing in many ways otherwise.

144668209.review:
▮▮▮▮▮▮▮▮▯▯ Historia
▮▮▮▮▮▮▮▮▯▯ Gráficos
▮▮▮▮▮▮▮▯▯▯ Jugabilidad
▮▮▮▮▮▮▮▮▯▯ Apreciación personal

Al comenzar a jugar esta entrega debo decir que no sabía con qué me iba a encontrar. Me dejé guiar por las buenas reseñas y el conocimiento previo de que se trataba de una historia un tanto corta de una hermana con su pequeño, y me alegro de no haber tenido idea ni de qué se trataba el juego, ya que una vez que me di cuenta me vi bastante asombrado.

▮ La historia de este juego es bastante particular. Lo que comienza siendo un intento de supervivencia entre 2 hermanos solitarios dentro de un mundo de podredumbre se convierte en algo mucho más grande. Conocemos varios personajes que se harán dueños de una pequeña parte de la historia, pero el concepto fundamental es proteger a Hugo. Hugo es este pequeño hermano inocente, lleno de sentimientos nuevos encontrados que no sabe cómo controlarlos ya que jamás ha conocido el exterior, y esta vez se ve obligado a hacerlo ante un mundo devastado. La historia se divide en capítulos, cosa que agradezco muchísimo y me permitió separar mi sesión de juego por episodios y no hasta el hartazgo. Esto quiere decir que jamás salía de la historia del juego yo, sino que le daba una conclusión al episodio y de ahí dejaba mi sesión para el siguiente día. En casi cualquier otro juego ponemos "Guardar" y dejamos al personaje en un lugar donde no sabemos si estamos por llegar a un giro de trama, un clímax sorpresivo o 3 horas de farmeo. Acá eso no va a existir, puesto que se divide por capítulos y la historia al ser tan corta es bastante nutritiva.

▮ Gráficamente es un juego muy completo, habrá dado que hablar cuando salió en 2019 con estos gráficos tan tétricos y oscuros. Se vio bastante bien, simplemente algunas texturas eran visuales pero no físicas, por lo que al comienzo del juego me puse a atravesar hojas de árboles y estas desaparecían dentro de mi personaje, sin alguna animación particular. Sí, soy quisquilloso porque algunas entregas de años previos han dejado el listón demasiado alto.

▮ En cuanto a su jugabilidad, se hace entretenido. No será la gran cosa, pero está bueno. Nuestro personaje maneja una gomera a partir de la cual arroja 9 proyectiles distintos, por lo que debemos ir cambiando a medida en que vayamos necesitando diferentes cosas o acciones a fin de vencer a los enemigos que se van presentando. El tema está en que el movimiento es bastante limitado, no es que sea exactamente lineal el camino a llevar a cabo para continuar, pero la verdad que lo es en su amplia mayoría. La exploración es prácticamente nula, prepárense para adentrarse en algo que se caracteriza por su flamante historia.

▮ Apreciación personal: no sabía con qué me iba a encontrar y salí muy satisfecho. Me dieron muchísimas ganas de jugar la segunda parte, pero no voy a ser apurado y voy a esperar una oferta. Si bien en un principio vamos anticipando qué podría suceder, me sorprendió un poco cómo se tornó la historia al final. Quizás fue algo abrupto, pero al serlo también fue poderoso. Cómprenlo, no se van a arrepentir. La historia se les va a hacer corta porque terminé sintiendo que necesitaba más cosas de este mundo, sentimiento que voy a reprimir cuando me compre el siguiente juego.

144401672.review:
I've been wanting to play this game for a while now, and when it went on sale for half price, I couldn't resist. After finishing the campaign, I'm so glad that I bought it. This game has been an incredible experience, one that I won't be forgetting for a while.

[h1] The Visuals [/h1]
A Plague Tale is a dark and gritty game, but also a colourful and beautiful one. The visuals do well to deliver on those aspects, with a huge variety of locations ranging from creepy and mysterious to magnificent and gorgeous. There is a huge attention to detail with each of these levels that encourages you to explore. Even the characters are interesting to look at, as they are given the same level of attention, both in their looks and animations.

Everything about the setting feels authentic, and that is greatly thanks to these visuals. My only complaint in this department would be the rats. They look terrifying, but when they chase after you and defy the laws of physics, it does ruin the immersion a bit.

[h1] The Story [/h1]
"I did it for him, and I'll kill you again if I have to. I'll kill all of you!"

I don't want to talk about the story too much as I don't want to head into spoiler territory. It is the year 1349, the start of the Black Death in France. You play as Amicia De Rune, and are tasked with keeping your younger brother, Huge De Rune, alive. Hugo was born with a unique disease that has kept him isolated his whole life. When the plague arrives, everything begins to fall apart as you are both hunted by the Inquisition.

If I talk more about it, I will spoil something. It is best jumping into it blind. All I can say is that the story is probably one of the best video game stories I have ever experienced. It's dark, it's intense and it's emotionally gripping. The stakes get higher and higher as new characters are introduced. The writing quality is excellent, with each character bringing something to the story. There's a reason this game won the story rich Steam award.

[h1] The Gameplay [/h1]
Although the gameplay is rather simple, it's quite diverse in how you can approach certain situations. The game is primarily a stealth game, meaning you should avoid the enemies. You are only children after all. However, if you want to kill the enemies, most situations will allow that. You are equipped with a handy sling that can be used to either distract enemies or kill them.

However, defeating some enemies requires more than just slinging a rock in their faces. As the game progresses, you are introduced to different types of projectiles. These can be crafted at any time, given that you have the right ingredients.

Crafting is a major element in this game. You can find plenty of ingredients dotted around the maps, which encourages the player to explore more. These types of projectiles range from a substance that can melt enemy soldiers' helmets to fire bombs that can kill rats. Each projectile has its use, and are unlocked to the player at the appropriate times, which helps keeping the game feeling new and refreshing.

As well as crafting projectiles, the player can also craft upgrades for themselves. These types of upgrades range from an increased carrying capacity to faster reload times for your sling. Each upgrade is important so collecting any materials you can find is essential.

As I mentioned before, this game can be an intense game. There are plenty of sequences throughout the story where one wrong step could be the death of you. There are two types of enemies. Soldiers, and rats. With soldiers, you have to be smart and tactful. With rats, you must ensure that you stay in the light and watch where you move. There will be times where rats will come out of nowhere, making you run for your lives. This is seen in the game's opening chapters. The game doesn't waste any time with getting you engaged.

My main complaint however, is relating to combat. In the moments where stealth isn't an option, the gameplay simply just consists of throwing rocks in peoples faces. This is very noticeable in the boss fights. It does vary up later in the game, but a sense of repetitiveness always lingers throughout these sequences.

[h1] The Sound Design [/h1]
I had to talk about the sound for this game, because it is incredible. The moment you load up the game, you are greeted with a beautiful main menu track. I knew I was going to like this game the first time I heard it. The soundtrack is consistently spectacular throughout the story. It instantly sets the mood of the level, and helps with the tension. Just listen to this!

The voice acting is top notch, especially for the main character, Amicia. The sound effects are all good as well, especially with the rats. As soon as you hear the ground rumbling, or faint squeaks in the background, you know there are rats nearby which, again, adds to the tension.

[h1]Final Thoughts[/h1]
All in all, an outstanding game. If you're looking for a story rich game, this needs to be on your list. It's an authentic, rich experience that will keep you entertai

Plague Tale: Innocence is an absolute gem that took me on an emotional roller-coaster. Right from the beginning, its captivating narrative and meticulously designed world immersed me in a harrowing journey of survival during the plague-stricken medieval times. The characters are so well-developed evoking their struggles, fears, and triumphs as if they were your own.

The game's unique blend of stealth, puzzle-solving, and storytelling kept me engaged at every step. Navigating through swarms of rats and unravelling the mysteries of a world in chaos is both thrilling and heart-wrenching. The use of light and shadows adds a layer of tension that keeps you on your toes.

Visually stunning and backed by a hauntingly atmospheric soundtrack, Plague Tale: Innocence is an unforgettable experience. Its emotional depth and well-crafted gameplay make it a must-play for anyone looking for a captivating narrative-driven adventure. Prepare to be moved and captivated by this dark tale of innocence in the face of adversity.

The presentation in this game is great. Probably one of the best realizations of black-death Europe in video game history.  The cutscenes are very pretty and feel like a well produced TV show. However that's about all that is very remarkable about this game.

The gameplay is middling. It consists of somewhat janky combat, average stealth gameplay, and unchallenging environmental puzzles. The story is interesting, but it is basically the same concept as the Last of Us with not as good characters. 

The best part of this game was just walking around and taking in the scenery. You can tell a TON of work went into how this game feels with the way the music is combined with whatever is happening on screen, and boy, a LOT happens on screen. I'd say the worst moments were when immersion was broken by some situations where I was unable to make choices I wanted to, like being unable to pick up a torch continue into a dangerous area after I put it on the wall.

For PC, there's also some bugs that crash the game and my computer. I ran into this about every 2 hours during my playthrough.

Overall, the devs did a nice job here, but it's clearly lacking in some areas. If you are a fan of games like the The Last of Us and the setting of medieval Europe, this is a game you should pick up on sale. Otherwise, I'd play The Last of Us first to see if this is the type of game for you.

143833269.review:
I don't think I've ever felt so much anger from such a beautiful single-player story game, which is why I want to review.
I wanted to like this game so badly and that was probably my mistake, I hyped it up too much for myself, because of course it ended up not being a game for me at all.
If you loved the game, that's obviously wonderful! My experience did not conclude to that result. To put it shortly-  I'm having a hard time understanding how this game is as new as 2019, because it feels at the very least like 2010.


The story is great, even thought I'm sick to death of religious plotpoints of any kind, that's inargubly a my-preference-thing. Either way, it's a solid and creative story. However it's also unfortunately part of why I'm so pissed. The mechanics of the game completely ruined the story for me. Heavy and sad plotpoints didn't make me sad even one bit, because I was fuming with annoyance over uncomfortable, unintuitive and seemingly inconsistent controls.
I will say that I'm not sure if some parts were buggy or if its my controller- that's could be likely, and maybe I'll try playing it on keyboard in the future, but even if I do, this was definitely NOT a game for me.

It's too much "Do it maticulously right or re-do it" and a LOT of that was time-based, either be fast enough- quickly grasp what you're even looking at, and if you've lost even a smidge of your bearings- Dead. OR be intentionally slow even though you have no idea if that's the better choice or not. (resulted in plently of re-do's for me, even when I did understand what to do. I never got a good grasp/sense of what the AI-characters understood and saw, or didn't.) 

I was constantly taken out of the immersion of the story because I kept dying- I kept dying because the controls never naturally came to me-in addition to the times I died because the script or direction fucked with my head and made literally no organic sense to me.

Nothing about "do it again and do it better" over and over and over, is fun or useful for ME personally, but that's what this game became. I only have the last fight left, and it literally hurts my head and makes me sad to even think about trying to finish, so I'mmaaaa... not do that!

There's plently of things I do like and appriciate about the game, but there's so many issues I have with it. Soooo, even though it might be as simple as this NOT being a game for ME and my brain specifically, just for my own sanity, I can't recommend it. At the very least, wait for sales. 39$ is crazytalk.

At some point I'll probably try the sequal, because the story feels new and creative enough, the characters feel new and creative enough. I've seen people say mechanics feel smoother in it, etc.

A Plague Tale: Innocence is an example of how engaging and immersive a game can be despite its linearity.

The visual side of the game is literally stunning. All locations and architecture are captured with incredible attention to detail. Lighting effects, characters, villages, cities, walls, atmosphere and thousands of rats together create a world that draws us into its medieval and dark environment with an unforgettable impression.

The main musical theme of the game is unforgettable, which is an important element that enhances the atmosphere and deepens the experience of the game. In emotional scenes, it increase the feelings of the characters and players, while allowing players to fully immerse themselves in the world.

Gameplay is designed to challenge our thinking. Hiding from dark threats, enemies, solving mysteries and strategic planning. This mechanic creates tense situations where you have to carefully plan your movements and choose optimal paths, because every detail can have a big impact on the journey.

A Plague Tale: Innocence is not just a game it is a work of art.

143762382.review:
played the game for 7hrs on my first go through a year ago, had other games I wanted to play at the time due to seasonal reasons - came back to it just a couple days ago, having opted to restart the game fresh so I know the story and what I had left off on.

game is really good looking, runs well (only had minor hitching in a singular, small area in one part of the entire game, probably due to a ton of fires around... was only in that spot for about 20 seconds anyways)
game plays slightly like walking sim very early in the game, but as the game goes on, you get a myriad of tools/craftables that really enhance the gameplay and made it much more enjoyable. the game also rewards you for exploring everything, as you'll find a lot of hidden materials scattered about which you use to upgrade your gear (I ended up having most things upgraded, but not quite; I got what I wanted anyways)

the game is EXTREMELY easy  - there are no difficulty settings in this game, it is static - I did die quite a few times though, admittedly, because the game usually is so straight forward, simplistic (and at times, hand-holdey) that the few times when it isnt, you get surprised and probably die. although there are quite a few intended strategies in this game, the tools you get in mid/near ending of the game gives you a variety of ways that you can personally approach it (you can stealth through almost the entire game, but I upgraded my gear and chose to be aggressive, killing many guards in my playthrough).

on the topic of the game being easy, the stealth mechanics are very forgiving, and might I say, too forgiving - at some parts of the game I could simply just run out of cover and into more cover when the developers had set up ways to divert guards - it is hard to get caught out unless you are playing ballsy (my weakness) or simply do not know where to go (my other weakness)

aside from the game being on the easier side, and the slower start, I did enjoy it very much. I liked the story mostly, I think my only qualm was the "twist" at the end with the main antagonist being so random, and slightly.. nonsensical? I didnt understand it fully; I only have theories as to why it came to be that way (which I cannot say without spoilers, so I wont), or, it is potentially answered in the sequel, which I have yet to play.

all in all, this was a good game, I had fun with it, and if stealth/exploration/strong character design is your thing, you will too.

143754680.review:
Solid Environment design and a strong narrative make this worthwhile. At times the dialogue seems too contemporary for the time period, but if you can forgive that the characters are endearing and memorable. 

Several times the gameplay got frustrating for me as the game takes away controls, limits camera, or forces the player to a very specific timer in order to progress. I don't like invisible walls and there are times where you'll hit one in combat or in the middle of an action sequence. You'll get what the devs are telling you after a few tries but it's frustrating to die a bunch just because you don't yet know the path of travel or pattern that's required to not die. In many ways that's the name of the game here: not dying. And for the most part it's fun. Don't get discouraged-- remember: Certain combinations of items will get you past. Don't be afraid to kill when needed to progress. Fuck archers, archers *are* in fact visible but they'll get ya from a distance-- if they can hit you, you can hit them. It's spotting them that can be tough.

Often the game will give you a distant audio cue or a you've-been-spotted FX screen blip but you won't know the direction. You will, in these moments, notice that the camera rotation is very slow. At times you'll lose control of the camera and when you get it back it'll be in a new spot. Fine if you're in a look-and-see mode of play but if you're in the middle of action, be careful when you let the game "look around." You can ignore those prompts.

Sometimes the NPCs and characters are kinda wooden, but ignore that and empathize with their plight and you're gold.

It's a linear narrative adventure game with crafting, stealth, and action. It's not a stealth action game, so don't expect it to be one and you'll likely enjoy it. Just watch out for pesky, "what are you forcing me to do in this sequence?" moments.

It's short at 10-12, IMO worth it or wait for a sale.

143604240.review:
What a phenomenal game. Everything about it was absolutely brilliant - from the voice acting, musical score, visuals and narrative, all the way to the pacing and atmosphere. I'm a sucker for story-driven/medieval/horror games but this one absolutely takes the cake.

A Plague Tale: Innocence follows the story of Amicia de Rune and her younger brother, Hugo, as they traverse the plague-ridden, war-torn countryside of 13th Century France.

I automatically felt connected to the brother/sister duo from the get-go, as I also have a younger brother and could see a bit of myself in Amicia. The siblings' relationship started off a bit rocky, as Hugo had been isolated from the outside world his whole life due to a mysterious blood disease. Amicia, on the other hand, felt neglected, as her mother was always preoccupied with Hugo's care. I loved the subtle hints of jealousy through some of the dialogue between Amicia and Hugo. As you progress throughout the story, you can see the change in dialogue as their relationship improves.

Charlotte McBurney did an outstanding job at voicing Amicia. Bought into every emotion she portrayed through her voice. I felt her pain, fear, anger, sadness and joy... Fantastic talent! One of the chapters that stood out specifically, was Chapter XIII - [spoiler]the one where she hallucinates after Hugo ran away. That whole segment of her walking through the tunnel of dead bodies, frantically screaming for Hugo not to follow Lord Nicholas - I got chills.[/spoiler] You could hear her agony and desperation, it just felt so real. Not many games can succeed in making me feel that way.

The fact that this wasn't nominated for best musical score is a crime. The last time I came across a score that managed to be as incredibly emotional, beautiful, horrifying, chilling, heartbreaking as this, was with The Last of Us. The Mystical Castle and rat theme specifically were very ominous and creepy. An absolute masterpiece of a game and a score.

Overall, A Plague Tale: Innocence was an extraordinary experience. As someone who generally plays FPS games, it was a nice change of pace to play a game with minimal combat and to rather just enjoy the story and appreciate the stunning visuals. Undoubtedly one of the best games in recent years, especially history- and originality-wise. I fell in love with this game; a game based off of rats, stealth and survival is honestly such a cool premise. I'm looking forward to playing its sequel.

143591972.review:
The high points of this game is the story and the voice work of Amicia's voice actress, but sadly the game is bogged down by tedious stealth segments with little to no player agency. Everything is laid out like a puzzle that must be tackled and every time you are given the needed amount of items to get through each section. Add to that clunky control schemes and scripted sequences that cannot be resolved in any other way than the way the designer intended it and any deviance from that leads to NPCs or Rats not behaving as they should, because they are waiting for a scripted trigger to resolve the "obstacle".

The upgrade system is almost entirely pointless and just comes across as adding mechanics for the sake of adding mechanics, with little thought put in to it.

But while the story is largely the high point of the game, it's not without issue, like the wholly unsatisfactory conclusion to Nicolas. He was a central figure of the plot but when the confrontation finally arrives, [spoiler]he's quickly toppled by Lucas, whom then proceeds to smash his helmet in with a huge rock in a cutscene, which seemingly has no effect in the next cutscene where Nicolas gets up again and cuts down Lucas, sloppy and cliche way to kill off a supporting character as well. Then follows a tedious dance around a small arena before his ultimate demise.[/spoiler]

Similarly the final chapters of the game has issues, such as the Final Fantasyesque boss fight, where you don't even get to use your sling much, the item that has been your mainstay throughout the story. You cannot even use the sling to extinguish the fires in the final fight, because god forbid you continue established precedence for gameplay mechanics.

Following the final fight you are presented with rolling credits, followed by a small final chapter and yet another credit scene, leaving the ending of the story open and without a satisfactory conclusion. The rats, the biggest point in the story, just went away, the end.

I bought this game on sale for £7 instead of its £35 base price that seems unjust for how short the game is. however if you look past the price you'll find a hidden gem of a game that will leave you wondering how it was left so under the radar. 

(STORY) Amicia and her younger brother Hugo are pursued by the Inquisition through villages devastated by the disease. The story takes you on a roller coaster adventure where at points you feel safe then suddenly everything goes wrong. The game does a good job of pacing you through the story giving you parts of information at a time so you don't get overwhelmed to eventually understanding what Hugo has and the power of it.

(GAME PLAY) At first what seems a stealth/ running simulator, the game step by step introduces many different ways to avoid and take down the rats, the Inquisition and the English troops by giving you new recipes for alchemical potions you can use to tactically deal with the chaos you have to pass through. 

(CONS) There is one real off putting thing in the stealth part of the game when with another companion apart from Hugo where your hidden but your companion is out in the open for the enemies to see yet they are not detected which can ruin the amazing immersion of the game at times. The price of the game is also unjust at £35 so unless its on sale i don't know if the quality can make up for it. 

(CONCLUSION) After fully completing the game i can say i did very much enjoy it and am glad there is a game reflecting apart of history that is mainly forgotten and brings it back to life in its own unique way. Now considering playing through its sequel to see where the story goes.

-- First the cart pushing part of Coronation is broken. In addition to the soldiers that are listed in the walkthroughs online, the first group of two soldiers that appear behind you has an archer following them, creating a pincer situation for Amicia with the archers on the terrace.

(Devs, this archer really needs to be removed! People hate the game for this part, even if they have no aiming issues.)

The only chance I found is a narrow window after killing the first of the soldiers appearing behind you move just up the stairs as the cart is there and use the column of the railing as a shield from this archer while the cart (hopefully) protects you from the others. Then move just ahead of the front wheel and hopefully the cart will block this archer’s arrows and the ones on the terrace. Once it stops, watch that archer as best you can and pick when to take a chance with the sling (have it started before leaving cover). Hopefully you kill the archer before they kill you. After that a 2nd wave of soldiers come before Roderick can move.

Rest of the game:

+ Graphics are really good.
+ Game is playing through a story and puzzles not level grinding
+ Most of the game seems to work fairly well with fights, stealth, and puzzles

- Some sections of the game seem poorly balanced (worst is cart in Coronation)

143277951.review:
[h1]A Plague Tale: Innocence[/h1]
[b]Play as a young girl in ancient-ish France as you evade people trying to kill you, and rats.[/b]
[list]
[*] Heavy focus on stealth elements to navigate levels, simple combat outside of stealth.
[*] Aiming reticle automatically locks onto any target worth destroying. A missed shot is not a possibility.
[*] Large focus on level-based collectibles, and crafting materials are plentiful enough that all major upgrades will be obtained relatively quickly as you progress.
[*] You light a lot of things on fire. If you enjoy fire you'll probably have fun in this game.
[/list]
This game is heavily story driven and [i]entirely[/i] on-rails. Play it if you enjoy any of the following:
[list]
[*] Babysitting
[*] Pest Control
[*] Arson
[*] Sneaking
[*] Collecting
[*] Throwing Rocks
[/list]

143019505.review:
This game is very good. I didn't quite know what to expect from it going in, and while the amazing production values and engaging story immediately made a good impression on me, during the first 2 to 3 hours I was a bit worried that the gameplay would amount to doing the same thing over and over again. However, past that point the game started introducing new mechanics at a good pace, or at least repackaging old mechanics in new ways that made them feel fresh. 

I think I mostly expected this game to be akin to the Quantic Dreams games (Detroit: Become Human and so on). In reality, the gameplay style was closer to the Last of Us, or it least it began to remind me of that game after those first couple of hours. The gameplay here isn't quite so expansive as in Naughty Dog's classic, but the combat encounters in A Plague Tale become just open enough, and give you just enough options, to make it feel like you can tackle them with agency. 

Most importantly, however, I just really liked the story and characters. These elements are brought to life by visuals that (at least four years after its original release) are very impressive. It goes beyond good visuals though: the story and characters are the soul of this game, and they were so well-realized that they can stand on their own, without necessarily needing those graphics to back them up. I don't often attach myself to characters in video games, but in this game I liked just about all of the nice ones, and was appropriately revolted by the evil ones. Amicia's little brother especially is exactly the right amount of precocious, without ever feeling overwrought as a child character. Only one or two moments in the whole game felt contrived to create tension (or facilitate gameplay scenarios), and other than those small instances I enjoyed this game as though it were a movie. The way the story unfolded was satisfying enough that I found myself wanting to play on just to see what would happen, and that almost never happens to me in games. 

I played this game in French, and thought the dialogue was great and well-acted (I am not sure if French is supposed to be the 'original' language). There were one or two annoying gameplay sequences, and the gameplay logic of the rats that are an environmental hazard doesn't always make sense, but those details did not spoil the game for me. On the contrary, it exceeded my expectations considerably, and I can heartily recommend it.

142800364.review:
A terrifyingly beautiful game. 

Stunning visuals that even a budget PC can comfortably run at high to ultra settings. Great voice acting combined with often really well written dialogue. Amazing soundtrack that I'm listening to regularly on spotify. Probably the best cutscene to gameplay transitions I've ever seen. And the most minimalist (basically nonexistent) HUD you could wish for. 

All this combined results in a very immersive experience if you allow that to happen. I mostly played at night with my lights off and a drink on my desk (but I usually forgot to drink). The game being so linear only helps with this immersion because you don't have to worry about navigation, inventory, gear, quests, skill tree, or any of those kinds of mechanics and can get fully lost in the atmosphere and the sound of a thousand squeaking rats. 

Meanwhile the gameplay itself (mainly stealth complemented by puzzles and slingshot combat) while being simple remains interesting exactly because of the atmosphere created! I've never been scared of dying in games. That has changed. This game made me play so cautious, not wanting to make any mistakes, because I hated the gut wrenching feeling when Amicia got impaled by a spear or swarmed by rats. Or even worse: when I let something happen to Hugo. I simply was too emotionally involved. Obviously, a stealth-focused game instantly becomes ten times better in this case compared to when you're playing "trial and error", throwing yourself at the level over and over again to figure out how to complete it.

You could say that this game is a little bit like an interactive movie. And I'd also recommend to play it like you would direct a movie. You'll probably get the most out of it this way. Personally, I absolutely loved it. 

(PS: only buy it on sale though when it's 10$ or less)

142799680.review:
A stunning story and a tribute to the fact that not every 3D-animated, realism, combat game has to be a huge sandbox with 100+ hours of play. A linear story can be just a rewarding, especially concerning the narrative progression. "A Plague Tale: Innocence" took me 13 hours to complete. I was hooked and the atmosphere was absolutely the main reason for that - especially the audio. And no, it doesn't have that much replay value, but you know what, neither does masterpieces like Campo Santo's "Firewatch." If, in many years, I'll have forgotten much of the story or simply want to relive the grotesque ambience, I'll have it in my library. And I am certainly looking forward to playing "Requiem" next.
A tiny critique if I may. I cannot stand dying because of an NPC. Which happens more than once over and over in this game. Lucas is slow, Rodric always takes the long way round. Shooting is also at times painfully slow (even though I focused on upgrading my sling), and it sucks knowing what and how to do something, but feeling the game doesn't allow it. Worst thing is when you're stuck and have to go through the same dialogue multiple times just to get another shot.
So gameplay isn't always wonderful (though chucking stones at guards is disturbingly satisfying), but the story more than makes up for it. It is heartwarming as well as gut-wrenching and brutal. Only part I disliked it the whole Macula business. Just what exactly had that to do with the rats and controlling them?

142564961.review:
I haven't played a linear storytelling game in quite a long time but I'm glad I picked up this title. 

Pros:
-The story is simple yet well told. Not too long, not too short. (I finished the game to its story conclusion in under 17 hours and that included my own dawdling as I looked around and tried to find everything I could in one playthrough)
-The graphics and other visuals are superb, plus there's a camera mode you can use to take pictures of the scenery.
-There's a crafting system that allows you to collect components to craft ammunition and upgrade your pack and sling but it's convenient and basic enough to not be confusing.

Cons: (These are minor and don't really break anything)
-The Story does suffer from leaning a bit too much into the linear side. There's very little room for deviation from the main story path. Aside from the various collections you can grab along the way, I'd have liked to have seen a bit more "extra" content involving possibly dynamic MC interactions with the other characters and places within the game.
-Progression through the story is paced based and there are a couple times during my playthrough of the game where I moved Amicia forward too quickly and it caused the story dialogue to get cut off/interrupted by the next bit of dialogue.

Overall I enjoyed the game and if you like games that are linear and tell a story, then I'd recommend this title. (Though probably not for the full price of 39.99 USD...)

142326169.review:
7/10
I really tried to play the game past Ch. VIII as the story intrigues me, but the gameplay is simply awful. 
Graphics: nice, as most are these days, you won't see some great details from rain on characters and so on, but it's really nice overall. 
Mechanics: it's the dump you'll find on most games nowadays - crouch to be silent, crouch to pass under objects etc, and it doesn't even feel too polished... gather materials to upgrade etc
Story: great, I won't give spoilers, it's far better than most nowadays
Sound: also great, just had to mention it, it gives quite the atmosphere on a good sound system, I personally found it most amazing
Gameplay: 3year old puzzles and repetitive game loops, + some fast action 'run' phases, sad, with the copy-paste mechanics of everything today... it really felt too boring because of it, had played too many games with literally the same ideas in terms of motion etc...
I found a video with all the cutscenes in 4K on yt, and learned the story from there, stalwart experience in comparison to the bland loops and gameplay.
I'll give it a 7 because of story, graphics and atmosphere, though I'd argue the copy-paste mechanics just ruined a game that would've made history. I'd have appreciated a new try like on Death Stranding, a gave I loved just because they really tried to be something else, but no, in that regard, they decided to monkey like the rest.

141985480.review:
... and including a Dark Souls final boss fight sequence.  Mid-game.
I'm at the section where Hugo is pushing the cart and Amicia is to keep it lit so as to not get the rats near and devour them.
After a while a tremor occurs and an "F - Look" image pops up onto the screen.

- I have tried to find out if the tremor plays a role into both characters' survival.
- I have tried to give the slingshot to Hugo, as the game hinted upon.
- I have tried to use the slingshot before the cart fire went out.
- I have tried to use the slingshot in front of the cart, before its light goes out.
- I have tried to backtrace to see if I needed some other parts to survive and progress through this.
- I have tried to look left, right, up, down when the tremor appears, as thinking it needs me to do something else except of dying.
- I have tried to pick up all the ingredients lying around, thinking I'd need them to survive this game part.

I have made an effort to get through this part of the game ... 
FOR MORE THAN SIXTY TIMES.

There are limits to a human's resilience.  To mine.
So I'm asking this question to the devs: how many times do you need me to see that screen that says "Amicia Died" during this sequence any more?
83 times?
98 times?
127 times?
THREE HUNDRED AND EIGHTY NINE TIMES?

So for this, this 100% "You Will Die" section of the game, I'm giving it both a negative review and a final score of 5/10.  The graphics are pretty cool.
I'm sure you devs will be happy.

And if you'll now excuse me, I'm off to my way of dying for the 62nd time in your great video game.

141968048.review:
replayed it again to prepare myself for the 2nd game.
FOR A STUDIO THAT MAKES FLIGHT SIMS AND KIDS GAMES THESE PEOPLE KNOW HOW TO MAKE A FANTASTIC MATURE GAME.

Man it feels great coming back to the world of plague tale. The game is still SUPER IMMERSIVE
Sure the story is super linear, theirs close to no freedom in exploring that isn't just for extra goodies or Easter eggs, and the combat is somewhat repetitive. The game MAKES UP for in terms of WORLD BUILDING, CHARACTER DYNAMICS, DIALOGUE, WRITING, AND IMPRESSIVENESS.

This game makes you feel like your playing with real people and theirs ALOT of love into every thing you do in the game its like almost absent of any silent moments and filled with great dialogue.

Man this game really throws me back to the good old days of OG assassins creed in terms of stealth, era, and best of all character writings and dynamic thats been lost in recent single player games for some time.

Plague tale is one of my favorite single player games up there with the witcher for sure cause it has the potential to be EVEN GREATER, WHICH IS NUTZ for their first REAL DARK GAME.

141884152.review:
[h1]Experienced on the Meta Quest 2[/h1]

You can view my 3D in VR gameplay here (TAB 3D): https://youtu.be/BD-dZsa1MFE

So I am not reviewing the game. The game is excellent. There's 46.5K positive reviews on Steam you can read to heart's content. I am instead reviewing the 3D in VR experience for this game. You can do this using only free, open-source downloads. 

I specifically used the Geo-11 3D driver along with the game fix by masterotaku and simply Google that name and a plague tale innocence and you should find the file to download. All you have to do is download the file and extract it to the game folder with the executable to get the game to render in 3D. By default it is SBS 3D stereo, however, I manually changed it to katanga_vr which uses Top and Bottom stereoscopic 3D. 

Once you do that then you'll need a way to view 3D in VR. I used Helixvision (katanga) which is no longer for sale. However, you can use Virtual Desktop or the free, open-source VR screen cap (again just Google that for free download). By default the separation is set to 100 which will create a double image, so change it to 40 for VR headsets (control f3/f4). 

The game almost looks perfect without any further modifications. I played the game with default game settings on my RTX 3080 and it looked wonderful. However, I did have variable frame rates from 70-140 fps, which caused some micro screen tears / stutters. It honestly wasn't too bad, and keep in mind, I had graphics basically all on ultra settings. Game looks amazing. One of the best 3rd person looking games in VR. The only real issue was the UI / menus and sometimes seeing these vertical red bars (it rarely happened).

[b]3D in VR Rating 8/10.[/b]

[quote]If you enjoyed my review, please consider joining my Steam Curator Group. You can join here: https://steamcommunity.com/groups/Oculus_WMR [/quote]

141817868.review:
Bought this game in the summer sale, it's too short for me to have felt that full price would have been worth it. 
It is however a wow of a game; gorgeous environments, well voiced, great characters, excellent story.
The biggest hassle with it is: combat(in general) and the finale - man I get so sick of restarting at a checkpoint that is just soooooo repetitive, recraft everything and start over.
 I didn't mind the stealth element and some of the combat was cool - when you had more than your weapon - your own weapon is somewhat hit and miss. I am looking at you finale - aiming at fires under pressure (trying not to give spoilers here).
I made the mistake of upgrading pretty much the wrong things which left me vulnerable under fire. I have not currently completed the finale, dying within like 2ft of the boss and being sent back to the checkpoint, I'm bored with that part.
Be aware, if you are a noob to this game like me - you cannot change difficulty in the game AT ALL.
It's still gorgeous and well crafted but needed work on the combat,  weapon, difficulty and save areas. I'd still give it and 8/10

141777790.review:
The medieval babysitter simulator:  A Plague Tale, plagued with a specific, glaring issue.  I'd love to complain to you about that silly babysitting mechanic of gameplay, but instead I've got a more annoying issue to make you aware of.  The awful, no warning/no going back, cutscene/checkpoint system.  
I'm only on the 4th chapter and this is like the third time this kind of thing has happened.  First, it was missing-out on collectables and next, it was areas I hadn't explored yet (so probably more materials and collectables).  They don't warn you before you are about to be put through a cut-scene and miss a ton of collectable sh*t and irreversibly lose the ability to upgrade.  I wanted to search the entire house, before having to talk with anyone, so I could upgrade at the workbench and then go back and collect the materials which I didn't have space to carry.  But no, I apparently opened the wrong door, so now, there's no way back because a video gets triggered by opening the door. 
It isn't the video that I find frustrating, it is the fact that I'm now unable to complete the things I had intended on doing before being thrust into the cutscene.  Now I can't, not just get the extra valuables, I also can't upgrade now.  Why doesn't it warn you before proceeding? And I can't go back to a previous checkpoint, because it only offers the most recent, which puts me right AFTER the video, not before, where I want to be.  The only other option is to go back to the beginning of the chapter, which is like a whole Splinter Cell's level worth of stealthy manoeuvring and collecting all the items my pockets are now full to the brim with.  All that work and I can't even use the stuff to upgrade! 
This is, in my mind, game-breaking.  Why didn't they sort this out before its release? I'm absolutely sure I'm not the only one who has been having this issue.  I'm not even impressed by the story or voice acting, so it's not worth suffering through any more.

141627485.review:
A Plague Tale: Innocence is a game I did not expect to enjoy as much as I did. The story is easy to follow and draws you in from the beginning. The mysterious feelings that the atmosphere invokes are unique and really well executed. The voice actors did a wonderful job, as well as the art team. The good graphics are further enhanced by the attention to detail and the truly WONDERFUL lighting in the game. As an older sibling, this story really hit close to home. 

The sneaky gameplay gets a bit repetitive, but that's the game's playstyle, so it's to be expected. I would get stuck occasionally and I really wish there was a system that would give a clearer hint as to which path to take. What to do was easy to figure out, but which way to go wasn't as clear.

I'd rate this an 8/10.

141622459.review:
The story is incredible. It takes a topic like the plague and puts a spin on it making a terrible situation and adding a "horror" element. Story wise, it has great pacing. Doesn't feel rushed at all, or too short of a narrative. That being said, not sure if getting this game full price is the way too go. It was a great game but its pretty pricey for a 4 year old game that takes 11 hrs to finish. 

I loved the characters, the siblings bond actually reminded me of my own with my siblings and the rest of the cast had their own personality, their own motives and I really like that in a game. Was I emotionally moved by some events? YES. Did the backgrounds set up the mood? YES. 

Warning though, there is death EVERYWHERE (I mean just like the real plague that wiped out a huge chunk of the population. Whether its corpses sitting around, or your teen characters offing someone. So if that's not your thing avoid the game. I played on the highest setting and some of the corpses (if you look at them closely) can be gorey.

This is a very good game with a great story behind it.  A young girl and her little brother lose their family to an inquisition and this is a story of their survival.  The graphics are very good especially for such a small studio.  The voice acting was exceptional, with a special award going to the actor who portrayed the little brother Hugo. ------------ ACHIEVEMENTS -----------------------

If you are into achievements completion and want to have the following ones:

Not a toy anymore 
Handfull of pockets 

You can avoid doing another playthrough with this:

Go to Main Menu and then Chapter Selection. Select Chapter X. Once the loading screen shows up you have to keep pressed your " i " button and hold it. Once the game loads you'll see the inventory's menu and the scene will go on. Wait until Amicia stops talking and then press and hold your "TAB" button while stop pressing the " i " one. Navigate with " A " or " D " button to the Craft Menu and once you're there you have to keep pressed the click button while selecting an item of the Quick Craft (TAB) Menu. 140812088.review: Amicia and Hugo are a wonderful pair to play. You can tell that their creators actually have siblings, because the two feel and act as siblings actually would. The game is a journey between this pair as they try to survive amidst a plague and inquisition that seek to end them. The gameplay felt very solid, but is definitely the same type of gameplay that most action/adventure, over-the-shoulder-third-person games exhibit. Nevertheless, this game didn't feel about the gameplay even if it hadn't been very good. It felt like it was about the emotional bond between an older sister trying to protect her younger brother from all the dangers of a terribly dangerous time.

140766023.review:
This is a solid game. 

The story was captivating. it was a blast from the past and I felt immersed in the story. I love how it focused on the black plague way back in the 1300s but gave it a bit of a twist to make it interesting. It's a story about so many different things such as family, truth, and sacrifice. The game always had me wondering what was going to happen in the next chapter. The graphics were beautiful and detailed. I felt at points in the game I did have problems with the audio. The music would sometimes cut out or stop playing and then would turn back on. I am not sure if this is a problem with the game or a problem on my end, but it is something I noticed. I would say an issue that stands out to be with this game is there being no difficulty to choose from. It's a standard difficulty. There were times were the game was easy. There were times where I wanted to punch a hole through my monitor. So this game definitely gives you the best of both worlds. I love the length of this game as well. It's short, sweet, and to the point, instead of a story that drags on. Overall, I enjoyed the game. I didn't want to put it down and I had such a blast with it that it made me start doing research on the history of the black plague. I recently found out there is a sequel to this game, so I will definitely be checking that out. If I had to give this game a rating, I would rate it a 8.5/10.

140680673.review:
This game is a little gem. It follows the story of a sister and brother, Amicia and Hugo, during the Black Death in 14th Century France. Atmospheric, dark, at times grotesque and disturbing, A Plague Tale Innocence is a story and character-driven stealth game. It is a simple but moving tale of familial love. It is relatively easy to play but at times challenging to complete. It delivers a very satisfying story.

It avoids the trend of making games longer and more complex for no reason, delivering a satisfying conclusion over about 10-12 hours of gameplay.

This game has become one of my favourites and I strongly recommend it to anyone.

And I didn't even mention the rats...

140650665.review:
Got this from Humble Bundle and went in expecting to not really like this game as I always do with these linear story driven games, but this is one of the best I've played. The gameplay is all very basic and everything you do in this game has been done to death in many others. But all of those elements are done way better than I've seen in other games, such as the stealth and follower AI, mainly because its very forgiving. This was one of the first games to make me actually try and be stealthy whenever possible, rather than just killing everything, and I think that's because the combat has a nice balance of making you feel both helpless and powerful. And the pacing is perfect, constantly switching up what you're doing so you don't notice the repetitive gameplay too much. I was also expecting this to just be another plague sob story, but it was actually quite engaging and did a good job at setting up the gameplay. 

Quite a few bugs, but I was also expecting that with this being a AA game. If you get stuck in a tent, you have to toggle fullscreen and tab out. In chapter 9 and on you have to lock your monitor to 120hz max. 

Overall, I was pleasantly surprised by how much I enjoyed this game. Will definitely be picking up the sequel at some point. 4/5

140345497.review:
An unforgettable experience! 

The developers of this game did a wonderful job combining many different elements of gameplay that thrill and inspire. A very unique story, and characters to match. Plague Tale: Innocence is a dark game for sure. Betrayal and grief are plenty, each person fighting their own conflicts while also being forced into those of others.

The gameplay excels through its varied stealth and combat. Many times you must be creative and persistent in this world, not necessarily due to difficulty, but instead for the purpose of immersion. I would often feel so enclosed in the narrative that each decision made felt personal, as if you really were trying to preserve the lives of these individuals, and often their sanity too. The writing is such to convey a perfect sense of what struggle your character is going through. 

The combat is well implemented, and though not incredibly varied, offers the right amount of use as to not become repetitive. The stealth mends very well into the world; and unlike many other attempts at stealth, this feels more polished and very practical. 

I would definitely recommend this game to those looking for a cinematic adventure filled with many memorable moments, and above average gameplay mechanics. It never feels sluggish. I’d describe it as meticulous, though not tedious. 

Be warned! There were a few moments where I was completely softlocked, and had to die or restart from a recent checkpoint to continue, and at the last boss fight, the game broke entirely and the action required to defeat it was not functioning. I was able to fix it by verifying my files, then restarting the game and continuing the boss fight in the  chapter. I originally wrote a negative review as I could not fix this, but as I stated, verifying my files did the trick and allowed me to continue thankfully. 

Otherwise, for the few issues I had, but the many positives, I would give this game a solid 8.5/10. Looking forward to playing Requiem next!

140186866.review:
This review is going to be rather neutral. While I definitely enjoyed the game, it is far from perfect.

The game is set in dark fantasy medieval setting, both design and graphics are flawless. In-game mechanics such as stealth, fighting abilities, crafting and exploration are very smooth and well designed, I never felt like I'm wasting my time in this game and never got irritated by any of these aspects. 

A Plague Tale: Innocence has a number of very unique characters that feel alive, all thanks to the voice actors and animators.

However, game design is not that perfect. You will spend 9+ hours either running away, figuring out your way from point A to point B using stealth mechanics, or solving puzzles. It quickly gets dull and repetitive, but engaging story around prevents you from getting bored. Stealth and scripted events in Plague Tale look very artificial and so non-realistic that it is almost surreal. You go just behind people in absolute silence being unnoticed, levels are built so that there's only one way through with all the stuff located so that you run through it and launch in-game scripts.
I encountered 3 major bugs that prevented me from progressing so I had to google how to fix or get around them. 2 of them are connected to unlocked FPS in the game. It seems that the game works more stable with 60 fps lock. 

Even though I quickly got tired of artificial levels done for stealth I simply can't give this game less than 8 out of 10, it has a decent story and well-built, I just dislike some game design decisions, but it is not that much critical for that short game.

139914393.review:
Definitely one of the best experiences I've had in a story-driven game.

First off, rarely have I seen a game whose settings bring the story to life as much as A Plague Tale. The world, even in its tragic, apocalyptic state, finds ways to look stunning, beautiful, and real. The cinematic scenes, interactions, the atmosphere, events, and the people are very much alive. They all seamlessly work to elevate the story to a new level. Can we just talk about the number of times where I spam clicked the screenshot button during a cutscene or stopped to play with the camera feature in-game at the sight of something spectacular? Even without the screenshots, I still vividly recall the various places within the game. 

The character development is big. Even though we do not meet a  ton of characters, the few companions that Amicia and Hugo make along the way feel like family. While I wouldn't consider myself an extremely sentimental person, I do often sympathize with the cast and rooting for their growth in the many ways that they happen. Unfortunately, you do not control which companions join you on chapters and quests as the game is purely story-driven. However, there is enough bonding time for them all. 

The gameplay is rather simple and consists mostly of stealth and using items. Amicia's primary weapon is a slingshot which she finds creative ways to use. One shouldn't expect crazy and in-depth combat as it is somewhat out of character for the girl and her little brother trying to survive (and not to kill everyone). What makes the gameplay interesting is the multitude of ways that you can approach a scenario or event. There are many items in your arsenal that can be crafted at your choice; its about how you use them. There is no fixed way of doing something unless otherwise told. The boss fights have mechanisms that are not too difficult to understand - typically if something doesnt click right away, observe the surroundings for clues. 

All and all, I personally found the game to be fun, enjoyable and a thrilling experience. It was like being apart of a movie with twists and turns. I was pleasantly surprised at the incredible execution of scenes and character/world building. I would definitely re-live the story again someday. Excited to try the sequel when it goes on sale :)

139908994.review:
Es empezar el primer párrafo y decir sin duda alguna que A Plague Tale Innocence es uno de los mejores single player de la historia de los videojuegos que "yo" jugué, sin pestañear.

Claro que como siempre ningún videojuego es perfecto y generalmente se pueden observar costuras descocidas por ahí y por allá, pero cuando algo se hace con mimo es posible dejar pasar ciertas cosas. Si lo positivo es mas que lo negativo por supuesto que si.

De todas formas a nivel personal hay cosas que me obligaron a rendirme de rodillas sin chistar. Sus personajes, especialmente Amicia, yo pensaba que no podría encontrarme otro personaje femenino tan entrañable desde Bioshock Infinite como con Elizabeth.

La ambientación juega mucho a su favor, los escenarios en general están muy logrados. Se juega mucho con los contrastes, los momentos felices realmente se ven felices, mientras que los momentos tristes y de dolor se van a ver justamente así.

Gráficamente esta muy bien, no es el portento gráfico tampoco pero esta muy bien, esta bastante bien optimizado. Sin embargo si tenemos en cuenta que no parece tener un presupuesto tan impresionante comparado con otros titanes de la industria, algo respeto es lo mucho y muy bien que se puede hacer con poco, y aquí no va solo por el apartado gráfico. No tengo datos de cual fue el presupuesto para este juego, pero se nota que fue acotado pero en lo que a mi respecta, muy bien invertido.

La jugabilidad es optima, no hay lucha cuerpo a cuerpo, de hecho que un enemigo siquiera se acerque significa practicamente la muerte, por lo que nuestra arma principal es la distancia y el sigilo. Y por eso mismo tenemos la mejor arma de todas, la honda de Amicia que tendra ciertas municiones para ciertos facetas, en general muy bien diferenciadas entre si y casi siempre para un unico proposito. Agradecimientos especiales a Lucas, que hariamos sin ti amigo !!

Claro que lo divertido del juego son las ratitas que a lo único que le temen es a la luz y que no dudaran (y tampoco duraran) en comernos pedazo a pedazo si no tenemos con que iluminar nuestro camino y si bien el videojuego no tiene puzzles en si mismos, debemos plantearnos bien como dar cada paso entre las ratas y los soldados enemigos que tengamos que generalmente eludir. El juego realmente no desea que vayas por ahí eliminando a quien veas a tu paso, sin embargo es posible hacerlo, aun que en muchas ocasiones es preferible no hacerlo, especialmente si queremos mejorar las pocas pero claras habilidades que tenemos, pues hay objetos que son limitados que iremos encontrando durante la aventura que sirven tanto para mejorar habilidades como para crear ciertas herramientas que nos abrirán camino o nos permitirá sacarnos algún que otro enemigo del trayecto.

Son cinco las veces que termine el juego, esta ultima siendo oficial en Steam. Y si bien parece que el juego es posible terminarlo en poco tiempo, la primera vez tengo recuerdo de haber tardado mucho mas, por lo que no dejarse llevar por lo que dice Steam en cuanto a tiempo, a la quinta vez uno ya conoce cada tramo y mi intención fue mas que nada sacar todos los logros y como agradecimiento finalmente comprarlo. Si se juega tranquilo y disfrutándolo es un titulo relativamente largo si tenemos en cuenta que no hay misiones secundarias ni nada por el estilo, o sea no hay relleno. El videojuego en si es mas bien lineal y no hay mapas o niveles donde tengamos mucha libertad mas que avanzar de un punto a otro, por supuesto que en algunos casos se podrá elegir un trayecto A o B dependiendo del caso, pero son muy escasos y básicos.

[spoiler]Amicia sin duda alguna el personaje que mas sufre toda la transición, y ya desde el principio absoluto, vemos ese lazo importante que tiene con su padre y como al poco tiempo lo pierde. Tiene un hermano del que prácticamente no sabe nada, casi que ni lo conoce al igual que a su madre Beatrice que vive y se desvive por curar a su hijo Hugo de la enfermedad que lo asola. Amicia de pronto se encuentra que se queda sin padre ni madre, sin hogar y con Hugo a cuestas sin prácticamente saber que hacer, indefensa en un mundo hostil con un niño que no sabe nada del mundo. Sin embargo ella va a hacer todo lo posible por proteger a su hermano y si bien al principio le cuesta aceptar todo, poco a poco se va dando cuenta de lo importante que es para su hermano estar cerca y protegerlo.
Si bien es una ficción, me gusta mucho el crecimiento de este personaje en particular, por que es el clásico individuo que saca la fuerza que físicamente no tiene por su complexión, pero que la saca igual desde donde puede, ese clásico dicho conocido de que una madre saca fuerza donde no la tiene y termina sobrepasando cualquier adversidad, pues básicamente eso. De todas maneras esta muy bien implementado y es creíble porque Amicia a la distancia resulta letal y eso es totalmente factible.

Hugo es el infante de la historia, el hermano pequeño de Amicia y el mas importante (desde el punto de vista de la historia) ya que sera el que tenga la habilidad y la desgracia de manipular a esta "plaga". Un niño que vivió prácticamente toda su vida encerrado sin conocer el exterior, por lo que incluso después de haber perdido todo al igual que su hermana se le despierta ese espíritu de exploración para con el mundo exterior, todo aquello con lo que no tuve contacto nunca lo va experimentando junto con Amicia, lo bueno y lo desagradable del mundo. También me parece un personaje muy bien construido porque constantemente va cambiando de parecer, en general como somos los humanos, ya que vivimos mutando, cambiando de ideas al menos la mayoría de las veces, en este caso Hugo es muy vulnerable porque por un lado quiere creer que el mundo es bueno pero a medida que van pasando cosas se desilusiona mas y mas, y si no fuera por Amicia caería prácticamente al instante.
Entiendo que a mucha gente se le hizo cansino este personaje, sinceramente no se que esperaban de un niño de 5 o 6 años, poco de comprensión... tiene todo el sentido del mundo que este preguntando constantemente cosas, es un niño... y que en prácticamente todo el juego los hermanos vayan de la mano tiene también todo el sentido del mundo ya que es la base jugable del titulo.

Lucas que sin pena ni gloria no le queda otra que unirse al grupo, y muy bien que así sea, pues es clave para que el pequeñajo pueda subsistir en la aventura.

Rodric es el hijo de un herrero que conoceremos en algún punto de la historia, hay dos cosas que me gustaron mucho de este personaje. La primera es la interacción que tiene con Hugo, si me baso en los diálogos Rodric es quien le afianza la seguridad a Hugo y aparte es una figura paterna. La segunda razón es porque hace en lo que a mi respecta el mejor sacrificio de todo el juego y por ende uno de los momentos mas tristes de la aventura.[/spoiler]

La música va de la mano con el juego, ya sea en momento de tranquilidad o en esos momentos críticos donde especialmente nuestros dos protagonistas deben enfrentarse a sus peores miedos, y todo ello al menos a mi me lo transmitió y lo sentí como tal, para mi es de agradecer, es lo que busco también cuando veo una película, especialmente si es un buen drama. El tema principal es muy poderoso.

Tengo entendido que el doblaje original en francés es increíble, sin embargo en mi primera partida lo jugué en ingles y me gusto tanto que no vi la necesidad de jugarlo en su idioma original, quizás este pecando de tonto en este aspecto, pero el trabajo de la actriz que interpreta a Amicia en ingles me pareció sublime y en general de los demás personajes también, el de Hugo me gusto mucho también.

Re contra hiper recomendado, cualquier amante de videojuegos de un solo jugador no le puede faltar este titulo, pero he de confesar que la primera vez que lo jugué mis expectativas eran nulas y/o pocas por lo que el denominado "hipe" que te inducen es un cáncer en la industria que mata al niño que llevamos dentro.

No entraron mas palabras.

139869577.review:
A visually-pleasing, yet disappointing experience. The gameplay concept (navigating massive swarms of deadly rats and fending them off via light) was interesting at first and the mechanics function smoothly, but the puzzles in the game are clearly designed with one "intended" way to complete them, and if you deviate from those steps, things fall apart.

PROS
+Nice graphics and scenery
+Voice acting of the MC isn't bad
+Satisfying seeing all the hundreds of rats scurrying around fluidly
+Some collectibles and extra dialogue for venturing off the beaten path

CONS
-Stiff puzzles that punish creativity
-Storyline starts off strong, gets weird in the middle, and then plummets into ridiculousness towards the end
-Seriously, I want to stress the above. The entire reason I got this game was because I was curious about the plot, and I gotta say, the storyline was definitely an unsatisfying experience. The game starts off as medieval-era realism and then you get things like [spoiler] rats grouping together to form mini rat-tornados  [/spoiler] and the final boss who [spoiler] uses a rat swarm as body armor and controls them telepathically to become rat geysers that blow through the stone floors and massive rat pillars that topple onto you  [/spoiler]
-Upgrades barely feel useful, and are bottlenecked behind two limited resources: fabric and leather
-Hugo is not a likable character. I get it, he's a kid so he's supposed to be stupid, but there's a scene in the beginning where [spoiler] you and Hugo are running for your lives through a town where everyone is trying to murder you, and you BARELY get away because an old woman lets you hide in her home. [/spoiler] [spoiler] and then Hugo throws a tantrum because he wants to go see his mommy, so he grabs a wooden mallet and starts loudly banging on the tables, and then he RUNS OFF OUTSIDE, so you have to go chase him. Like, seriously? Did he forget about the HOARD of murderous townfolk that we JUST escaped from? [/spoiler] 
-Some puzzles are just timewasters (e.g. Push this cart for 12 straight seconds)

Overall, I can't say I'd recommend the experience, or at least definitely not at full price.

139804635.review:
A beautiful and brutal story told within a beautiful and brutal world.

After seeing complaints from other players over the years, I’d been put off trying A Plague Tale: Innocence, but after finishing it I’m very glad I decided to get what I’ve found to be an impressive and captivating game.

It’s a survival story with interesting environmental puzzles and light stealth segments, set in a landscape of death and destruction while at the same being stunning and atmospheric. The music, ambience and voice-acting are all excellent. One of the main complaints I’d seen was about the younger brother being annoying, but I personally found him adorable and brilliantly acted. I really felt for the little guy.

Throughout the game the camera, controls and overall tone kept reminding me of Life Is Strange, while the gameplay itself felt like a combination of Splinter Cell and the PS2 game Ico, which made for an interesting mix. The puzzles aren’t overly challenging, though I caught myself out a few times by over-thinking and over-complicating things.

Using an i5 12600k and RTX 3080, performance was excellent through the whole game, holding a rock-solid 120Hz at 1440p once I turned down the shadow maps by one click. I encountered a couple of minor bugs that needed a restart from the last checkpoint, but they weren’t much of an issue and I didn’t encounter any crashes.

Overall, I’ve found A Plague Tale: Innocence to be a real gem of a game, and I’m looking forward to playing the sequel at some point.

I'll review the game for what it is : a linear story game, and a good and entertaining one. I must add that I played the game from start to the end on the Steam Deck.

First, the setting is awesome, at least a game/story that take place in medieval France without looking like a boring history children classroom. Add some quality french voices! The scenery is just breathtaking, the level design make feel a bit restricted sometimes, but most of the times it fits well that you don't want to go wander (and get eaten by a gr-- err rats).

Storywise, I'm happy. It add a supernatural component to the setting, but something that blends well with the setting. The characters are relatable and credible, it's a just a bit of shame the story do not manage to include some more characterization in some of them. I found Hugo especially well done for  a 5 year old. The plot is consistent, and makes the game story go forward like a movie.

Graphics are quite good on the Deck. No performance issue despite the Deck compatibility chart. Like previously said, scenery is awesome, characters looks good even if the facial expressions are a little bit too shy -- but given the darkness of what the characters go through, maybe that's everybody PTSD taking place.

Games mechanics and puzzle: collaborative puzzles are very nice and fit well your companions skill sets. You are kindly nudged if you don't see a puzzle solution, that's nice because ambiance-wise, you don't really expect to run around for hours looking how to proceed. Fighting is a bit weird: Amicia's slingshot skills make you think you're in a superhero movie, but you are a glass canon, not doomguy. It's a good thing it's not fighting all the time. The part I found a bit weird was the gear upgrade system that felt not intuitive on my first run -- and a bit frustrating because I was often at a bench without the possibility to upgrade anything.

So, this games deserves praises and recognition with a setting and story that really push the player forward. If the teaser/trailer interested you, you'll like the game. I'll play the sequel at some point!
