139682227.review:
Just finished the game and actually it's my first time writing a game review in a story mode game and I'll give it a 8/10. Also I got the game in a discounted price for like I think less than 5 dollars

Right so, I'm gonna be talking about the pros and cons and recommendation.

Pros
-Have good story that you'll enjoy.
-Visuals are phenomenal. If you are wondering if it has a Ray tracing because it came out in 2019. Unfortunately it does not have it but the game never failed to deliver stunning visuals, Trust me.
-The development between amicia and hugo's relationship as siblings is good but I wish that it was also done to the other characters like Rodric and Lucas. Because as the story go, they will be important and yeah most of the character does but all throughout my play I didn't get any affection to them. The progress on them is just, I can't say it's poor but short.
-The boss fights are decent and I enjoyed the last two boss fight.
-Some of the story is intense and most of it requires you to be stealthy.
-Animation is good
-Optimization is decent I am able to play in ultra graphics with a bit of stutter but it will not affect your gameplay it will be less and less as the story go. I'm using RTX 2060 and Ryzen 5 3600. So if you have the same specs as mine you will not have any problem.
-Autosave so you won't have to worry to save your game.

Cons
-Just like I said all the side characters doesn't have development between the sibling except for Lucas.
-Acting is bland but the emotions is there.
-There is a bug that I encountered at near end of the game. (spoiler alert) it's when Hugo is protecting her mother. If you failed to protect your mother from arrows but at the same time killed the enemies the game will not trigger the death animation and the dialogue will continue but everything will pause. I actually found a way to fix it without restarting the game you just have to alt+tab and the menu will show and you will be able to restart from the last checkpoint. Make sure to do it right after that.

Recommendation
For full game experience. I suggest you to go the settings, game, advance hud settings and turn everything to no to make it a little bit harder, also turn your aim assist to low. Don't worry the controls is easy to find out. Go play in ultra graphical settings (if possible). Use the surround speaker in audio settings if you have a surround sound headset or speaker (it is for the better sound experience). It is ok to take your time in clearing every part of the places so don't be afraid to loot (don't do it in a chase scene).

Last, is it worth it for 23.10 dollars? It's up to you. You'll be the one to tell if it's worth it because for me it is. I got it for a discounted price and enjoyed the 9 hours of gameplay so that's why for me it is worth it. Maybe you'll get the same experience even with the original price.

139679242.review:
The 14th century was one of the most horrible chapters in European history. The lands were ravaged by famine, war, and a terrifying pandemic of then-unknown origin. It is in these apocalyptic times that A Plague Tale: Innocence is set.

This is a game that really makes fantastic use of its setting to deliver a haunting story filled with memorable environments. From primeval forests to dead battlefields to crumbling castles and opulent cathedrals, there is rarely a moment where the visuals do not shine, and the story of orphaned siblings Amicia and Hugo is compelling from start to finish thanks in particular to outstanding voice acting for the main cast. It's an excellent narrative that should delight fans of story-centric gaming.

What is also interesting is how the Black Death is represented in this world. If, like I was, you might be worried there will be graphic depictions of bubonic plague and what it does to the human body, rest assured: no, nothing quite like that. Instead, this devastating outbreak is presented through a fantasy lens, with enormous squirming hordes of outright demonic rats serving as the game's biggest threat. The only thing standing between you and a painful death at the hands (teeth?) of these chittering creatures is light. You'd better hope your torch doesn't go out...

On the subject of gameplay, what's on offer here is not particularly revolutionary, but the familiar blend of stealth-action and mild environmental puzzle-solving is executed robustly enough that it doesn't really matter that there are no great innovations; this does not feel like "we have The Last of Us at home", if you ask me. It is good enough to stand on its own feet. 

I've been a fan of the not-quite-AAA, often European-developed, narrative-driven games published by the likes of Focus for a while now, and this is easily one of the best ones in that category. If you're looking for a great story that was clearly produced with a lot of love and passion, I'd warmly recommend giving A Plague Tale: Innocence your time.

139628828.review:
First of all,
The gameplay mechanics are equally impressive. As you progress, you'll encounter hordes of deadly rats that react to light and sound, creating an ever-present sense of tension and danger. You'll need to think strategically, using fire and other tools to manipulate the rats and clear a path for Amicia and Hugo. The puzzle elements are challenging yet satisfying, and the stealth mechanics are executed with precision, adding variety and depth to the gameplay experience.

Moreover, the voice acting is superb, bringing the characters to life and evoking a range of emotions. From Amicia's determination to Hugo's innocence, the performances are nuanced and believable, further immersing players in the game's world.

I leave a positive review, because in the end I have finished the game(which is rare), and I like the art design of it. Apart from that, the game is very 'mediocre'. I would sumarize this game as The Last Of Us: Medieval. 

The gameplay itself is extremely repetetive for the most of the game.  It's a very limited sealth game with some fighting mechanics, and its quite bad at both. You go around throwing rocks at things. Things make noise, guards go there.  Enemies are dumb, their patrol patterns are extremely basic. Near the end gameplay changes quite drastically, but for the worse in my opinion. I don't want to spoiler too much as the story is what is supposed to drive this game.
Story is ok. Has its stupidities, but it can be enjoyable along with all the characters. Even the little kid, as annoying as he can be sometimes, is likeable.
And please devs for gods sake make some historical research, at least a little. Guards surely were not wearing Tournament Jousting helmets when on duty. Game is full of this kind of historical nonsense, it took quite a lot from the experience for me.

139551105.review:
The game is a visual treat, with stunning graphics and realistic animations that bring the medieval world to life. The game’s gameplay is mostly based on stealth and also has some puzzle segments.
The game’s main strength is its narrative, which is well-written and well-acted, with believable and likable characters that you will care for and root for. The game explores themes such as family, loyalty, faith, and courage, as well as the horrors of war and disease.
A Plague Tale: Innocence is a must-play for fans of action-adventure games, as well as for anyone who enjoys a well-crafted and engaging story.

139459184.review: I'm normally not into these kinds of games when I kept seeing people say A Plague Tale was like The Last of Us I was worried I wouldn't like it since I find stuff like modern playstation exclusives (i.e. The Last of Us, Uncharted, God of War, Horizon Zero Dawn, Ghost of Tsushima) boring but I'm glad that wasn't the case since it didn't really feel like an interactive movie and it was the first time I enjoyed a story driven game. Loved the story it was the first time I actually cared about story in a game it was well paced enjoyed it from start to finish, gameplay is pretty solid when getting into the last few chapters of the game I can understand why they didn't add hand to hand combat or even let Amicia use weapons besides the sling. Really good soundtrack usually these games have such a forgettable soundtrack but that's not the case with a plague tale it has some good beats. One issue I had with the game was the final boss while the design of the fight itself and the build up to it was epic but gameplay wise it felt a bit tedious but other than that I'd recommend A Plague Tale: Innocence if you;re looking for a good story driven game 8/10

139448602.review:
A Plague Tale: Innocence is a linear, story rich adventure game where you play as Amicia, the female protagonist and Hugo her younger brother. 

The story telling, graphics and game play were all phenomenal. Every chapter of the story was engaging and the progression of items and skills was perfectly balanced. 

Lastly, the in-game tutorial system is how every game should do it! You learn a new ability, they give the required items and have you test it then and there. Also, the lack of any overhead HUD really added to the immersion. 

Highly recommend and I’m already looking forward to the sequel! Overall rating, 9/10

[h1]A Rat-Infested Masterpiece![/h1]
The depth of the narrative and the emotional impact it delivers are truly remarkable. The voice acting and character development are top-notch. The gameplay offers a blend of stealth, puzzle-solving, and storytelling. Visually, the game is stunning. The graphics are so detailed that you can practically count the fleas on the rats. However, the combat mechanics may become repetitive over time and lack the desired depth seen in other aspects of the game.

Rating: 9/10

139180897.review:
I just finished the main campaign at the time of writing this review and all I can say is: 

Wow!

I usually play faster-paced games that are open world and are not plot-focused. This is a linear game with much of the gameplay revolving around getting past one enemy type or another with a variety of tools and strategies and is similar to puzzle games in that way as fighting is often not an option or not the best option. 

The plot is wonderful. The characters are wonderful. The gameplay gets to be very exciting! The world that is created here is gorgeous, though also tragic and grotesque. I intend to buy the sequel immediately. 

I highly recommend this game.

Might not be the best - has its flaws and the biggest of them will be that it doesn't have a replayability.
Why I think so?
There's a low chance that you'll get any collectible at the first run, so a proper New Game+ would be a great way to encourage a player to play again.
Every upgrade you've got on your previous playthrough (probably except Hugo's skill) would unlock new possibilities to solve puzzles. Maybe it would be "too easy", but haven't I already finished the game?

138988227.review:
Recomendado porque no existe la opción de ni fu ni fa.

Un "vídeojuego" que tiene más de vídeo (tampoco mucho) que de "juego". Trata de mezclar una historia pseudohistórica (plagada de falacias, por otro lado; típicas justificaciones desde el desconocimiento de niños de 10 años adoctrinados) con una trama absurda y que a la mitad del "juego" pierde todo sentido y desvaría en un absurdo... Ideas buenas de opciones "jugables" y mecánicas totalmente desaprovechadas, con un árbol de progreso que no aporta mucho. Las nuevas opciones se solapan y al final hay poca variedad porque el movimiento y el punto de vista ortopédico en tercera persona hacen que la "jugabilidad" se pierda. Hay, ahora que lo recuerdo, opciones como echarse a un lado que son totalmente inservivles, no las he usado nunca. No hay combates como tales, se trata de un juego con gráficos bastante aceptables, aunque necesita una GPU potente, una 970 apenas llegaba a los 60FPS al máximo a 1920x1200 (eso sí, no usa apenas VRAM, las texturas no son malas, pero en 4K deben verse bastante mal; con DSR 1600p que usa una RTX3080 12GB 384b OC no alcanza el 70% de uso y nunca llega a 4GB de VRAM). Quien guste de efectos del todo a  cien de postprocesado, pueden dejar la aberración cromática, filtrado paso alto y ruido, pero si no te gusta estropear la imagen porque esté de moda, toca poner a 0 esas opciones en el fichero de configuración (no aparecen en el menú de gráficos del juego).

Gráficos: 8
Sonido: 8'5
Música: 8'5 (usar zanfoña no evita que la inclusión de instrumentos totalmente ajenos a la época hagan de la música un quiero parecer pero no lo soy de la época).
Historia: 5. No dice nada, un algo que no se desarrolla y que ni es atrayente per se, ni se narra bien, los diálogos son abominables, con una forma de hablar y unas palabras que para nada "parecen" de la época, sino más bien de niñatos nacidos hace 20 años. La representación de la sociedad medieval es una aberración también, y sin mentar la fe católica explícitamente, pero usando su imaginería e incluso añadiendo en coleccionables personajes reales totalmente deformados y tratados como dicta la actual doctrina 2030, sin ningún tipo de trasfondo de realidad. La imagen de la inquisición (búsqueda) es la de "siempre" negrolegendaria; al menos en este caso es la francesa...
Jugabilidad: 5; y me estoy pasando. El juego en realidad son pasillos con alguna breve ramificación que, al estar todo totalmente predefinido por "scriot", si llegas a un sitio antes de ir a otro, la animación te salta, cota el camino y lo pierdes. Esto sumado a los objetos usables para crear objetos hace que pases el tiempo tratando de encontrar objetos olvidando la trama del momento... Estos pasillos que es el juego llevan a zonas donde se presentan sencillos puzles que al final con las opciones dadas (que se pueden simplemente resumir en disparar a la cabeza) apenas se exploran las opciones y en casi todos los casos están tan medidos que no puedes ahcer ciertas opciones porque te dan ya lo que hacer para que salga, de hecho te dan los materiales necesarios para que unívocamente crees el objeto a usar. De la supuesta inteligencia artificial mejor ni hablamos.
TOTAL: 7 (pero como "juego", de 5).

No digo que no sea recomendable para echar un rato, pero es una oportunidad perdida en lo jugable, y una aberración típica pretendiendo mostrar el medievo que no fue así. De la inquisición y la Iglesia, mejor ni hablar, es material anticatólico y "veintetréinco". Y eso que sólo tiene un personaje que es más así [spoiler]la ladrona es inaguantable[/spoiler]. Lo "escriptado" que está todo, la ortopédica movilidad cuando llevas lastres, digo "compañeros" lo dejan en una serie de puzles simples, pseudo zonas de "sigilo" (ejem) y una pretendida trama que no hay por dónde cogerla. SI querían mostrar la peste, esta no es la manera, esto es una absurdez.

138942763.review:
TLDR:

Pros: The atmosphere of the game is amazing and it's achieved through its music, voice acting, and art style. The story is also pretty good. 

Cons: There were plenty of bugs that could be annoying, the game is short for its price, and some characters were written weirdly. 

7.5/10
=====================================================================================

For context I 100 percent the game 

A plague tale is a game developed by Asobo Studios. I was made aware of this game by my brother, and I got it entirely based on his recommendations. I would say that the game is very good. I very much enjoyed the game, and I think you will too. Here are the pros and cons of the game

[h1] Pros [/h1]

Atmosphere - I would say that the biggest positive about this game is the atmosphere. It makes this game amazing and carries it hard. it was able to achieve this amazing atmosphere with 3 main components. 

	Music - the medieval percussive string music in this game is phenomenal. It adds to the game as a whole and allows for intense moments to shine. 

	Voice Acting - The voice acting from most of the main cast is very good and adds to the emotions and the story

	Art Style - Not to get confused with graphics, the art style makes you feel like you are playing in the medieval period. This makes the game look really good even if the actual graphics fidelity is not so impressive

Story - The story itself is pretty good. I won't talk about it here to not spoil it. 

[h1] Cons [/h1]

Bugs - There were plenty of bugs that were very annoying to come across during this playthrough, one of them is invisible barriers, that for some reason do not allow Amica to move to another area. The only fix is to change the game to windowed mode, go past where ever you need to go, and then change it back to full screen.

Length - The length for a game is 40 dollars at full price (most of the time tho, you can get a pretty good discount) The game is very short. The only reason why I have above 20 hours in the game, is because there were lengthy sections that I needed to go back and leave my game running. I probably spent around 14 hours playing the game. 

The way that SOME characters were written - Sometimes, some character sections are written very weirdly. For example, not to name anyone. You meet them while trying to get an item important to the story. You save them while they were getting escorted by guards, and all of a sudden it feels like they will do whatever you want them to do, with no thought behind it. It just feels very weird.

[h1] In Conclusion [/h1]

Overall, this game is a short, but memorable experience that I will surely remember for a long time. I would recommend picking up this game when it is discounted. You will not regret it.

[h2] 8/10 [/h2]

138938879.review:
I've seen tons of positive reviews of this game, and a few negative ones; sadly enough i'm going to add one to the latter.

As a gamer who's been touching controllers and other gaming input devices since the early 1980's I think that my opinion might have some value for other people. I'm not a gaming god or whatsoever but I do hold quite a lot of gaming experience in that grey matter which fills the upper part of my skull.

So i'll start with the positive things:
On my system the game runs decent on my system (1440P on a RX6700XT and i5-10600K and 16GB ram). I've seen worse ports so can't say it runs bad. The storytelling on the other hand is a lot better than tons of games. It's a nice story with characters that are very interesting themselves too and the story is picked up every 1 or 2 puzzles so you stay invested deeply to unfold the next part. The story itself has some very minor issues but overall i can't say bad things about it. The character building of the protagonist also is done quite well; you can upgrade your character with new skills and you get to discover a lot of "tools/weapons" during the game that will support you then and later on. The levels are well-built, you really get the feeling of walking around in France during the middle-ages while the Plague was wreaking havoc on the population. For a 2019 console game the graphics are not bad at all; but looking at other games from the same year (or even older) I can't say that this game stands out for its beauty or realism. Another thing i really liked is that the talk-animations are synced with the Original language those people were speaking; French.  It took me a while to find out exactly which of the voice-overs was the original, as the game was defaulted to English (i live in a country that has Dutch and French as official language) on my system and nowhere was stated that French was the original language. When u change the language for speech during a conversation, the sync will only be corrected in the next conversation you have with someone.

Now some negatives ...
I ended with the speech language; sadly you cannot set the game to use the OG language (French) while keeping the English for all the rest of the game. Eg if you set the subs to english, you'll hear french, read english subs but if you see an item and put your mouse over it, that text will still appear in french. So you can't change the complete game language to english and then set 'speech' to french. 
The game could've run A LOT better had they not just blatantly made a port, add some settings and call it a day. For the graphics we get presented this game performs not that good. I'm sure that if they properly ported the game to PC and fixed their engine to use the available resources optimally, we could've seen some 30 to 50% extra frames per second. I've seen games that look a lot more realistic (and need more resources) and at the same time run a lot smoother.
My biggest problem with this game is sadly not how it looks, sounds or feels; but how it plays. In my experience this game doesn't leave a lot of room for creativity; If the devs want you to solve a puzzle THIS WAY, often that's the ONLY way you can do it without dying. It's ok during the very first part of the game, where you learn to handle the game and it's controls. Once you have the controls under your knee I don't think it's really opportune to restrict the player of being creative. I'm not saying there's no room for creativity during the complete game; but almost every puzzle that you need to solve inside a building is designed in such a way that you need to solve it the "developer's way". This results in having to retry puzzles a few times, until you finally discovered which solution, according to the devs, works best. I don't mind to have some puzzles that need an 'exact solution" from time to time, but when half of the gameplay is like this it becomes boring and dull. That's also the reason i stopped playing after some 14hrs. I was playing in 2hr "episodes", and i already had problems finding motivation to begin with the 4th 2hr-episode but after the 7th part I was so bored with the game that even the nice story couldn't convince me anymore to just continue the game.  I'm really into good stories but this game kills the interest in that story by adding such a bad game-design between the evolution of the story. 
A game can have a good story, but the story can't be the main event of the game if the rest is just some bad gameplay to add extra time to the experience.. EIther you've got a good story you want to tell and use a walking sim type of gameplay to add time OR you put decent effort an playtesting in the game so it's enjoyable for at least 70% of the people that buy the game. In this game I can't believe they ever hit that mark. I've played worse games too, but for how this game is positioned (as a AAA game) I can truly say i've played TONS and TONS of games that were better.  It's sad that this fantastic and interesting story has to live with such bad gameplay in the same piece of entertainment software.

Conclusion:
I really enjoyed the first few hours of the game, but soon it became dull, boring, uninteresting because of how the gameplay tears down every brick that was so nicely built by the story itself. I can't recommend this game other than if you get it on a promo or sale. It's not worth the full price and the chance is high that you'll stop playing before you even get to the halfway point of the game. I probably won't pick up the sequel, for those who did I really hope that the devs actually paid some attention to the problems that make this game so bad for a pc-game. I'll probably never find it out because right now Asobo is on my 'avoid-list' until i've heard, read and saw reviews from a new game of theirs where people are saying they really learned from the mistakes they made in their previous game(s).

I really appreciate a small indie studio with an original idea trying to make a grand experience. They did a really great job creating the character of Hugo. I felt sympathy for him. The giant waves of rats were impressive. [spoiler] it was a good change of gameplay to be against the rats to try help them later in the game [/spoiler] 

What I play single player story focus games is for immersion. However dying so often was very immersion breaking. The frequent check points made death all the more inconsequential. Quite often enemies would see me from a mile away while I'm 90% behind an obstacle and at the same time for me to then escape them by going round a half a meter object. This is also immersion-breaking and many times my death was unjustified considering the rules expectations I was set until that point. [spoiler] It was obvious to me from the very start that we would be able to control the rats. [/spoiler] The antagonist was introduced three quarters into the game so the defeat of him didn't feel cathartic. I wish I knew that there was a french language option as it would have been more immersive to me than English voices with french accents, which although the main 2 characters mostly nailed, speech from others took me out of it. [spoiler] Amesia would do anything for her brother but then stops looking for him and doesn't go looking for her mother isn't in line with how the character behaved up til that point, they could of made any other excuse why she wasn't able to maintain her search [/spoiler]

I can't recommend, although it started interesting and original, when the core gameplay loop is not fun, there is little reason to keep playing other than to keep up with the story, and while the 2 main characters are written well, what they do is not so.

9.8/10. Lightweight spoiler-free review below (though this is one of the games that is deserving of a novel of praise).

The -0.2 was for a shitty prologue that left a sour taste in my mouth for the first third of the game. Otherwise, this game is a 10/10. Graphics, story, gameplay, character, and just overall planning & writing for the game was excellent. I really wish more games were like this. I found myself really admiring the writing and the way the story was told, as well as the characters. I don't think that there is even one character that was poorly written. Hell, even the vile demon rats had quite the charm by the end! 

It had drawn me in so much halfway through the first game that I was really bummed out when I heard it wasn't getting a third game. You know how One Piece, Naruto, etc etc has a gazillion episodes, and genres like The Elder Scrolls & Star Wars have never ending lore with new games? Yeah, I would totally buy into something like that with lots of content and follows these characters. To me, this is infinitely better than say, Harry Potter, yet there's just way less story to the universe. I would totally buy a game telling a backstory of Amicia's father or mother, or what happens to Meilia after she departs, or even more games just following Amicia. Amicia was very well written and I would like to see more content with her on screen. I could say the same of other unnamed characters, but that's not possible given story circumstances. 

I'm a dude that writs a lot of negative reviews. That dude is saying: Pick this up and savor it. 
It's worth full price, but if you pay just $10 more, you can get the sequel too.

137984469.review:
Developer: Asobo Studio
Publisher: Focus Entertainment
Publication: May 19, 2019

A Plague Tale: Innocence is a single-player narrative set in medieval France that follows Amicia de Rune and her sick, isolated younger brother, Hugo, who are fleeing from an inquisition. The religious order is convinced that their royal bloodline is hiding the secret of liberating the country from the increasing hordes of bloodthirsty plague rats and, in an act of rage, murder the de Rune parents.

The story is unapologetically brutal, set in a dark atmosphere where piles of sick bodies line abandoned streets and others are hung to lure the monstrous swarms away from ruthless, patrolling guards. This is complimented by Olivier Deriviere’s harsh symphony of violins, cellos, and a lute, which mix tones of dread with slivers of hope.

In fact, in the forefront, is a tale of inspiring, ruthless idealism for the siblings, contrasting the oppressive world that they live in and the people who would do them harm. Along the way, they make allies who add a strong dynamic to the de Rune family, without taking the spotlight from them.

The narrative itself is tight; there are no side-quests and only a few optional collectibles that are not terribly tedious if you have a guide or a few minutes to run around in the narrow world… which isn’t a bad thing, either. Yes, the game is short – it took me about fifteen hours to a single playthrough – but the quality is strong and it never overstays its welcome, something that the market does not always understand.

Voice-acting in this game really shines; despite a few adults voicing kids, I never found it jarring, and they do such a great job. The standouts are, of course, Charlotte McBurney (Amicia) and Logan Hannan (Hugo)… as well as Edan Hayhurst, whose character I will not spoil.

I should mention that Asobo Studio is a French development team, so the original cast is voiced by francophones. I did play some of the game in their native language, but found that the English voice actors/actresses carried their scenes with far more emotion. This, of course, is a personal preference.

Graphically, it looks good, although I should mention that facial animation is quite stiff, both in how characters move their mouths or the dead way they shift their eyes. I did not find it to be off-putting, but definitely noticeable.

As far as gameplay, this may be the biggest turnoff: You are cast into third-person, avoiding guards throughout the country, slipping behind blockades and buckets, or inside conveniently-placed tall grass like “Horizon” stealth mechanics. Attacking is minimal, especially as resources can be pretty scarce, so you will usually be trying to figure out how to sneak by guards after distracting them with a satchel full of rocks.

The only mechanic consists of sections where Amicia will need to go on her own… but only too far, otherwise her younger brother will have a panic attack and you will need to restart the mission.

A Plague Tale: Innocence is a short, but powerful coming-of-age story about finding hope in spite of strife. Its character development is strong, never taking the spotlight off of its core: a sister and brother who become insufferable. The combat, while the weakest part, is not enough to keep people away from experiencing such a powerful tale.

137869428.review:
Una aventura narrativa única que se aleja de los juegos de acción y sigilo convencionales. Una historia oscura, triste y apagada. Y sobre todo la justificación de cómo un título AA puede competir con cualquier AAA. Dentro reseña!

A plague tale nos propone un mundo que se va al traste por la aparición de una plaga de ratas que se come todo lo que se mueve. Imagina a zombies, pero en ratas. La historia narra el punto de vista de Amicia y Hugo De Rune, dos hermanos muy especiales. Por cosas del destino, Amicia deberá proteger a su hermano de las personas que quieren capturar al chico y descubrir quién es y qué relación guarda esa familia con las plagas. El juego propone un estilo de gameplay diferente, que se basa en el sigilo.

Amicia porta una honda con la que disparar diferentes tipos de municiones que podremos ir creando a lo largo de las 10-11 horas que nos puede durar el juego. Hay municiones desde piedras normales, municiones que apagan fuegos, que aislan a las ratas...todo en una ruleta de "armas". Los recursos son escasos y deberemos explorar bien todas las zonas que si bien son lineales durante los 17 capítulos del juego, podremos hacer pequeños desvíos para encontrar un carro con recursos, por ejemplo. No siempre hay que optar por matar o por el sigilo, dependerá de las situaciones. 

A lo largo de la aventura, encontraremos compañeros con diferentes habilidades que ayudarán a Amicia y Hugo en su camino. Al haber pocos personajes importantes, estos poseen de mucha carisma y personalidad, donde podremos conocer sus historias, intenciones y miedos. El uso de la luz es de lo más importante pues los tonos oscuros del juego constantes, contrastan con el uso obligatorio de la luz para ahuyentar a las ratas. Y con eso llegan los pequeños puzzles donde se usarán braseros, fogatas y demás para sortear a las ratas y poder avanzar. Las cinemáticas están hechas in-game y el juego cuenta con modo foto. Podremos encontrar coleccionables por el mundo.

A plague tale no tiene miedo de construir algo diferente, una historia adulta, con un gameplay si bien sencillo, efectivo para la duración del título. Los gráficos son muy bonitos aunque el diseño artístico no es muy variado. Las plagas de ratas impresionan y sientes constantemente que te enfrentas a algo que no puedes controlar. Los tipos de enemigos son muy escasos, caballeros de una época medieval con diferentes armaduras. A veces necesitamos que los juegos sean más guiados, como a plague tale, para enseñarnos llo que el equipo de desarrollo quiere transmitir. 

Si buscas algo corto, narración en vena, plot twist constantes, unos personajes que transmiten y un gameplay sencillo donde deberás darle al coco, entonces juégalo, lo vas a gozar. Lo jugué de salida y ahora he podido pasarlo por segunda vez a 60 fps en mejor calidad que una consola. Había partes que no recordaba y me ha dejado un buen sabor de boca. Tanto como para aventurarme en Requiem, su secuela. Gracias por leer! <3

137806241.review:
Oh, how I loved this game!

Short summary:

Story:			9/10
        (Plot:		9/10)
        (Characters:	9.5/10)
        (Setting:     	8.5/10)
Mechanics:  		3.5/10
        (Combat:       	4/10)
        (Puzzles:         	3/10)
Design:			9/10
       (Graphics:      	9.5/10)
       (Sound:            	8.5/10)

Total Rating: [b]7.5/10[/b] (story counts twice)
Personal (biased) rating: [b]9/10[/b] (since I don’t care too much for the mechanics)

Story:
The Plot in Innocence is very believable, especially when compared to other rpgs or requiem. There are very few inconsistencies (that I could spot) and events feel like, they have meaning. This is true for character deaths (unless you count NPCs), boss fights and often times even the timing, with which the rats are coming - no part feels out of place. It lets us have hope enough, so that the tension can hit hard when it comes. It also doesn’t just keep us in utter despair the entire time, so that we would always know there is no salvation coming, but rather makes us feel, like every bad thing that happens was ultimately avoidable, we were just unlucky, which in my opinion is exactly how you write fate. Plot armour as surprisingly very scarce. Almost every time, someone escapes death, it feels like they did so, because of their own skill, or that of those who saved them. There are a few exceptions to this though, for example [spoiler]the scene, where Amicia hides from arrows under a body[/spoiler]. 

Innocence’s characters are very well written, they have strong motivations and feel like real people. Over the course of the game, you are made to love Amicia, Hugo and the others, learn to hate the inquisition, but also understand, why they are doing, what they are doing. The only exception to this is [spoiler]Milie[/spoiler], as [spoiler]her[/spoiler] motivation feels a little weak at times. Its not too bad and kind of a nit-pick, so only -0.5. Also, every time I died and heard Hugo scream for Amicia, a part of me died inside.

While still great, the setting doesn’t really reach quite as high as plot and characters. The holes it leaves don’t feel intentional and don’t add to any feeling of mystery in my opinion. None the less it is still believable, that such a world could exists, even the politics seem to have logic in themselves. [spoiler]A very nice touch I think was when the archbishop told the inquisitor, he would be excommunicated, it feels like the thing the church would do in a situation like this.[/spoiler]

Mechanics:
This is not the games strong suit! If you’re looking for a game with a good combat system, boss fights and believable stealth, this might not be it. Most of the game doesn’t really challenge the player. There is aim assist (which you can turn of), the guards lose you around two corners and are much slower than you. Most of the game you can clear with just running if you feel like it. The big exception to this is the last boss. There the difficulty does a 180° and the game becomes kinda challenging all of a sudden. Me personally, I liked this, since it added to the feeling of fighting the bbeg, but since you don’t really have to get good at dodging in the rest of the game, I do realize, a lot of people are not gonna enjoy this. The aim assist also feels really clunky when multiple targets are close to each other, the same goes for anything you have to interact with. 
The sling is also very clunky at the start, but that’s probably intentional, since you can upgrade it, which makes it quite a bit better. The alchemy system is the redeeming factor for this game. It gives a lot more depth to the gameplay (both in and out of combat), but not so much, that you can just brute force every encounter with it (as you can in Requiem).
The puzzles are not that big of a challenge either. While the “puzzles” when you consider stealth and rats are a little interesting, since you often have to be wary. The real puzzles often boil down to “do you see this one thing or do you not”, where the solutions are often handfed to you by your companions. 
The interface is very clunky, especially on PC, since they just had to smoothen the mouse. Also: Why can’t I just press F again to see where I’m supposed to go?

Design:
For this, the game speaks for itself, I think. It has the best graphics I have ever seen, not only in the cutscenes, but also during gameplay. There are a lot of repeating textures, probably for recognition, but I still think that could have been just a little better, the same is true of facial expressions in gameplay, though I fear that might be just a little much for our time.
The music is also very good. It gives you exactly the right feeling at the right time (mostly anyway), but you can only hear a song so long until it becomes at least slightly annoying, the repetition is a problem. The effects are on point as well, from the sound of the rats up to the fire, it all sounds real. Same goes for the voice acting, you can really feel the characters emotions. A special shoutout, to who ever came up with the sound for the rats, anytime I listen to a crowd of people far enough away and enough voices so I can’t understand any individual one, I swear it sounds almost exactly like those little beasts!

For me personally, this is one of my favourite games, I’ve ever played, when it comes to story, it is the best one! If you care only for the story you need to buy this game! If you care for both story and gameplay equally, you should still by it, maybe when it’s on sale, depending on how soon you want it. If you don’t care for the story or care much more for the mechanics, youre probably not gonna be happy with this game though, you shouldn’t buy it, I think.

137570561.review:
A Plague Tale: Innocence shows the horrors of a plague-ridden country and the corruption of power in a graphically beautiful narrative.  
- The soundtracks fit very well atmospherically with the story, and the story is well-written and fluid; it doesn't get stale or bogged down. 
- The game is on the shorter side at 15-20 hours, but that's long enough for it to be played out to its fullest.  
- With the game being more narrative focused the combat is not very deep, it serves its purpose and acts more of a puzzle-based combat, if that makes sense; hit point A, fight guard B, otherwise you die.  It's almost like a QRT system.
- The characters are interesting but some of the character relationships fall a bit short and come off as a little shallow.   FYI Roderick is best...fight me.
All in all a very enjoyable game that makes me excited to play the sequel.

9/10

137543935.review: A pretty good game, worth playing once. Not really worth playing again to get all the collectables.

137540654.review:
In the story, we follow Amicia and Hugo, two siblings of royalty, who lose everything after a raid on their village. While on the run from the Inquisition, who desperately want to capture the two children, Hugo grows sicker from a disease with no apparent cure. Amicia drags Hugo across the land to try and get closer to finding a cure, but the Inquisition is not the only dangers in their path.

Throughout the game, you'll either have to rely on stealth or your trusty slingshot which come with different ammunition types which can be helpful for certain circumstances. With sixteen chapters to go through, every chapter is refreshing in my opinion. 

I have two separate copies of Plague Tale: Innocence on Epic Games and Steam so on my second play through, I managed to 100% the game within only 9 hours. The average time for new players should be about 14-16 hours though. I would highly recommend. 

9/10

137518090.review: Narrative focused adventure game set during the black plague. Stealth and puzzle elements. Not the most *fun* game, but quality story!

137511265.review: A great game, an impeccable story that immerses you.

137486310.review: Great story, atmosphere, sounds and characters - looking forward to seeing how they build on it in Requiem.

137446189.review:
An absolute masterpiece. Incredibly well written story, intense atmosphere and great gameplay. The puzzles are pretty basic in the beginning and get harder and harder the farther the story and your arsenal grows - but there are multiple ways to solve them. You get pretty attached to all your characters and companions, you meet throughout your journey. I usually play games in English languague but the german synchronisation was on point.
There was one bug in chapter 6 which was solved pretty quickly via a 20 Seconds google search ;)
Looking forward playing the successor A Plague Tale: Requiem

137428571.review: The game is very liminal and limited.

originally played on GPPC. I got to chapter 6 in the GP version and got soft locked in the tent. I thought maybe it's just the xbox version. I bought the steam version hoping it would work better. I got to chapter 6 and got soft locked in the tent.
10/10 
golden joystick award

137388232.review: Great game. Worth playing. Buy it on sale.

137382947.review: This was an amazing atmospheric game. I loved the storytelling, and the world was absolutely beautiful. The game definitely had more stealth and combat than I was expecting, and my only biggest complaint was that the resources felt so scarce to me that it came to certain times in the game where I didn't want to create something I needed because I felt it would take away from an upgrade I was aiming for which was really frustrating during certain aspects. Besides that, it was really fun and easy to achieve 100% your first time through, another big benefit was the world was very linear which I just loved.

137354206.review:
[h1]TIPO DE JUEGO[/h1]

🔲 Multijugador
🔲 Cooperativo o versus
☑️ Individual

[h1]DIFICULTAD[/h1]

🔲 Aventura visual
🔲 No presenta complicaciones
☑️ Normal
🔲 Compleja
🔲 Desafiante
🔲 Tedioso

[i]El juego no resulta complicado y dispones de muchas herramientas que te condesen segundas oportunidades por si fallas en alguna ocasión, pero nada se hace solo.[/i]

[h1]GRÁFICOS[/h1]

🔲 Malos
🔲 Mediocre
🔲 Tienen su propio estilo
🔲 Buenos
☑️ Hermosos

[i]La calidad gráfica del juego es de alta calidad, los escenarios aprovechan bien la capacidad de texturas que puede llegar a alcanzar.[/i]

[h1]ESTILO VISUAL E INTERFAZ[/h1]

🔲 Desagradable
☑️ Mediocre
🔲 Bella
🔲 Práctica
🔲 Original 

[i]Los elementos de la interfaz no son nada sobresalientes y siempre tratan de estar ocultos para que se aprecie más los escenarios en los que estés.[/i]

[h1]BANDA SONORA Y MÚSICA[/h1]

🔲 Mala
🔲 Mediocre 
☑️ Buena
🔲 Hermosa

[i]La banda sonora es buena y varía bien entre momentos de tensión, tranquilidad y combates. En especial las de tensión que tiene a su vez un toque que la hace fácilmente asociable a este juego.[/i]

[h1]HISTORIA[/h1]

🔲 No tiene historia
🔲 Simplona y/o genérica 
🔲 Rebuscada y confusa
🔲 Mediocre
☑️ Bien escrita
🔲 Intrigante y atrapante

[i]La historia es original y agradable, te da ganas de continuar para saber que ocurrirá pero también tiene sus partes que parecen relleno.[/i]

[h1]PERSONAJES[/h1]

🔲 Vacíos 
🔲 Mediocres 
☑️ Bien logrados 
🔲 Muy carismáticos

[i]Los personajes que van presentando a medida que avanzas son algo genéricos pero llegan a adquirir y sentar bien la base de su personalidad de buena manera.[/i] 

[h1]AMBIENTACIÓN Y ATENCIÓN AL DETALLE[/h1]

🔲 Pobre
🔲 Normal
☑️ Buena inmersión 
🔲 Perfecta

[i]Los escenarios son muy detallados y están muy bien logrados, pero el problema está en que todos estos son zonas super pequeñas o pasilleras.[/i]

[h1]REQUISITOS PARA SER DISFRUTABLE[/h1]

🔲 Bajo
🔲 Medio
☑️ Alto
🔲 Ultra

[i]Uno de los mejores puntos de este juego es la ambientacion lograda por su buena calidad gráfica, si se jugara con estas configuraciones en medio o inferior creería que se perdería la esencia del mismo.[/i]

[h1]DURACIÓN[/h1]

☑️ Corto 
🔲 Normal
🔲 Largo 
🔲 Muy largo
🔲 Sin fin

[i]El juego me duró 8 horas completando solamente la historia principal, tomándome algo de tiempo en revisar las zonas en busca de materiales o para ver los escenarios.[/i]

[h1]GAMEPLAY[/h1]

🔲 Muy aburrido
☑️ Difícil de divertirse 
🔲 Pasable
🔲 Divertido
🔲 Muy disfrutable

[i]El gameplay base consta en ir sigilosamente eliminando los oponentes de las zonas para poder avanzar, si bien desbloqueas muchas maneras de hacer esto a medida que avanzas el nucleo del juego de ir siempre en sigilo termina aburriendo y es poco emocionante entre más tiempo juegas. Aun así las distintas variedades de hacer cada nivel dan muchas posibilidades para que lo hagas como se te ocurra, sin dejarte una única manera de resolverlo.[/i]

[h1]REJUGABILIDAD[/h1]

☑️ Es una experiencia única
🔲 Para completar logros 
🔲 Para ver otras interacciones/decisiones 
🔲 Luego de un buen tiempo
🔲 Infinitamente rejugable

[h1]PRECIO (ARGENTINA 💀)[/h1]

🔲 Gratis
🔲 Mucho más barato de lo que debería
🔲 Barato 
🔲 Normal
🔲 Caro
☑️ Demasiado caro para lo que ofrece 

[i]Recientemente el juego aumentó su precio, y dado a las pocas horas de contenido que ofrecen considero que no vale para nada la pena comprarlo a precio completo.[/i]

[h1]VALE LA PENA COMPRAR[/h1]

🔲 No
☑️ Solo en oferta
🔲 Sí

137330168.review: Not the most complex gameplay, but the story is dark yet heartwarming, the concept is creative, the voice acting is on point. One of the best portrayals of a sibling relationship I've seen. I fell in love with Hugo [strike]and will pretend Requiem doesn't exist.[/strike]

137325064.review:
A plague tale innocence es una aventura narrativa desarrollada por el estudio francés Asobo studio.

La esencia principal del videojuego está en la puesta en escena, que es donde salen a relucir la infinidad de detalles que hay en cada fotograma de esta obra de arte.

Hay una gran variedad de escenarios, lo que rompe con la monotonía y estimula constantemente al jugador con paisajes de ensueño o del mismísimo infierno en la tierra.

El guión es excelente y bastante acertado, teniendo en cuenta la edad y procedencia de nuestros protagonistas, pero son las voces lo que más destaca y no es para menos porque estamos ante un doblaje merecedor de grandes alabanzas.

La banda sonora está compuesta por Olivier Deriviere una eminencia con mucho recorrido en la industria y considero que esta es una de sus mejores creaciones.

Jugablemente es ágil y relativamente fácil, menos algún puzzle que puede resultar enrevesado.

Se lo recomiendo a cualquier amante de los videojuegos.

137300383.review:
Introdução:
A Plague Tale: Innocence chamou minha a atenção pela ideia da trama, ambientada na França medieval e envolvida em torno de hordas de ratos pestilentos, contrastando com os protagonistas, buscando sobreviver e entender o que os cerca num ambiente cada vez mais hostil.

Trama: 
França, 1348-1349. Guerra dos Cem Anos. Peste Negra. Santa Inquisição. Neste contexto, somos apresentados à nobre família De Rune, especialmente a jovem Amicia e seu irmão Hugo, de 5 anos, portador de uma condição que é a chave da trama. O jogo começa ensinando a jogabilidade básica de combate e movimentação num primeiro capítulo tranquilo. Porém, no segundo capítulo já temos a invasão da Inquisição em busca do jovem Hugo, e, dali em diante, um turbilhão de eventos acontecerá com os dois irmãos, passando por diversos ambientes, de vilas a campos, de castelos à campos de batalha. No decorrer dos eventos, aparecem aliados e muitos inimigos, sejam roedores ou humanos, com uma mistura de alquimia, religião, guerra e pestilência, onde inocência vai dando lugar à desolação e busca por respostas e vinganças.

Gráficos:
O jogo apresenta cenários bem detalhados, para o belo e para o mórbido. Seja andando por vilas desertas ou se esgueirando por corpos e ossos, o detalhamento chama a atenção. Mas o destaque principal fica por conta dos ratos. A ninhada explodindo chão acima, passando por cima de corpos e deixando somente ossos, ou formando turbilhões e partindo para cima de você sem medo de nada ocorre com incrível fluidez de movimentos.

Jogabilidade:
O controle de Amicia responde bem. O combate pode não parecer muito dinâmico para alguns, mas a temática do jogo não é muito voltada à ação frenética, pelo contrário, temos muitos momentos de “stealth” e há alternativas entre enfrentar e fugir sem ser visto de inimigos. Nesse ponto, a AI dos inimigos pode vacilar um pouco e perceber você bem longe ou não perceber perto, mas longe de estragar a experiência. Há um modo furtivo e um modo “normal” para lançar pedras e chamar atenção ou ser discreto. O jogo oferece diversas invenções divertidas (e explosivas), com base na alquimia, para lidar com fogos e inimigos.

Som:
Trilha está sempre apropriada ao momento. Momentos de calmaria, como florestas e caminhos durante o dia tem trilhas pacíficas, enquanto combates e hordas de ratos explodindo do chão acima são carregadas de suspense e frenesi musical. 

Prós:
Trama, ambientação e gráficos fora de série. Inovação pelo conceito deste jogo. Campanha com o tempo e dificuldade ideal.

Contras: 
A IA de amigos e inimigos às vezes deixa a desejar. Deixou passar um item colecionável, terá que iniciar o capítulo novamente. Se deixar passar alguns itens, não conseguirá completar os upgrades dos equipamentos antes de concluir o jogo.

Nota: 9,0.

137099725.review:
The "A Plague Tale" Series is by far one of the best Story-based series I have EVER PLAYED! The series is currently short and only contains 2 different games, varying in length and depth! These 2 games, no matter the price are a MUST BUY if you love deep, intense, developing, and even immersive linear story games! The genuine love you see as you develop the years with Amecia and Hugo is unmatched in any other game!

Let's use this review as an OVERALL look at "A Plague Tale", as I believe they are both worth a buy!  ---  in order of course!

                                                                                                                (this will be long)

1st: A Plague Tale: Innocence - 2019
2nd: A Plague Tale: Requiem - 2022

So. "A Plague Tale: Innocence" Starts off as our primary introduction into the series. We start off as a younger Amecia, who is accompanied by her father. Things quickly go wrong. While out hunting with the family dog, Lion, he runs off and gets killed by an unknown entity.

This QUICKLY sets the tone of the game. Throughout the entire journey of the game, you not only develop as a character yourself...but with your companions as-well! During the game, you will have certain friends who will join alongside your journey and help you. These characters all have their own unique personalities and develop dynamically as the story progresses! You will gain a real sense of attachment to characters, as you become a sort of "family" during your constant running, fighting, and hiding over the years. Some characters meant to stay, some meant to go. They all play a very important role on not only the game-play, but the development of the story and other characters as-well.

Let's talk about the game-play aspect of the game! The guts of a game. They're... not bad. It is a stealth game after all. You  have your usual crouching behind or around people. YOU! Hide behind this conveniently placed dresser! OH! HERE! Hide in this perfectly places closet! No, jokes aside, it's not bad. There is a LOT of traversing through levels of enemies where you can either go all out and kill, using your arsenal and the environment around you to your benefit, or you can sneak around all stealthy-like, using tall-grass and building placed around the areas. The game also builds a distraction mechanic to help those players who really want to sneak around without killing! 

Your arsenal in the game is quite slim, but the capabilities extend past their worth! Amecia's main weapon of choice is her trusty Sling, which she uses rocks as a projectile. It is very deadly, at a 1 shot to every enemy which is unarmored. The main combat aspect of game-play revolves around Alchemy. You find and use alchameic powders to craft deadly and even helpful solutions which can be applied many ways! This all ties in directly with the development of the story. Each unique companion in the game also has their own ability you are able to use in your favor!

THIS! Is the main game-play draw. This is what makes A Plague Tale what it is. During the game, there are multiple breakouts of large hordes of rats which can kill you and your companions in an instant. The only way to defend yourself is with fire or light! You will have to use Ignifer, an alchameic solution to light fires to make your way past the hordes of rats. You will run into many puzzles in the game required to advance the story (some hidden optional ones as-well). These puzzles require you to use the environment around you to your advantage. From puzzles, to rats, to enemy encounters, to cut-scenes, to story filler, to exploration... the game really makes sure to fit it all in!

Overall for "A Plague Tale: Innocence", it took me 20 hours to finish. I was 100% invested the entire time and LOVED every second of it! It was one of the most grabbing story games I have ever played. I was honestly sad it was over. It would be a lie to say my emotions were not all over the place during the end of the game, but at-least I had a second game to look forward to!

Now, "A Plague Tale: Requiem". The second installment of the game took what they did right with the first one, and elevated it past the level I even though was possible! I thought I was in love with the story of the first game, but after seeing what we have now... it is hard to judge which is better. They are both amazing!

The story in "A Plague Tale: Requiem" starts right back where "Innocence" left off! You are accompanied by your Mother, Hugo, and Lucas. Thing's have settled and your family is happy again. At a new island, the plague seems to be unheard of...until all hell breaks loose. Just like the last game, you meet new characters which join you alongside your journey. They provide crucial aid to get Amecia and Hugo to find the Cure for the Macula! They help fight and pivot the way through even deadlier, scarier, more advanced hordes of killer rats! "Requiem" adds onto what the De Rune family is trying to accomplish and during the years you develop with these characters, you becomes even more attached as you have now spent hours and hours across multiple game titles with them! Your love and feelings for the protagonists will really make you feel like what hurts them really hurts you. This game really gets to your emotional side!

The game-play is pretty standard compared to the last game, but improved just enough to be interesting and actually really fun! You have your trusty Sling still, but during the story, you will obtain a VERY deadly crossbow! It's... pretty cool. You will have to find bolts around the play areas. You will also be using alchameic powders to craft the same solutions from last game, as-well as the addition of tar! Tar can be used against enemies or rats, whichever you prefer!

SKILLS! This game added the Skill Tree Mechanic. What this does is passively progresses you down a certain skill tree based on your play style. There are 3 different skill paths you can go; Prudence, Aggressive, Opportunism. These all will grant you increasingly helpful buffs as you reach a 25% threshold mark. This adds for a variety of very different and unique play styles! (You can also find SECRET CHESTS on select levels!)

Overall, "A Plague Tale: Requiem" follows a lot of the same story elements and principles as the first game. It progresses the story to what could be a possible completion, or hopefully what will be a 3rd installment of the game... way in the future :( However, I can wait! This game managed to bring me even more closely immersed into the story than I would've imagined possible! I was fighting every moment to keep everyone alive like I was there myself! The upgraded game-play really helped to keep me interested and wasn't as stale as "Innocence". 

I am a man, and I am more than okay to admit I cried hard at the end of the game. Harder than Red Dead Redemption 2... that says something... This game created a story that was so deeply developed and so real you could feel it as a person through the game. You felt real hurt and emotion when the character you loved, dies. 

The "A Plague Tale" Series is something that is like nothing else. You see character development and such a deep story that will leave you feeling empty after you finish the games. It was such a wonderful and amazing series that I could not believe such a small indie studio was able to put together such a beautiful masterpiece! This has by far been some of my favorite games of all times and I really hope we will see another continuation!

Make sure to use Photo Mode! Both games are incredibly gorgeous and you can use it to your advantage to get some incredible shots, which would otherwise be impossible! (Special shout-out to the beautiful character models and voice actors! It was all amazing and really made it fit so much better together!) 

Buy the "A Plague Tale" Series!!!                                                                               (: Thanks for the read :)

137025396.review:
[h1] I love Amicia [/h1]

La historia se desarrolla en la Francia medieval, durante la Peste Negra, y sigue a dos hermanos, Amicia y Hugo. 

[spoiler]Amicia se da cuenta de que Hugo tiene una conexión muy especial con las ratas, capaz de comunicarse y controlarlas, mientras más avanzas se da cuenta de que esta enfermedad es el resultado de un experimento fallido de la Inquisición, quienes intentaron crear una cura para la plaga utilizando la sangre de Hugo y otros niños.[/spoiler] 

[b] Lo positivos:[/b] 

1. La trama es bien escrita y conmovedora, con personajes bien desarrollados y una atmósfera inmersiva.
2. El sistema de juego es emocionante, con una combinación de sigilo, exploración y puzzles que te mantiene enganchado en todo momento.
3. Los gráficos son impresionantes, con entornos detallados y realistas y una iluminación impresionante, cada lugar se siente único. Además, la música y los efectos de sonido son inmersivos, lo que ayuda a generar una atmósfera tensa y emocionante. 

[b] Lo negativos:[/b] 

1. A pesar de que la mecánica del juego es emocionante, puede volverse monótono después de un tiempo, especialmente en los momentos de sigilo.
2. El juego es corto , lo que puede ser decepcionante para algunos.
3. Algunos de los elementos de la historia pueden resultar predecibles o clichés y bastantes wtf xD .

En lo personal me gusto bastante y amicia ufff joder amicia.

137002036.review:
It’s not really a game, more of an extended Quicktime event.  It reminded me of a more complicated Dragon’s Lair except I had to do all the walking around myself.  Stealth sections with Hugo were especially annoying.

The graphics are “ok” on a 3080 with everything on Ultra, but the overuse of bloom was quite annoying.

Story is also “ok”, with cookie cutter villains - which would have been fine in an over the top JRPG but fairly incongruous in a game that takes itself super seriously.

Overall, pretentious and just “eh”.  TLOU while also very linear at least had some fun moments to be had - this is one step up from a visual novel which is fine if you’re into that kind of thing, but the story isn’t anything to write home about (utterly forgettable).

136993057.review:
I'm not gonna lie I got bored playing this game & ended up reaching chapter 10 before thinking to myself why am I even playing this? If you played any of Naughty Dog's cinematic experience games that Sony has pushed such as Uncharted and TLOU then you most likely played all of their competition's knockoffs that repeat the same formula as TLOU (Most recent example is the God of War reboots that to me are overrated) including this game. Games where instead of telling a good story & being more gameplay focused usually target the casual audience that want quick feels. I'm here to tell you that the only way to even tolerate the voice acting in this game is to either change the language to German or French. None of these characters at all are intriguing until Chapter 7 sort of when the game finally gives you the independence not to sneak around anymore since the stealth is the same as any other triple A game. Hiding in grass means you're instantly hidden, the enemy AI is dumb as rocks & the aiming system is very poor (especially for CQC) to the point that the problem could've been easily solved if Amicia during the game found a knife of some kind to defend herself.

Hugo while believable in his actions is still annoying through the entire time playing the game. An entire game as an escort mission while at the same time dealing with uninteresting side characters is not a good mix as a game to me. Even the PC performance despite all its patches doesn't even run 60 fps well even with high settings on. [spoiler]The story itself to me is a stretch that the inquisition gave a shit about one boy and it should've been developed better about why this specific boy is more important than any of the other people sick during the plague.[/spoiler]

The puzzles while simple are also repetitive. Why Amicia can't throw her torch or sticks to the side characters makes no sense & the only time I was somewhat invested was the castle puzzle since every other puzzle was a bore. Even the upgrading is restricted and the devs constructed it in a way so that they only give you crumbs on when to upgrade the exact same way the storytelling is. It's quite a chore just to keep checking your menu due to this regressive game design. Even if you try to break the path the devs made you're not rewarded for anything for exploring by yourself. Just crappy collectibles that don't add much to the worldbuilding at all and not even lore either.

Throughout the game you meet a kid who knows alchemy that tags along with you after story related reasons. Why the hell do I have have to sacrifice my materials when he could've easily gave me spare materials or light faraway torches for me? I swear the only useful character was this thief kid you meet for story reasons because she at least can unlock chests and doors for you so why couldn't the alchemist kid be more useful?

Overall if you want my rating, it's a hard pass and not even worth the money during a sale. The only positives that I can give are the rat mechanics and the skippable cutscenes since for some pretentious reason these modern games believe their story is so interesting that the player shouldn't have the option to skip cutscenes at all.

I got this together with the sequel, Requiem. Looking at trailers and reviews I was expecting a good looking game, I found a fantastic story (albeit very grim and not for the faint of heart) and very likeable characters.

I took 12 hours to finish the story at normal difficulty, but as always, your mileage may vary.

If you care for either thing, there is NO multiplayer mode nor a NewGame+. You can replay from any chapter you have unlocked, so you can get all the collectables you missed on your first run.

Buy this if you want to enjoy a very gripping supernatural story set in the Middle Ages. Don't treat this like a hardcore action game and I guarantee you will have a great time.

My vote for this game: [b]8/10[/b].

Got this on sale and after playing it, i wish i could've bought it at its full price. IT IS REALLY GOOD! 

I love the dynamic between Amicia and Hugo, they really captured what it feels like to have a little brother, because i too have a brother like Hugo. Of course minus the rat part HAHAHA. The story is phenomenal, you have this characters power through this unfortunate events using there wits and their problem solving. You really get attached to them. The side characters as well are very well written, they're not just passing by and then not have a role after, they play a huge part of the story as well. Overall, the story is chef's kiss!

The way the combat works is very well made and it makes sense since you're this unarmed kids who just trying to get away from the bad guys. You're not this powerful knight who can easily defeat your foes, you have to strategize your moves, as well as your resources. You have to be very careful with your moves as well, which makes the gameplay all the more exciting and scary, because every enemies in the game will insta kill you. 

I wish i played this game sooner, because i really had a good time. I laughed, i cried, i got scared, and i had fun! This game has a special place in my heart <3

A Plague Tale: Innocence is seriously one of the coolest games I've played in a long time! The story is super intense and emotional, following these two siblings trying to survive in a medieval world full of rats and the Inquisition. And the graphics are seriously stunning - they really make you feel like you're there in the game, dodging rats and trying to sneak past enemies. 

But what I love most about the game is the relationship between Amicia and Hugo - it's just so heartwarming and touching. And the puzzles and stealth elements keep the gameplay interesting and engaging throughout. I'd say if you're looking for a game with a killer story and beautiful visuals, A Plague Tale: Innocence is definitely worth checking out. Just make sure you're not too squeamish about rats...

136558114.review:
This is a little bit of a tough one. The setting and initial idea is really good and I can't objectively say it's a bad game, cause it's absolutely not, but I just can't deny there are so many flaws. 

- First, why go with the supernatural crap when you had such a unique setting not usually explored in games. The story could have been grounded in reality and tell what really happened at that time of history, but instead we get rat tornadoes.
- Too many instant deaths. Many of them ruin very emotional moments by having to play them all over again several times. This is specially true in the last chapters.
- The actual gameplay is pretty poor. Just kill the guards by exactly the way the game intends you to, since they are strategically positioned to be killed in said way. Also, the puzzles are so simple and boring that only serve to pad out the game.
- Honestly too long. Considering the tedious gameplay, it could have ended half way through or have shorter sections, since the most important parts where the cut scenes. 

Despite all those flaws, the first part of the game is really good and overall it has very touching moments. Amicia is a great character and Hugo is the sweetest and most likable kid that I've ever seen in a game. I basically only played till the end to see how everything wrapped up for them, specially poor Hugo, not because it was an enjoyable playing experience per se.

Overall a great game. Good graphics, nice story (although more in depth info and lore would have been welcome, I feel like most of it was barely brushed on the surface). The mechanics sometimes feel a bit clumsy, but this is no AAA studio so they work just fine for the size of the studio. The voice actors did a great job,  Amicia's french and english voice actors did great, though some of the lines, especially Rodrick's take-down lines are so macho cliché it's a shame. Hugo is a bit of an exception, most of his lines and conversations are a pain to listen to, so much that you have trouble relating to him. The only part where I enjoyed him was when you get to play him alone since it actually feels like lines a scared boy would say and it wasn't just him constantly whining.
I did enjoy the possibility to make the game as bloody as you want it to be. If you wanna rely on stealth and lurk in the shadows, that's fine, but if you wanna kill every last one of them, it's also a possibility.

136394317.review: Amazing story. The face expressions of the characters needs improves.

136389727.review:
A Plague Tale: Innocence is a strong example of a game that doesn't know what it wants to accomplish. At times, it seems like the game wants to be a stealth platformer like Assassins Creed/Dishonored, but then the next minute all hell breaks loose and you're forced into scripted chase sequences with no variation or choice. The many puzzles in the game are mind-numbingly easy and the time you spend completing them takes up about 80% of actual gameplay time. 

The story itself is packed with cliches that anyone who has seen more than a handful of movies will recognize from a mile away (your family is dead/younger sibling has a secret power/textbook revenge plot), and the lack of a lengthy buildup to the story means that there is little actual reason to care for the early deaths (within 10 minutes of the game beginning) of your character's family, which initiates the entire story. 

Your brother is completely insufferable, making most dialogue scenes with him tedious at best. There's also some highly questionable storyline choices involving your brother that similarly grind the game's pacing to a halt, especially around the middle section of the plot. 

The game's two redeeming qualities are the voice acting of the protagonist, Amicia, and the atmospheric settings. While the level design doesn't inspire much imagination due to its backtracking and repetition, the atmosphere is actually quite effective at making you feel claustrophobic, paranoid, and isolated - which are all central themes of the story. 

Overall, I can't really recommend this game to anyone, since I'm not sure who the targeted audience of this game was supposed to be. It doesn't accomplish anything new in the way of storytelling, the worldbuilding itself is limited, the level design is so simple it's grating, and the few standout setpieces of the story don't last long when compared to the endless puzzle sequences that compose the majority of the game's runtime.

Just finished the game. To me it's one of the best games I played - ever. Stunning visuals (to my taste at least), great voice acting, awesome game optimisation. Only 2 bugs in the whole game (I couldn't get out of the tent in the British camp but restarting from checkpoint solved it, and the other bug was just missing sounds of falling rats in a particular part of the game but I don't want to spoil anything). 
The story was gripping from start to finish, and at times made me emotional, so I completed the game in, I think, 2 or 3 days.

136326870.review:
An incredible game. 

The story takes place during a plague outbreak spread by rats, the events are not entirely realistic but taken as the experience of frightened children running for their lives wherever they go, realism gives way to the sheer effort and diligence that went into the atmosphere of terror, confusion and at times complete hopelessness.

The dialog is anything from helpful to me as a clueless player, missing something in a simple puzzle, to addressing serious issues and tough situations with great voice acting on all involved characters and in multiple languages, and heartwarming, childish conversations that build the character off each other in a way I can only describe as incredible.

Hidden items had me running around for way longer than I should have just because I wanted to hear the genuine reactions of the characters without looking up a guide first.

Every word (or damn close to it) feels impactful, every little stutter, every little thing that happens has a reaction.

The gameplay is quite simple and linear, but some materials (and those amazing little dialogs) can be gained from exploring areas just a bit out of the way. Although absolutely none of them are needed to comfortably finish the story as it relies heavily on careful movement and short puzzles than quick reaction times (edit: the last chapter is a bit different, but you'd probably have some upgrades by the time you get there anyway).
It's one of those games you play at 20 fps (please don't, but you get my point), like an interactive movie just to get that one perfect screenshot and enjoy the quality of the writing (even if the events themselves are sad at times).

It quickly became one of my great examples of a simple puzzle game made great by good writing or a well-written and performed movie series adapted to be playable.

135982686.review:
39.5 Hours played to completion and 100% achievement
Played on Steam with Logitech GamePad
Purchased on sale 1/31/2023 for $7.99

This was a great game. It is a bit linear in play, and definitely not an "Open World" experience - however, the game play and story telling are absolutely fantastic. The voice acting and Mocap animation make the "kids" very real - which amps up the tension with them in peril.  I had heard a lot of good things about the game, but some people equated almost to a graphic novel based on the linear play - but it still felt like a game to me, though they are correct, there is no variation in the story line, you just work your way through it... still I was okay with that and actually pleasantly surprised by how engrossing the game is (especially the first time through). However, because of the linearity, I would suggest getting it on sale rather than paying the full $40 ticket price. It is often on sale on multiple platforms for $9.99 and that seems quite reasonable.

I was expecting it to be a bit more "real history", and it was actually a second pleasant surprise that... how to say this... it wanders quite far away from "reality" by the end of the game and becomes something more than "just survive the plague". They did fill the game with little side things to find and read about that provided some historical background on "The Plague" and which if you are a completionist like Jackie and I pretty much guarantees at least two playthroughs just to find all the stuff and get the achievements. 

In our case we finished the game and had found most of the side things on the first play through in around 18 hours. If you just focus on the story line and play through the first time it may depend on your game skills but 8 to 12 hours seems easily possible for most gamers (Watched Gab Smolders play after we completed it and it took her about 8.5 hours but she missed all kinds of things). Many people complete the achievements as well under the 20 hour mark - but we replayed the entire game trying to find it all without any assist - and on levels where the 2nd pass didn't find the stuff then we looked for a bit of help and then played the chapter a 3rd (sometimes 4th) time.

Very much look forward to the second game "Requiem", but will wait for a sale as there are a ton of other games to play already in the library.

135899326.review:
[b] "A Plague Tale: Innocence" is an absolute gem of a game industry that truly captures the essence of a gripping and immersive narrative. From the very beginning, the game hooks you in with its beautifully crafted visuals and hauntingly atmospheric soundtrack, transporting you to a world that is both stunningly beautiful and deeply unsettling.

The game takes place in 14th century France during the height of the Black Death, and the setting is expertly crafted to convey a sense of desperation and despair. The environments are beautifully rendered, with each location telling its own story through subtle details and intricate design.

But it's not just the visuals that make "A Plague Tale: Innocence" such a standout game. The characters are expertly written, with each one feeling like a fully-realized individual with their own unique motivations and backstories. The relationship between the main characters, siblings Amicia and Hugo, is particularly well-developed and serves as the emotional core of the game.

The gameplay is equally impressive, seamlessly blending stealth, puzzle-solving, and action elements into a cohesive whole. The use of light and sound as gameplay mechanics is especially clever, adding a level of tension and strategy to every encounter.

But what really sets "A Plague Tale: Innocence" apart is its storytelling. The game manages to tackle weighty themes like loss, grief, and sacrifice with sensitivity and nuance, making for a deeply affecting experience that lingers long after the credits roll.

Overall, "A Plague Tale: Innocence" is a truly divine game that deserves all the praise it has received. From the stunning visuals to the expertly crafted characters and narrative, everything about this game is top-notch. If you're looking for a beautiful, atmospheric, and emotionally resonant gaming experience, look no further than "A Plague Tale: Innocence".

"A Plague Tale: Innocence" is a game that I highly recommend! I can't wait to play the second part of this game! [/b]

I feel like the run and hide moments are the best parts of the game, and the story sucks you in right away with a Game of Thrones level of bleakness, but then you get goofy parts like boss fights where you have to undress a fully armored knight by knocking his buckles off with rocks. I probably could have stuck it out, but I had one too many failures that flung me backwards to a checkpoint where I had to do lengthy sequences of tasks over and over just to get back to the one critical point where I failed. Worth checking out if you're more patient than I am (which is not very patient.)

This is a gem hidden in the rough. It's hard to point out what exactly it is that holds this game back from being a masterpiece, but while the concept is good, the execution is shoddy. The game is very clunky at times, and the pacing is very, very slow, to the point where I was almost ready to give up the game more than halfway through. However, combat itself is very fun, and there is a particular skill that you unlock almost at the end of the game that I really had a blast with. The graphics are acceptable for their time, and the ambience is great - in fact, at one point you come across a battlefield [spoiler]littered with dead soldiers[/spoiler], which was so well designed that it really shocked me. However, as much as I liked what the writers were trying to do, we were not truly given enough time to bond with characters, nor was the acting phenomenal enough to get feelings across, so that when a character dies and we are meant to be shocked, you will never quite feel that.

Nonetheless, it's an interesting concept, and definitely worth a try. Just make sure you buy it on sale. 5/10
