135262359.review:
A plague's Tale is set during the 100 year war in the 1300's and the plague is in full flow.
The sheer number of rats on screen truly makes your stomach turn and made this game quite unique.
The story was interesting especially watching the De Runes going from nobility to losing everything in an instant and their constant struggle through the 12 hour playtime.

Unfortunately I personally didn't really care for the De Rune's too much and the villains were very one dimensional to the point where I'd seen them in numerous other media.
The fact that enemies wouldn't react to a fellow guard being eaten alive by rats right next to them could also take you out of the immersion.

On the whole though this was an intriguing tale made on a budget far removed from a AAA title, this was evident by the visuals which range from good to serviceable but the setting and level design make up for this as did the storytelling and the lead characters relationship with the rats as the game unfolded. 

If you have the time and inclination to fit this game into your schedule then I would recommend it. Whilst some of the game has a been there seen that vibe too it (location, predictable enemies) there are unique parts too (The rat concept, complex sibling relationship).

I will be playing the sequel at some point so this title did enough to consider me invested.

135119131.review:
4/10 It's just meh. My rating is heavily based on character/story, less on gameplay.

STORY:
I honestly was kind of expecting more. It's about two siblings during the black plague being hunted by the inquisition, but it wasn't as compelling or emotional as I thought it was. I couldn't find myself caring about either of the two main characters. As far as the rest of cast, honestly didn't really like them either except Rodric. At first I thought that maybe it's because this is a 10-15 hour game, and you don't really get a whole lot of time with the characters, but then again, Rodric is the last character to join your party, maybe halfway through the game, and I liked him. Maybe it's just the way the characters were written, but I just couldn't empathize.

GAMEPLAY:
This is a stealth game through and through. There are stealth mechanics and sometimes puzzle mechanics. It's all stuff you've probably seen before: tall grass to hide in, suspicious/alert guards, noise diversions, dumb AI, etc. The new things here are the rats and light interaction, and the different alchemy potions you can craft for different effects. Lots of collectibles for those with OCD. Also lots of crafting materials everywhere for your stealth crafting needs.

ART:
Definitely the highlight for me. It looks and sounds good. English voice acting is okay. The creepier elements definitely stood out. Lots of gory details, dark hallways full of rats, etc.

135080150.review:
Diving into the Kingdom of France of the year 1348 was the history lesson I've always wanted. Where the black plague makes it's grim debut as well as Amicia De Rune and her younger brother Hugo.

The relationship between Amicia and Hugo felt genuinely natural and at times very entertaining as Hugo would make funny remarks to lighten the mood as they constantly fight for their lives. The game does a superb job of delivering a compelling story with excellent character development.

Visually the game is a masterpiece and will have you stopping multiple times to either enjoy the French country side or gasp in horror of the aftermath brought on by both the Inquisition and the rising plague.

Gameplay is intuitive and the combat while limited, still made the game enjoyable, especially when using Hugo's special abilities. The AI of the enemies were very one dimensional and weren't much of a challenge during the stealth missions but the pace at which this game is played along with the amazing voice acting in a way makes up for this.

If you're reading this review and having second thoughts about playing this game. PLAY IT! It is an emotional roller coaster that will grip you from the start and won't let go.... Like a rat gripping onto that stale piece of cheese you dropped and rolled behind the couch.

134527910.review:
Narrating the emotional story of a sibling in a plague-stricken environment, this game becomes an impressive experience with all its problems.

The relationships between the characters, especially the relationship between Amicia and Hugo, are completely human, believable, and far from the artificial and exaggerated stimulation of the players' emotions.

The antagonists of the game, unlike its positive characters, are one-dimensional and even stereotyped characters, which has a bad effect even on the ending of the game.

A Plague Tale: Innocence does a great job in creating an impressive atmosphere centered around a plague-ridden and cruel world, and the excellent music and graphics help the game in this regard.

The gameplay mechanics, from the stealth parts to the rat-fighting parts and the puzzles, are interesting the first few times but become repetitive over time.

But a final question; Is A Plague Tale: Innocence worth playing? My answer to this question is the same as we mentioned before and it depends on your taste as a video game audience.

If you are one of those people who are very interested in hearing a good story in games, enjoy watching the relationships between the characters being depicted, and are especially interested in works with a heavy and impressive atmosphere, you will definitely enjoy playing A Plague. You will have a lot of fun with Tale: Innocence, and maybe even the story weaknesses of this game will not be as important to you as they should be.

But if your goal in gaming is to enjoy fun and engaging gameplay, and you expect A Plague Tale: Innocence to be a high-quality stealth experience in this regard, this work will not be able to meet your expectations of such an experience and its mechanisms. Maybe they will appeal to you for an hour or two.

Strengths
+ Excellent characterization of the game's positive characters.
+ Deep, impressive and logical story.
+ Very beautiful artistic graphics.
+ Audible and perfectly suitable music for the mood of the game.
+ The overall atmosphere is very believable and realistic.

weak points
- Completely one-dimensional and stereotypical negative characters.
- Repetition of the process of hiding the game.
- The uniformity of most puzzle solving mechanisms.
- The inefficiency of features such as the possibility of upgrading equipment.

Score: 7.5/10

134513517.review:
[h1] A Plague Tale [/h1]

A Plague Tale is a refreshing break from other grim and brutal narrative-driven games on the market, with beautiful details in the world and story rich historical fiction it is truly unique. As of recent this has been one of the best immersive story games I have played; I absolutely adore the connection to the historical events of the Justinian and Bubonic plagues. While I was not expecting the heavy amount of gore included, the settings where corpses can be found are both unsettling and extremely detailed but very idiosyncratic. I'm very excited to move on to the second game of this newer generation series. 

[h1] Historical Context [/h1]

I got so excited to find a historical fiction rooted 'horror' game, especially with the unique supernatural spin on the infamous plague carrying rats. Without giving spoilers to the secrets we learn carried by these rats and the Inquisitions obsession to Hugo there is a lot to be said about this plague. This game heavily takes influence to many deadly plagues that occurred through history, some to include for reference in my opinion but are not limited to;
[list]
    [*]The Justinian Plague (541 A.D)
    [*]The Black Plague (1347)
    [*]The Italian Plague (1629)
    [*]The Bubonic Plague (1720)
[/list]
In this case, the Plague we see in this game begins in 1348 in medieval France, and is referred to as 'The Bite'. Historically this plague lands in the path of the Hundred Years' War fought from 1337-1453 between the French and English for power of the French aristocratic throne. The game has heavy details and notions of the war from commentary to accurate visuals. One detail I was blown away by was the entirety of Chapter 5, 'The Raven's Spoils'. this entire chapter is the characters struggle to make it across a battle field riddled of bodies, rats, and abandoned siege equipment for what seems like forever. This battle field was supposed to be a recreation or at least take heavy inspiration of The Battle of Crecy; one of the bloodiest battles of the affair that lasted 116 years. Without giving much more away, it's easy to say i'm obsessed with the historical accuracy and little hints too historical events in this story. 

[h1] Characters [/h1]

I really enjoyed the set of young protagonists given in the game, especially watching the growth and development of their bonds and loyalty to one another. A set of characters I especially enjoyed seeing a dynamic character progression with was that of the De Rune siblings. In the prologue and first chapter of the game where we are introduced to Amisia, we learn she lacks a connection with her younger brother, Hugo. Through the story, we see the growth of their bond as the 'Macula' continues to take over Hugo. All of the characters were unique and dynamic, from the band of kids the De Rune siblings accompany to the unique enemies of the Inquisition. Overall the unique narrative and plot was immersive and brought to life by these characters. [b] 10/10 [/b]

134445468.review:
I'm pretty picky about my games, maybe even nitpicky. I don't know. But I do know why I couldn't get into Plague Tale.

It's a beautiful game and the story and characters are engaging, almost.
The scenery is gorgeous, the voice acting well done, the story interesting and the pacing pretty good as well.
So why'd I quit?

Two reasons, the first was the gameplay. It got old way to fast for me. The sneaking mechanics are absurd to the point of breaking immersion and repetitive. The whole, throw rocks and pots to distract guards is unbelievable and not very exciting. I don't mind escorting my kid brother through army encampments but don't pretend I'm invisible and silent because their backs are turned even though we're three feet a part. Once or twice stretches the imagination but this is the core of the sneaking mechanic.

The rat/darkness levels are hardly any better, why do thousands of rats forget about you to eat a sack full of meat when there are literally piles of carcasses everywhere? The epitome of this is wandering through the aftermath of a battlefield, literally climbing over piles of bodies and then shooting down a hanged man for the rats to devour so that you can walk past them. It breaks the immersion. And it gets old fast, the sling is neat but the puzzles are all the same so there's no reason to keep doing them over and over again.

Lastly, it's hard for me to feel emotionally engaged with the main character when she wantonly murders and sacrifices other people to achieve her own goals, and not even in ways that make sense. I get that she's just a kid who isn't good at reasoning through consequences, but maybe you should walk around instead of driving the rats to devour people who have nothing to do with you. It seems she's mildly upset the first time she kills someone (who's actually attacking her) but then goes on to dispatch of enemies Assassin's Creed style even when she could just go around them. It wouldn't really bother me if this was the story of a battle hardened soldier or an assassin instead of a little girl trying to escape.

Remember, you're killing soldiers, English and French and the occasional villager not bandits or orcs. It kinda destroyed my interest in the story which was the only part of this game I was really engaged with.

134278174.review:
A Plague Tale is an excellent AA game about a brother and sister during the Hundred Years' War between England and France. It's a fictionalised account of the Black Death (or the Plague) with an interesting supernatural twist. So, the first strength of this game is the clear passion from behind the scenes. There's something about AA or indie titles where you can see just the clear passion on screen. The scope is focused, it isn't a meandering mess and overall, a well-paced adventure. From just a graphical perspective it's better than most last-generation games (and even this generation). This is a combination of high-quality assets, beautiful lighting, stunning art direction and fitting music. There is a considerable amount of period piece architecture that's breathing taking to experience. From the churches and paintings like during Byzantine Empire and so forth. As this was before the Renaissance, so overall the world is rich and lived in. The developers take advantage of the diversity of the world.

My favourite chapter location would be chapter 5, It’s like seeing a terrible period in history at its worst. Without any glorification, just that dread, the sound design of walking through ... the lighting particularly makes it feel uncomfortable and sort of claustrophobic. It just showcases the vulnerability you have so well and makes this plague even more frightening as there’s so little you can do. When you start up the game, I think the ICO inspiration is fairly obvious, especially in terms of its design for Escort missions. Hugo isn't an intangible, like from games such as The Last of Us or Bioshock Infinite, but a character in gameplay you have to hold their hand and take care of. There is definitely more the developers could have done, to make it even more immersive but I do applaud the effort in general, compared to many game developers who don't bother adding a basic feature (like this) in general. This remedy does expose some weaknesses when it comes to AI. The brain-dead AI is a curse and a blessing in disguise because from a mechanical perspective, it’s pretty brain-dead, but the stealth of the game is far from great, so I guess it makes it a less frustrating experience. The weaker levels were the ones that had to rely on those mechanics except one which I won't spoil besides stating it was very good.

The crafting is pretty much the same as the Last of Us which the developers openly stated it's the reason they could make the game, as these games would be financially viable. So, this is the first obvious homage and others that are scattered throughout the game. I think what was truly satisfying was the sling, yeah it does the majority aiming for you, but man the recoil is very good. Especially as you upgrade it.

The writing across the board is strong, especially some good character writing. Both in and out of gameplay, the relationship between the siblings is enhanced because of how you treat each other in gameplay. Simple stuff like holding Hugo when he is scared, or tired or him putting a flower above your ear. Though I do admit I think there's some odd audio editing. Like sometimes characters respond so awkwardly and less to do the actor but the editing. Generally, there was some funkiness to it. I'm unsure what the cause of the weirdness but it does appear briefly.

In Conclusion, this is a fantastic AA game that's worth experiencing and I would highly recommend it. I’m curious where the sequel would go considering the ending is quite closed and as a whole satisfying.

133950662.review:
*This review doesn't contain big spoilers, but some basic information that may or may not want to be explored before reading this review*

What an amazing game. From start to finish, I was engaged in the story. Each character felt necessary towards the story, and wasn't just used as a "tool." The people that were lost along the way felt like I was actually feeling the emotions the characters were feeling. 

Pros
- The graphics are insanely well done. It feels like I was truly inside of the game at every step of the way. To add to that, the visuals in the distance were portrayed REALLY well. Seeing the massive church (I forgot what it was called) in the distance at the end, just before fighting Vitaly was unbelievable.
- The story telling was extremely intriguing and engaging. I wanted to progress through the story and figure out what the Inquisition wanted with me, and I was curious to understand the story behind these zombie rats.
- The plague was portrayed perfectly, with the crosses on the doors along the way to represent the infected, and obviously the tremendous amounts of zombie-like rats.
- The voice actors were almost perfect. The only thing that I will say is sometimes I got mixed up with Amicia and Mellie, but it didn't happen often (and could've been avoided altogether with subtitles w/ names on).
- Important fights (boss fight at the end especially) wasn't incredibly difficult like some games in this genre. I love story games with fights that you don't want to pull each individual hair out for.

Cons
- I really wish the game was longer. As much as I feel the time frame of the game fit the story being told, I was really sad once I completed the game (I know there is a second game, and I will be buying it shortly). Also, I spent maybe 10-12 hours on the game, not 19. I fell asleep with the game open, which bumped up the hours quite a bit
- Sometimes, being stealthy was extremely difficult. The one that really frustrated me was when we first met Mellie and had to escape all the guards (with the tents and everything). I tried to be stealthy for about 30 minutes with no luck, and eventually I accidentally completed it just by making it to the halfway point and b-lining it towards the cutscene checkpoint (which i didn't actually realize it was where i stepped). Of course, this was before I had learned a lot of the abilities in the game, I think all I had were rocks at that point (maybe a few other abilities that weren't useful to me at the time)

Overall though, it's one of the best games I've played in a LONG time. I have a hard time getting through most story games, but this one I did not want to put down. It was the only thing on my mind for a couple days getting home from work. Like I said earlier, I will be buying the second game soon, and I have high hopes for it.

133863656.review:
A great example of a type of game you don't get enough of any more: a linear, single-player adventure that's all about the atmosphere, the story and the setpieces and doesn't feel the need to shoehorn in an open world or a load of pointless side quest 'content' just for the sake of padding the game out. I completed it in 13 hours and didn't feel short-changed.

Medieval France made a nice change from the usual well-trodden videogame settings - there's a really strong sense of place and I can highly recommend setting the audio to French with English subtitles to enhance the mood further (although this does have the slightly odd side-effect of making the English soldiers you'll meet in a couple of levels grumble to each other in French - would have been good to have an option for all characters to speak in the appropriate language for the scene, with subtitles where necessary).

And it is a beautiful game as well - the architecture in some areas is stunning, which again adds to the sense of time and place.

That said, this is very much a fantasy game in a historical setting (which isn't immediately apparent from the trailer/store page) - if you're expecting a realistic depiction of a Black Death style plague you're going to come away disappointed but the story is well paced to ground the player in the historical aspects of the setting before introducing those fantasy elements.

I could certainly have lived without the boss fights, and there were one or two annoying difficulty spikes, but overall an excellent game and I'll be checking out the sequel.

133838249.review:
Excellent game from French indie developer Asobo Studios that punches well above its weight. Set in 14th century France during the 100 Years War, A Plague Tale's compelling story weaves a realistic and gritty medieval setting with fantastical elements in a way which never feels overdone. This game is an admirable feat of medieval fantasy that strikes a perfect balance between realism, and an exciting originality in an over-saturated and often tired genre. 

 The characters are well written, and major props goes to the voice actors of both Amicia and Hugo. I played the game in both French and English, and while there's great performances in both languages, the French voice actors really stole the show. I really recommend playing this game in French for an experience that is as close as possible to what the dev's envisioned. 

For me personally, the creative art direction of this game should take centre-stage. Despite being an older game now, the environments are gorgeous. I ran the game on a Nvidia GeForce RTX 3080 and was blown away by the detailed, mesmerising and sometimes horrifying set pieces in this game.  This game was no doubt a labour of love and it shows, it's one of the prettiest and immersive worlds I've experienced in a while

The gameplay is great too, and for those of you who are less interested in the setting and plot, and perhaps players more interested in stealth-orientated gaming, with light puzzle solving and a bit of combat will find enough here to keep them interested. I say enough because there are moments where this game feels a little jankey, with some very cheap deaths leading to some frustrating moments. These moments are few and far between; however, with the majority of the game loop being seriously fun. 

The developers have done an awesome job at making the gameplay add to the sense that Amicia and Hugo are very vulnerable in a very dangerous world. You'll never feel overpowered in this game, and I like that. 

My only other criticism of the gameplay is that there is often only one way to progress through a level or encounter, which means that you WILL die. Over and over again until you find the 'right' route through the level. 

This game is excellent, and if you're also late to the Plague party like I was, please do yourself a favour and give this thing a whirl - you won't regret it. Bravo to the developers. Can't wait to play Requiem.

133739497.review:
I can't help but draw comparisons to Life is Strange 2. Both Amicia and Sean are fiercely dedicated to their younger brothers, Hugo and Daniel, respectively (and get blamed for not being the perfect ones for most of the time). While it's admirable to see siblings looking out for each other, I couldn't help feeling a bit sad about the situation. Amicia and Sean are just teenagers themselves who need care and leadership from elder ones as well, and yet they're burdened with so much responsibility.

Amicia especially seems to have been thrust into the role of protector, with little time to pursue her own interests or seek her own way to live. When Hugo gets himself into trouble by sneaking out and trying to rescue his mother, it becomes painfully clear that they only have each other to rely on as they seem to be the only two family members left alive. The mother has never even once shown solicitude for Amicia but merely disinterest. I did not even feel it heartwarming when they bonded together, for Amicia does not belong to the ship.

What really gets to me is the contrast between Amicia and Hugo's upbringings. Amicia seems to have been told from a young age to be the responsible one, while Hugo has been encouraged to be himself and live by his own power instead of for others. It creates a stark divide between them that's hard to ignore, even during the game's quieter moments.

All in all, A Plague Tale is a beautifully crafted game, but the relationship between Amicia and Hugo can be tough to watch at times.

133735844.review: A decent adventure through waves of rats

133732360.review:
I got this a part of my humble choice monthly sub. Didn’t think much of it until I burned out on hogwarts legacy and needed something to play. Installed this game and at about an hour in, i knew this game was special. 

The fact that not a lot of devs are making survival horror set in the Middle Ages should be a crime. It is the perfect time line to do it. People lead miserable lives, die of war, disease, starvation etc and this game captures all of that beautifully. Just in terms of atmosphere alone it is one of my absolute favorites. The visuals, the music, the art do a tremendous job of really immersing you in this historical hellhole. And the rats… holy Christ the rats. Nightmare fuel. 


As for the gameplay, I enjoyed the take on survival stealth. You can’t really action hero your way through this game (until you upgrade the sling). You have to play cautiously, smartly and use the environment to your advantage. You get no health bars. If you get caught and hit you will die. Each leve is a set piece with puzzles to solve involving rats, your use of fire and cleverly avoiding (or killing) the various human nuisance along the way. 

There is an upgrade system in the game but it isn’t that extensive… it is however, extremely useful. I appreciate this take. The early levels have you managing your resources (you don’t get much) and encourage you to explore and take risks to get that one piece of cord/leather/fabric for that one upgrade to change your gameplay. If you’re diligent, and explore each level you will be rewarded with a pretty powerful character. The game becomes more action packed but it never loses that horror/survival aspect. 

Overall, this was a pleasant, amazing surprise hit for me this year. The mixture of great atmosphere, awesome time period, engaging gameplay and tremendous story really elevate the whole package. It’s not a long game, but it throws you into one hell of a roller coaster ride. Get it if you love survival with a mix of mysticism, gore and spiritual horror. 

9/10.

133693091.review:
"A Plague Tale: Innocence" is an incredible video game with an emotionally gripping story. Set in 14th century France, it follows Amicia and her brother Hugo as they evade the Inquisition in a disease-ridden world infested with rats. The game's meticulously crafted setting and atmosphere draw you in completely.

What truly sets this game apart is its exceptional storytelling. The relationship between Amicia and Hugo is central, portrayed beautifully throughout the game. The well-developed supporting characters and excellent writing further enhance the narrative depth.

The gameplay is also outstanding, featuring challenging puzzles and satisfying combat. Strategic use of light and shadow adds an extra layer of depth, and the presence of swarming rats creates a unique and unnerving threat.

In summary, "A Plague Tale: Innocence" is a masterfully crafted game that seamlessly blends storytelling and gameplay. It evokes genuine emotional investment and keeps you on the edge of your seat. If you appreciate compelling narratives in video games, this is an absolute must-play.

Lo inicie con no tan altas expectativas y me dejo queriendo jugar su secuela.
 Ambientado durante la guerra de los 100 años, con la Inquisición como antagonista y de escenario, una Francia devastada por la peste negra o peste bubónica,
esta aventura narrativa se llevo mi aprecio y gratas horas de diversión ademas de una aversión significativa por las ratas, y respeto también.
Nuestra protagonista Amicia es una guerrera, un poco temeraria pero sensata, haciendo frente a todo para lograr salvar a su hermano, una muestra de afecto sublime
 que se gano mi atención y en lo personal hizo que me atraiga mucho mas, mención honoraria por Rodric, se llevo todo mi respeto.
El apartado gráfico es excelente,ni mas ni menos, su banda sonora es otra cosa, encaja en la dinámica y las escenas de manera única, increíble el soundtrack de Olivier, hizo una magia impecable.
 No tiene puntos negativos relevantes, creo que puede dar paso a criticas personales, nada mas, ya que su jugabilidad es practica, fácil de dominar, con un sistema de sigilo dócil y una dificultad normal que hace que puedas disfrutar y apreciar de mejor manera lo que la historia tiene para ofrecer.
Lo recomiendo, yo lo obtuve de oferta, pero creo que vale cada centavo, si te gusta ver ratas comiendo gente y una buena narrativa, esto es lo que buscan mesdames et messieurs.

133270423.review:
A Plague Tale: Innocence -

Is a rare jewel of a game, 
wherein you play the role of BIG sibling to a needy underling.
Not only are you struggling with loss, death, strife, plague...
practically the worst parts of the apocalypse; and not to 
mention having the "holy-grail" of (God's army) after you,
you would think there's no hope for our little heroin.

To the point,...the game 'graphically' is amazing,
What you get is an experience like no other;
The game seems to be designed to run on any
system,...because even running a 2060 Super
allows me to get ultra settings maxed w/o so
much as a single frozen frame. Fidelity is top
notch, frame rates are excellent, 60 fps on point.

I surely recommend the game.

133263761.review:
This game does not receive nearly as many flowers as it should (Hugo's Herbarium reference intended).

A Plague Tale: Innocence is a beautiful story, heartwarming and heart-wrenching in equal parts, of a bond forged that overcomes the Great Plague itself. Memorable characters, absolutely stunning scenery, and unique combat techniques are all rolled into this superb title from Asobo.

The stealth-action gameplay will appeal to fans of games like The Last of Us and Resident Evil 2, and the fantasy-inspired medieval setting creates the ideal atmosphere for fans of The Witcher or Thymesia.

I can highly recommend this game for its story, design, and characters alone, but I must also praise the way it utilises stealth-centric combat mechanics with a teenage protagonist. 15-year-old Amicia, despite her experience hunting in the woods with her father, is still young and has little knowledge of survival beyond the forest, as she grew up in an estate with noble parents. It would not make any sense for her to be grappling grown men in full suits of armour by herself, so I enjoyed the sling and her own wits being Amicia's only real weapons. Using alchemical concoctions and distraction techniques alongside the sling prompts the player to think, and offers them a variety of ways to handle a situation, even more so when accompanied by companions with special abilities. While the combat can be clunky at times, it's not too difficult to grasp and feels very gratifying to master.

The voice cast for this game is also outstanding. Charlotte McBurney and Tabitha Rubens can scream like nobody's business! Not to mention, both Stéphane Cornicard and Mark Healy are utterly chilling as Vitalis and Nicholas respectively. In combination with the gorgeous sound design, Innocence nails the atmospheric balance between unease and awe. The intensity of the strings during showdowns with the rats will make your heart skip a beat, while their more delicate crooning in the cinematic scenes will pull more than a few heartstrings (again, pun intended).

Overall, A Plague Tale: Innocence captured my attention quickly and held it fast for the entire duration of the game. I could play it over and over and still marvel at the love and dedication that went into creating it. I can't wait to try Requiem!

133158423.review:
Hay que entender que cada juego busca ofrecer algo al jugador, no todo siempre tiene que ser lo mismo, no busques en este juego algo tipo the last of us, ni armas o acción tipo resident evil, lo fuerte de A Plague Tale Innocence es su historia, punto, el pretexto de tener el control en tus manos y avanzar de una zona a la otra de principio a fin es simplemente contarte su historia, y si a eso le sumas unos gráficos increíbles cuidados al más mínimo detalle, hace que la experiencia sea aún mejor.

Es cierto que en juegos de puzzles, algo interesante es cuando puedes resolverlo de distintas maneras, y veo que muchos critican el hecho de que para ir avanzando en el juego, casi todo siempre tiene una única solución, que además si puede parecer obvia o no, el juego en la gran mayoría de ocasiones trata de dejártelo claro como avanzar, hasta el punto que de inicio a fin pareciera llevarte siempre de la mano, y aunque concuerdo con eso, no siempre es así, en varias situaciones quedará en ti el buscar como avanzar haciendo uso de tus distintas armas, como administrar los recursos para tener más munición o mejorar tu equipo, incluso quedará en ti explorar bien tu entorno para descubrir todos los coleccionables, que aunque no parezca difícil, pronto te darás cuenta que se te han pasado algunos, así que aunque es un juego bastante lineal, tiene su buena dosis de exploración.

Si buscas un juego con buena historia que te tenga intrigado de principio a fin, sin la necesidad de estar batallando con controles complicados, o tener que ir a lo rambo matando a cientos y cientos de monstruos porque te sobra munición a lo loco como en otros tantos juegos que parece no saben salir de lo mismo, o si no buscas el enésimo juego de mundo abierto que es inmensamente gigante pero tan vacío y que te aburre de lo desaprovechado que está, este es tu juego.

133098674.review:
Playing through this game three times, I wouldn't be mad about playing it a fourth time. It has a good story and it's enjoyable to play it.

However, it lacks in many ways and I don't recommend it.

The few good points:
- Graphics are beautiful. The scenery, the colors, like candy to the eye.
- Story, the characters, voice actors and all that combined. It's a pleasant ride. Almost like a movie plot.
That's about it. 

The bad points:
- Way too expensive for what it has to offer. From what I will mention below, if you [i]really[/i] want this game then get it when it's on sale, because £39,99 ain't it.
- Gameplay and story is extremely linear. There's only one way of playing this game, and that's it. There's no freedom, no choices, everything is scripted to be played in one way. Once you reach a checkpoint, you can't go back if you for example forgot to pick up an item. And there's no way to get back to that item unless you replay the whole chapter which means you lose the progress you've done. 
- The stealth is ridiculous ngl. My first thought was "what the hell is this" when I was apparently "sneaking" around. The characters are 10 centimeters away from the guards, whispering really loud, the steps when sneaking are loud enough but no, they hear nothing unless you stand right in front of their sight. 
- Playing through the game will take about 10 hours, after that you're finished. Nothing else to do with this game, it has nothing else to offer. There are no difficulty levels. No way to affect the story, everything is already decided how it will turn out. You only either kill guards or sneak past them, but if you do kill them you waste resources which means you can't upgrade your equipment or sling if you don't pay attention to what you use. And you can't upgrade all of your stuff in one save, what's the point in that? You either fully upgrade the sling/equipment for the 2 achievements, or fully upgrade the alchemy which leaves the sling and equipment being half upgraded. You can still very much beat the game without the full upgrades so I'm not sure what the use of the upgrades are.

So in conclusion, uninstalling and never touching this game again will be the results.

I still like this game it was fun to play it, but I don't recommend it at it's full price.
